{{Infobox scholar | image = Tzigara-Samurcaş.JPG | image_size = 230px | alt = | caption = Tzigara, photographed ca. 1914 | name = Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș | fullname = | other_names = Al. Tzigara, Tzigara-Sumurcaș, Tzigara-Samurcash, Tzigara-Samurkasch, Țigara-Samurcaș | birth_date = {{birth date|1872|4|4}} | birth_place = [[Bucharest]], [[Romania]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1952|4|1|1872|4|4}} | death_place = [[Bucharest]], [[Romania]] | era = 19th and 20th centuries | region = [[Eastern Europe]] | school_tradition = ''[[Junimea]]'' | main_interests = [[ethography]], [[museology]], [[art conservation]], [[art of Romania]], [[eugenics]] | notable_ideas = | major_works = | influences = [[Wilhelm von Bode]], [[Eugène Grasset]], [[Horace Lecoq de Boisbaudran]], [[Titu Maiorescu]], [[Alexandru Odobescu]], [[Grigore Tocilescu]] | influenced = }} '''Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș''' ({{IPA-ro|alekˈsandru t͡siˈɡara samurˈkaʃ}}; also known as '''Al. Tzigara''', '''Tzigara-Sumurcaș''', '''Tzigara-Samurcash''', '''Tzigara-Samurkasch''' or '''Țigara-Samurcaș'''; April 4, 1872 – April 1, 1952) was a [[Romania]]n art historian, [[Ethnography|ethnographer]], [[Museology|museologist]] and cultural journalist, also known as local champion of [[art conservation]], [[Romanian Police]] leader and pioneer radio broadcaster. Tzigara was a member of the ''[[Junimea]]'' literary society, holding positions at the [[Bucharest National University of Arts|National School of Fine Arts]], the [[University of Bucharest]] and lastly the [[Chernivtsi University|University of Cernăuți]]. During his youth, he was secretary to [[Carol I of Romania|Carol I]], the [[King of Romania]]. Close to the royal family, he also served as head of the [[Fundațiile Regale|Carol I Academic Foundation]], where he set up a large collection of [[photographic plate]]s. Tzigara achieved fame in 1906 as founder of the "National Museum", nucleus of the present-day [[Museum of the Romanian Peasant]], but was also involved in arranging and preserving the [[Theodor Aman]] art fund.
During [[World War I]], Tzigara-Samurcaș irritated Romanian public opinion by accepting to serve in a puppet administration set up by the [[Central Powers]]. Although his conduct was considered benign by the legitimate government, it drew him accusations of [[collaborationism]] from within academia, and aggravated his long-standing conflict with historian [[Nicolae Iorga]]. Tzigara was prevented from advancing in his university career over the [[interwar period]], but compensated for this mishap with other achievements: he was a delegate to several [[World's fair|world fairs]], the first-ever lecturer on [[Romanian Radio Broadcasting Company|Radio Romania]]'s staff, the editor in chief of ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'' magazine, and, shortly before retirement, a corresponding member of the [[Romanian Academy|Academy]]. His post-[[World War II]] years were spent in obscurity, owing to his ideological incompatibility with the [[Communist Romania|Romanian communist regime]].
Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș was alleged to be Carol I's illegitimate son, a rumor fueled by his closeness to court. He was himself the father of artist [[Ana Tzigara Berza]], and father in law of folklorist [[Marcu Berza]].
==Biography==
===Origins and early life=== A native of [[Bucharest]], Tzigara-Samurcaș was born on {{OldStyleDate|April 4|1872|March 23}},<ref name="culturatzs">{{ro icon}} [http://revistacultura.ro/nou/2011/01/intre-orient-si-occident-%E2%80%93-arhiva-de-imagine-alexandru-tzigara-samurcas/ "Între Orient și Occident – Arhiva de imagine Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș"], in ''Cultura'', March 19, 2011</ref><ref name="mparhiva">{{ro icon}} [[Mihai Plămădeală]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/index.html/articles|details?articleID=23503 "''Arhiva Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș''"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 519, April 2010</ref> and baptized into the [[Romanian Orthodox Church]].<ref name="abmoartea">{{ro icon}} Alexandru Barnea, [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/moartea-lui-carol-i-2874073/ "Moartea lui Carol I"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', October 20, 2006</ref> A popular rumor has him as the illegitimate son of ''[[Domnitor]]'' Carol I, the future King of Romania, to whom Tzigara was especially close in later years.<ref name="zomarturisiri">{{ro icon}} [[Z. Ornea]], [http://www.romlit.ro/mrturisirile_lui_tzigara-samurca "Mărturisirile lui Tzigara-Samurcaș"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 3/2000</ref><ref name="vdcurtea">{{ro icon}} Vasile Docea, [http://www.revistatribuna.ro/doc_db_site/tribuna/tribuna41.pdf "La curtea iubirilor reprimate"], in ''[[Tribuna (Romania)|Tribuna]]'', Nr. 41/2004, p.12</ref><ref>Boia, p.327; Nastasă (2010), p.89</ref> Historian [[Lucian Boia]] gives some credit to this piece of oral history, and notes that Tzigara, like [[Wilhelm Kremnitz|Wilhelm]] and [[Mite Kremnitz]], had "an unusually tight relationship" with the royal family.<ref name="lb327">Boia, p.327</ref> Researcher [[Zigu Ornea]], who notes that Tzigara may have been spreading the story around, argues: "This legend is naturally hard to verify but, in any case, it is a possible one, since Tzigara-Samurcaș was born in 1872 and Carol I was present on our throne, as ''Domnitor'', from 1866."<ref name="zomarturisiri"/> Like Boia, Ornea notes that Tzigara's close relationship with the king, the king's repeated interventions on his behalf "every time [Tzigara's career] got stuck", and his contacts with the Kremnitzes (including Mite, Carol's alleged mistress) were some additional clues to a royal bloodline.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/> Historian [[Vasile Docea]] criticizes Ornea's verdict, noting that it relies on questionable sources, and argues that, far from embracing this legend, Tzigara spoke "with evident pride" about his Tzigara roots.<ref name="vdcurtea"/> According to historian Lucian Nastasă, Docea effectively "disproved" the rumor of Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș{{'}}s royal descent.<ref name="ln(10)89">Nastasă (2010), p.89</ref>
Alexandru's mother and Carol's alleged mistress was Elena Samurcaș, married to Toma Tzigara.<ref name="vdcurtea"/><ref name="ln(10)89"/> Research into his maternal genealogy led the art historian to conclude that he was of noble [[Greeks|Greek]] and [[Greeks in Italy|Italo-Greek]] descent: his supposed ancestor was ''[[Spatharios]]'' [[Zotos Tzigaras]], buried in [[Venice]] at [[San Giorgio dei Greci]] (1599).<ref name="msr343-344">Rădulescu (2000), p.343-344</ref> The Samurcaș family had aristocratic blood, being related to the [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|boyar nobility]] of [[Wallachia]]: the art historian's paternal line made him a relative of the Kretzulescu, Rallet, Bengescu and Crețeanu boyar families.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.162; (2010), p.89, 331</ref>
[[File:Tzigara-Samurcaș, combined arms.svg|thumb|240px|Combined arms of the Tzigara and Samurcaș families]] Also of boyar rank, Alexandru's Samurcaș ancestors had a history on both sides of the [[Southern Carpathians]], in Wallachia and in then-[[Austrian Empire|Austrian]]-ruled [[Transylvania]]. Active during the [[Age of Revolution]], Wallachian ''[[Vornic]]'' Constantin Samurcaș took part in [[Filiki Eteria|Eterist agitation]],<ref>Rădulescu (2000), p.350</ref> but later, fleeing the [[Wallachian uprising of 1821|1821 rural uprising]], settled in [[Brașov|Kronstadt (Brașov)]] to spy for the Austrians.<ref name="dhradio">{{ro icon}} Dumitru Hîncu, [http://www.romlit.ro/al._tzigara-samurca_-_din_amintirile_primului_vorbitor_la_radio_romnesc "Al. Tzigara-Samurcaș - Din amintirile primului vorbitor la Radio românesc"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309113354/http://www.romlit.ro/al._tzigara-samurca_-_din_amintirile_primului_vorbitor_la_radio_romnesc |date=2014-03-09 }}, in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 42/2007</ref> Another ancestor, ''[[Postelnic]]'' Alecu Samurcaș, was a linguist, known for his work in the [[Greek language]].<ref>Nastasă (2010), p.90</ref> The meeting of two branches was recorded in the [[coat of arms]] that Tzigara-Samurcaș fashioned for himself, showing the ''[[spatha]]'' of Zotos Tzigaras, alongside a [[sable]] ([[Romanian language|Romanian]]: ''samur'') and a stylized eyebrow.<ref name="msr343-344"/>
A while after Toma Tzigara's death, Alexandru was adopted by his childless uncle Ioan Alecu Samurcaș (he officially took the name ''Tzigara-Samurcaș'' years later, in 1899); he was also helped with his education by the Kremnitzes, who taught him [[German language|German]], introduced him to high society circles, and regarded him as a son.<ref>Nastasă (2010), p.89-90, 347</ref> His first contacts with history and folk art came by means of his extended family, which collected and preserved documents and art objects.<ref>Rădulescu (2000), p.344</ref>
After graduating from the [[Matei Basarab High School]] and taking his [[Romanian Baccalaureate|Baccalaureate]], he enlisted at the University of Bucharest Faculty of Letters, Historical Section.<ref name="mparhiva"/> It was here that the young man was acquainted with his first mentors: writer-collector [[Alexandru Odobescu]] and archeologist [[Grigore Tocilescu]], the latter of whom ensured Tzigara's employment as custodian for the National Museum of Antiquities.<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="mparhiva"/> He was a critic of the museum's underdevelopment under Tocilescu's management, and wrote that the disorganized collection comprised an [[Ancient Egyptian burial customs|Egyptian mummy]], copies of frescoes from the [[Curtea de Argeș Cathedral|Cathedral Church]] in [[Curtea de Argeș]], items from the [[Pietroasele Treasure]], and works of [[Precolumbian art]], alongside a scale model of the [[Eiffel Tower]].<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Andrei Pippidi]], [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/ieri-cu-vedere-spre-azi/articol/casa-macca "Casa Macca"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Nr. 265, March 2009</ref>
From 1893,<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref>Boia, p.327. See also ''Luceafărul'' (1914), p.265</ref> the young graduate was in the [[German Empire]], where he studied at the [[University of Berlin]] and the [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich|Ludwig Maximilian University]], taking his [[Ph.D.]] in [[Munich]] with a dissertation on the [[Baroque painting|Baroque painter]] [[Simon Vouet]].<ref name="mparhiva"/> He received his diploma, ''[[magna cum laude]]''.<ref name="luc265">''Luceafărul'' (1914), p.265</ref> Tzigara-Samurcaș returned to his home country and, following a dispute with Tocilescu, gave up his position at the Antiquities Museum.<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="mparhiva"/> He later specialized in museology in [[Paris]], hearing lectures at the ''[[École des Beaux-Arts]]'' and working for city museums,<ref name="luc265"/> before returning to Germany, where he studied with the preeminent [[Duchy of Brunswick|Brunswickian]] curator [[Wilhelm von Bode]].<ref name="culturatzs"/>
===Early academic career=== [[File:Palatul Fundatiei Universitare (Biblioteca Centrala Universitara).jpg|thumb|300px|Palace of the [[Fundațiile Regale|Carol I Academic Foundation]], ca. 1904 (photograph by Alexandru Antoniu)]] Back in Romania, Tzigara unsuccessfully applied for the Archeology Chair created at the [[University of Iași]], but lost; according to scholar and diarist [[Teohari Antonescu]], who emerged as the victor, the competition was rigged in his own favor, even though Tzigara "had the good sense to come prepared."<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.372</ref> From 1899, he was librarian of the [[Fundațiile Regale|Carol I Academic Foundation]] and Professor of Aesthetics and Art History at the National School of Fine Arts.<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="mparhiva"/><ref>''Luceafărul'' (1914), p.265-266; Boia, p.327</ref> As Tzigara later acknowledged, his introduction to royalty came through a relationship with the Kremnitzes, his neighbors on Polonă Street, [[Dorobanți]].<ref name="zomarturisiri"/> This period saw the start of Tzigara's close relationship with Carol, whom the art historian later called "my most generous protector" and "the sovereign ''[[Wiktionary:par excellence|par excellence]]''".<ref name="zomarturisiri"/> Received into royal circles, he was a confidant of the [[List of Romanian consorts|Queen Consort]] and cultural patron, [[Elisabeth of Wied]], whom he called "the animator of [[Art of Romania|Romanian art]]".<ref>Ciupală, p.98</ref> For a while, he was her private secretary, helping her fulfill her literary ambitions under the ''Carmen Sylva'' signature.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref>Nastasă (2007), p.162-163</ref> Tzigara's recollections speak with enthusiasm about Elisabeth's works, as well as about the king's dislike for her interests in [[spiritism]] or philosophy, and discuss Carol's enduring affection for Mite Kremnitz.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/>
In order to support his lectures at the Fine Arts School, Tzigara began gathering [[photographic plate]]s, a collection which grew in size over the following decades. It includes images of European monuments and works of art, as well as samples of [[Architecture of Romania|Romanian architecture]] (in some cases, the only surviving images of since-demolished buildings) and copies of maps.<ref name="mparhiva"/> The images of local life are considered of particular importance, since they document the [[Westernization]] and [[modernization]] of Romania's landscape.<ref name="culturatzs"/> Mostly anonymous works, they most likely include some of Tzigara's own photographs.<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="mparhiva"/> A few of them were inventoried by [[Editura Casa Școalelor]], and some were published, in Tzigara's lifetime, by ''Buletinul Comisiunii Monumentelor Istorice'' or other Romanian scientific magazines.<ref name="mparhiva"/> His [[Image projector|image projections]] at the Carol I Foundation, supporting a students' elective course on sculpture and painting, became one of the better-known student summer activities.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Andrei Pippidi]], [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/ieri-cu-vedere-spre-azi/articol/amintirile-unui-arhitect "Amintirile unui arhitect"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Nr. 216, April 2008</ref>
The young scholar was at the time also interested in the development of [[decorative arts]], which he wanted to reflect the local tradition of [[handicraft]]s and notions of national specificity.<ref name="iv51">Vlasiu, p.51-52</ref> According to art historian Ioana Vlasiu, Tzigara and painter-researcher [[Abgar Baltazar]] were in part responsible for fusing local folk art and international [[primitivism]] with [[Art Nouveau]], thus paving the way for the ''[[Neo-Brâncovenesc]]'' school of decorators and architects.<ref>Vlasiu, ''passim''</ref> The interest in decorative works was a special focus of his visits to [[England]] and [[France]]—the [[Victoria and Albert Museum|South Kensington Museum]] impressed him greatly, as did the workshops of [[Eugène Grasset]] and [[Horace Lecoq de Boisbaudran]].<ref name="iv51"/>
===''Junimea'' debut=== Described by Lucian Nastasă as a case of social climbing, Tzigara's marriage to Maria (1900) brought him into the high circles of aristocracy: Maria, born into the [[Cantacuzino family]] (daughter of [[Alexandru Cantacuzino]], former [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Romania)|Foreign Affairs Minister]]), was also the widow of [[Grigore Sturdza]], and as such inherited part of the [[Sturdza family]] fortune.<ref>Nastasă (2003), p.53-54, 109; (2007), p.162-163; (2010), p.90, 168, 347</ref> Through her mother Coralia, Maria Tzigara-Cantacuzino was additionally related to [[boyar]] lines of [[Moldavia]], the Boldurs and the Costakis, as well as to Zulnia, mother of historian [[Nicolae Iorga]].<ref>Nastasă (2003), p.54, 71; (2010), p.90, 168, 331</ref> This marriage was reportedly arranged by the Kremnitzes, the couple having as their best men-[[Godparent|godfathers]] two influential political figures: [[Lupu Kostaki]], [[Constantin C. Arion]].<ref>Nastasă (2010), p.90, 111, 346-347</ref>
During the ''[[fin de siècle]]'' period, Tzigara-Samurcașș also began a cooperation with ''Junimea'', the literary society representing Romanian [[traditional conservatism]], and sympathized with the ''Junimist'' nucleus of the [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]]. The art historian was one of the young scholars fascinated with the personality of [[Titu Maiorescu]], the cultural critic and main ''Junimea'' leader, and joined a new ''Junimist'' critical elite which also comprised [[Constantin Rădulescu-Motru]], [[Pompiliu Eliade]], [[Mihail Dragomirescu]], [[P. P. Negulescu]] etc.<ref>Nastasă (2003), p.151-152; (2007), p.173-174</ref> His work was featured, along with texts by other 50 ''Junimists'', in the [[Editura Socec]] volume ''Lui Titu Maiorescu omagiu, XV februarie MCM'' ("To Titu Maiorescu as Homage, February 15, 1900").<ref>Nastasă (2003), p.151-152</ref> Maiorescu's diaries display his interest in Tzigara's private life, and claim that the scholar was by then lover of the widowed and much older [[Mite Kremnitz]], with whom Maiorescu himself had had an affair.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/>
Tzigara attended, in 1901, a major event in ''Junimist'' society: the wedding between Nicolae Iorga and Ecaterina, daughter of scholar [[Ioan Bogdan]], where Tzigara unofficially represented the royal court.<ref>Nastasă (2003), p.39, 71</ref> Tzigara was the couple's godfather at an [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Orthodox]] marriage service held outside the [[Kingdom of Romania]], in [[Șcheii Brașovului|Belgerei (Șcheii Brașovului)]], Transylvania.<ref>Nastasă (2003), p.71; (2007), p.323; (2010), p.168</ref> For a while, Iorga and Bogdan were both interested in obtaining Tzigara a better employment at the University of Bucharest, but their efforts were made useless by the ''Junimea'' adversary in government, the [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]].<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.321-323</ref>
Before 1903, Tzigara became a literary and art columnist at ''[[Epoca (Romania)|Epoca]]'' newspaper, headed at the time by Maiorescu.<ref name="zo(98)122">Ornea (1998), p.122</ref> During the period, ''Junimea'' popularized its causes through ''Epoca'', rather than through their main venue ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', and, according to Maiorescu's own pronouncement, Tzigara's work was a main asset.<ref name="zo(98)122"/> Around 1907, Tzigara's work was also regularly featured in ''Convorbiri Literare'', edited by Maiorescu's pupil [[Simion Mehedinți]]. At the time, Transylvania's ''Răvașul'' journal commented that Tzigara's art chronicle and [[Aurel Popovici]]'s political column were especially "rich" in information, and mentioned that Tzigara and Teohari Antonescu were debating, through the journal, about the characteristics of fortified houses (''cule'') from [[Oltenia]] region.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/revasul/1907/BCUCLUJ_FP_279662_1907_005_021_022.pdf "Cărți, reviste, ziare"], in ''Răvașul'', Nr. 21-22/1907, p.382 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> As literary historian [[Tudor Vianu]] notes, Tzigara-Samurcaș and architect [[Aurel Zagoritz]] centered their contributions here on the scientific study of [[Folklore of Romania|Romanian folk art]], but their presence nevertheless coincided with ''Convorbiri Literare''{{'}}s decline in readership.<ref name="tv11">[[Tudor Vianu]], ''Scriitori români'', Vol. II, [[Editura Minerva]], Bucharest, 1970, p.11. {{OCLC|7431692}}</ref> Tzigara also published his articles in Iorga's traditionalist magazine ''[[Sămănătorul]]'', where he discussed the art exhibits of the ''[[Tinerimea Artistică]]'' society.<ref>Șotropa, p.28</ref>
===National Museum creation=== [[File:MTR Mills 1A.jpg|thumb|280px|A village mill, preserved in the [[Museum of the Romanian Peasant]]]] Around 1901, inspired by the [[Exposition Universelle (1900)|Paris World Fair]], Tzigara and other Romanian ethnographers first took into consideration the establishment of a permanent ethnographic collection.<ref>Longuet, p.144; Vlasiu, p.51</ref> Like other Romanian intellectuals, Tzigara preserved his special interest in handicrafts, which, art conservator Isabelle Longuet argues, were "elevated to the status of 'national art' " in the belief that the peasantry represented "an authentic 'Romanianness' ".<ref name="il144">Longuet, p.144</ref> In similar terms, ethologist Ioana Popescu notes: "[Tzigara's] collections were to become the argument and the source of inspiration for the national ideology and creation."<ref name="ipfragile">Ioana Popescu, [http://www.plural-magazine.com/article_a-fragile-collection-the-memory-of-glass-plates.html "A Fragile Collection - The Memory of Glass Plates"], in the [[Romanian Cultural Institute]]'s ''[http://www.plural-magazine.com/ Plural Magazine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321152817/http://www.plural-magazine.com/ |date=2012-03-21 }}'', Nr. 21/2004</ref> His project came after a similar attempt on the part of art collector [[Nicolae Minovici]], founder of the private folk art museum ''[[Nicolae Minovici folk Art Museum|Casa Minovici]]'',<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Adina Dinițoiu]], [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Vila-cu-clopotei-are-noi-prieteni*articleID_15315-articles_details.html " 'Vila cu clopoței are noi prieteni' "], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 319, May 2006</ref> and an even earlier textile art archive, endorsed by Maiorescu (1875).<ref name="ndiurban">Narcis Dorin Ion, [http://www.plural-magazine.com/article_urban-memory-museums-of-the-romanian-capital.html "Urban Memory: Museums of the Romanian Capital"], in the [[Romanian Cultural Institute]]'s ''[http://www.plural-magazine.com/ Plural Magazine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321152817/http://www.plural-magazine.com/ |date=2012-03-21 }}'', Nr. 32/2008</ref>
1906 marked the start of Tzigara's chief work as an ethnographer. That year, he founded the "Museum of Ethnography and National Art", now [[Museum of the Romanian Peasant]] (and which he intended to name "Museum of the Romanian People"),<ref>Tăslăuanu, p.60. On the other proposed names, see Vlasiu, p.51</ref> serving as its Director for the next forty years. This project received support from Education Minister Haret and, on the other side of politics, from Haret's predecessor Maiorescu.<ref name="ndiurban"/> The institution was later known as "Museum of Ethnography and National Art" or "Carol I Museum of Ethnography and National Art".<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="il144"/><ref name="abmeteor">{{ro icon}} Alexandru Barnea, [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/meteorologie-si-etnografie-in-bucuresti-acum-99-de-ani-2876964 "Meteorologie și etnografie în București, acum 99 de ani"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', October 6, 2006</ref> Its original quarters were the abandoned National Mint building on [[Șoseaua Kiseleff|Kiseleff Road]], but plans were being made for a new, more adequate museum palace.<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="abmeteor"/>
As manager, Tzigara-Samurcaș ordered the collection into two distinct sections, dedicated respectively to ethnography-proper and [[sacred art]] (the latter chapter also took over the religious objects kept at the National Museum of Antiquities).<ref name="il144"/> An additional exhibit was to include the ''[[Tropaeum Traiani]]'' [[Metope (architecture)|metopes]], attesting the [[Roman Empire]]'s rule over [[Dobruja]].<ref name="abmeteor"/> Tzigara's subsequent work as a collector and folk art historian received much appreciation. A 1914 article in ''[[Luceafărul (magazine)|Luceafărul]]'' journal stated: "[He] reorganized [the museum] and turned into a true national institution. The Museum's rich collections are owed to Mr. Tzigara-Samurcaș's industriousness."<ref name="luc266">''Luceafărul'' (1914), p.266</ref> In 2010, folk art reviewer [[Mihai Plămădeală]] wrote that Tzigara's activity "impacted on everything that this Museum ever meant in the history of [[Culture of Romania|Romanian culture]]."<ref name="mparhiva"/>
Tzigara's fieldwork also focused specifically on increasing the museum's ethnographic collection. Particularly active in Oltenia, he was, as Ioana Popescu notes, "more attracted by decorated, colorful objects, used at celebration time."<ref name="ipfragile"/> During one such trip to [[Gorj County]], he bought, disassembled and transported back to Bucharest the "Antonie Mogoș House", considered a masterpiece of Romanian woodcarving and the museum's centerpiece.<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="msrskansen"/><ref name="mmetnogf">{{ro icon}} Miron Manega, [http://www.sfin.ro/articol_4743/stiri_pe_scurt.html "Etnografia românească în epoca de piață"], in ''[[Săptămâna Financiară]]'', April 28, 2006</ref> It is the first-ever such relocation in the history of Romanian museums.<ref name="mmetnogf"/><ref>Georgeta Stoica, [http://www.plural-magazine.com/article_a-landmark-on-the-european-map-the-dimitrie-gusti-national-village-museum.html "A Landmark on the European Map: the Dimitrie Gusti National Village Museum"], in the [[Romanian Cultural Institute]]'s ''[http://www.plural-magazine.com/ Plural Magazine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321152817/http://www.plural-magazine.com/ |date=2012-03-21 }}'', Nr. 24/2004</ref> His photographic collection was expanded by an entire series on Oltenian carpets, which helps in their specific [[Taxonomy (general)|taxonomy]].<ref name="ipfragile"/>
The developments raised interest among the [[Romanians|ethnic Romanian]] community of Transylvania, whose cultural body, the [[Asociația Transilvană pentru Literatura Română și Cultura Poporului Român|ASTRA Society]], was in the process of creating its own permanent exhibit of folk architecture, later [[ASTRA National Museum Complex]]. ASTRA activist [[Octavian Tăslăuanu]] reported in 1909: "[Tzigara's] national art museum, although [...] important sums were spent on it, is at the early stage of its beginnings. Only two years ago did more systematic work begin for its endowment and presently, its national significance recognized, the state granted it a yearly sum of 14,000 [[Romanian leu|lei]] [...]. And maybe in a few years those who are running it, so diligently, will manage to turn it into an institution of great importance for our national art."<ref>Tăslăuanu, p.60-61</ref> The next year, Tzigara himself wrote, in ''Convorbiri Literare'', that Tăslăuanu's work with ASTRA permanent exhibits was far more advanced than his when it came to storage and display, but noted that the ASTRA collections were not yet rich enough to validate the "museum" name.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/transilvania/1910/BCUCLUJ_FP_279996_1910_041_005.pdf "Însemnări. Muzeul Asociațiunii"], in ''Transilvania'', Nr. 5/1910, p.376 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
===Aman Museum and Bucharest University=== [[File:Theodor Aman - In atelierul artistului.jpg|thumb|340px|[[Theodor Aman]], ''În atelierul artistului'' ("In the Artist's Studio")]] During those years, Tzigara was also an inspector and evaluator of works collected from [[Secu Monastery]] and the [[Diocese of Buzău]], becoming both a Fellow of the Romanian Royal Society of Geography and the Architects' Society.<ref name="dhradio"/> Tzigara also served as representative of the Romanian curators in European colloquiums: the Public Art Congress of [[Liège]], [[Belgium]] (1905) and the [[Braunschweig]] Congress on Art Conservation (1906), where he presented a report on the efforts to preserve Romanian monuments.<ref name="luc266"/> Also in 1906, Tzigara-Samurcaș attended the 8th International Congress of Art History.<ref name="luc266"/> Once familiarized with the artistic fashions of the day, Tzigara reported to the National Liberal [[Ministry of Education, Research, Youth and Sport (Romania)|Education Minister]] [[Spiru Haret]] about the need to reform the [[Education in Romania|educational system]] in such manner as to provide peasant children with an artistic education, citing reasons moral and economical.<ref>Vlasiu, p.51</ref>
Around 1908, Tzigara was also involved in the process of cataloging and preserving the body of works left by Romanian painter [[Theodor Aman]]. The Aman Museum appointed him director, and, under his leadership, opened its doors to the public for the very first time.<ref name="luc266"/> Tzigara was also involved in controversies marking the celebration of Carol I's 40th year on the throne, when he spoke out against politician [[Ioan Lahovary]], accused of mismanaging the [[Carol Park]] festivities.<ref name="ln(07)37">Nastasă (2007), p.37</ref>
The creation of a separate University of Bucharest Art History Department for Tzigara was a project which split the academic and political world. At the core of such disputes was Nicolae Iorga, from the History Department, who argued that his own courses also covered art, and who consequently became Tzigara's main adversary.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.36-37, 323</ref> The proposal of expanding University was also defeated in [[Parliament of Romania|Parliament]] by Lahovary, the [[Senate of Romania|Senate]] president, who probably still resented for his 1906 comments.<ref name="ln(07)37"/> The debates prolonged themselves over the following years. In 1909, Tzigara-Samurcaș, [[Grigore Tocilescu]] and [[George Murnu]] competed with each other for the Archeology Chair, and this created a dispute over whether art historians could not lecture in archeology (Murnu eventually won the contest, despite being exposed for [[plagiarism]] by Tzigara, in articles for the magazine ''[[Noua Revistă Română]]'').<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.37, 310-311</ref> The same year, he was in [[Sweden]], [[Norway]] and [[Denmark]], where he visited the [[Skansen]], [[Norwegian Museum of Cultural History|Bygdøy]] and [[Frilandsmuseet|Lyngby]] [[open-air museum]]s, but suggested that a similar project would be redundant at home, arguing that peasant society in Romania was only too visible around Bucharest.<ref name="msrskansen">{{ro icon}} Mihai Sorin Rădulescu, [http://www.romlit.ro/skansen_i_muzeele_etnografice_din_bucureti "Skansen și muzeele etnografice din București"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 36/2009</ref> He was much more impressed with the [[Nordic Museum]], which reportedly became the template for his Bucharest museum.<ref name="msrskansen"/>
In 1911 (or 1912), Tzigara eventually became a Substitute Professor of Art History at the University of Bucharest,<ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref name="dhradio"/><ref>Boia, p.108, 327, 353; Nastasă (2007), p.36</ref> attending the [[Great Berlin Art Exhibit|Great Art Exhibit]] of [[Berlin]] and, in [[Italy]], the ''[[International Exhibition of Art (1911)|Esposizione internazionale d'arte]]''.<ref name="luc266"/> He lectured on folk art at the ''[[Kunstgewerbemuseum Berlin]]'' and in [[Austria-Hungary]], at the [[Vienna]] ''[[Museum für angewandte Kunst Wien|Museum für angewandte Kunst]]''.<ref name="luc266"/> Overall, his mission was to introduce Romanian art to an international audience, as noted by ''Luceafărul'': "he arranged the Romanian pavilions, making known for the first time in history the artistic creations of our people. In all exhibits he registered successes".<ref name="luc266"/> A prestigious visitor of the National Museum was [[Raymund Netzhammer]], the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bucharest|Catholic Archbishop of Bucharest]], who was introduced there by Tzigara, with whom he remained good friends.<ref name="abmeteor"/> Netzhammer was impressed with its ethnographic collection: "Nowhere can one acquire a better eye for Romanian folk art than in this establishment."<ref name="abmeteor"/>
In support of his activities, Tzigara published a succession of art books. In 1906, ''Arta publică'' ("Public Art") appeared in Bucharest, while the [[German-language]] study ''Denkmalpflege in Rumänien'' ("Historical Preservation in Romania") saw print in [[Karlsruhe]].<ref name="luc266"/> Later, Tzigara contributed biographical and critical entries in the 1907 edition of ''[[Allgemeines Lexicon der Bildenden Kunstler|Allgemeines Lexicon der bildenden Künstler]]''.<ref name="luc266"/> ''Catalogul Muzeului Aman'' ("The Aman Museum Catalog") of 1908 was followed the same year by the essay ''Ce se înțelege prin arheologia de azi'' ("The Present-day Meaning of Archeology") and the monograph ''Biserica din Filipeștii de Pădure'' ("The Church of [[Filipeștii de Pădure]]", co-authored with [[Nicolae Ghica-Budești]] and [[Gheorghe Balș]]).<ref>''Luceafărul'' (1914), p.266, 268</ref> In 1909, he authored the album-study ''Arta în România'' ("Art in Romania"), comprising his collected ''Convorbiri'' essays and edited by [[Editura Minerva|Minerva]],<ref name="goarta860">{{ro icon}} [[Gheorghe Oprescu]], [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/transilvania/1920/BCUCLUJ_FP_279996_1920_051_011.pdf "Arta țărănească la Români"], in ''Transilvania'', Nr. 11/1920, p.860 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> together with another monograph, ''Muzeul neamului românesc'' ("The Museum of the Romanian People").<ref name="luc266"/>
The next year, he followed up with ''Discuțiuni în jurul arheologiei'' ("Debates on Archeology") and ''Rumänische Volkskunst'' ("Romanian Folk Art"); in 1911, with ''Casa românească de la Roma'' ("The [[Casa Romena|Romanian House]] of [[Rome]]"); in 1912, with ''Sonderaustellung Rumäniens'' ("Romania's Special Exhibit"), ''Istoria artei și însemnătatea ei'' (Art History and Its Significance"), ''Muzeul național din București'' ("The National Museum Bucharest").<ref name="luc266"/> Between 1909 and 1912, he also redacted Carol I's 17 volumes of memoirs, working from scattered notebooks.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/> As an art critic for ''Epoca'' and ''Convorbiri'', Tzigara became one of those who opposed the new [[Primitivism|primitivist]] tendencies of the ''[[Tinerimea Artistică]]'' group: in 1910, he chided the modern sculptor [[Constantin Brâncuși]] for his break with tradition, and even suggested that Brâncuși's works be hidden away from the public eye.<ref>Juvara, p.78, 81</ref> Such reactions made Brâncuși decide to leave Romania and begin his international career.<ref>Juvara, p.78-79</ref>
While in Rome, Tzigara was reputedly offered membership in the [[Freemasonry]]'s [[Grand Orient de France]], to whom many of Romanian colleagues belonged (''see [[Freemasonry in Romania]]''). The offer, Tzigara later claimed, was made by sculptor [[Ettore Ferrari]], and included various perks and a promise that he would soon become a [[Grand Master (Masonic)|Masonic Grand Master]].<ref name="ln(07)102-103; (10)230">Nastasă (2007), p.102-103; (2010), p.230</ref> Although widely rumored to have taken up the offer, Nastasă writes, Tzigara was probably never a Freemason.<ref name="ln(07)102-103; (10)230"/> Also in 1911, he was briefly President of a newly created professional association, the [[Romanian Writers' Society]].<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.525</ref>
===1910s projects and ASTRA conferencing=== [[File:RO SB metropolitan cathedral.jpg|thumb|230px|The [[Holy Trinity Cathedral, Sibiu|Sibiu Cathedral]], with paintings by [[Octavian Smigelschi]]]] Tzigara's honors for 1912 included the Romanian Kingdom's ''Bene Merenti'' medal for services to culture.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.134</ref> During much of that year, after some campaigning to obtain state funds,<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="luc266"/> the art historian considered proposals for the Ethnography Museum's headquarters, also housed on Kiseleff. He and his colleagues looked into international proposals, from [[Heino Schmieden]], [[Louis Blanc (Swiss architect)|Louis Blanc]] and others, but eventually settled for a design proposed to them by the Romanian native Ghica-Budești.<ref name="mparhiva"/> The Neo-Brâncovenesc features of the building, researchers note, where themselves an attempt to highlight the return to a peasant model.<ref name="msrskansen"/><ref>Longuet, p.144, 146</ref> This formed part of a greater [[urban planning]] effort undertaken, with Carol I's approval and the involvement of Neo-Brâncovenesc architects, throughout northern and central Bucharest, with the erecting of many new public buildings: the [[Palace of Justice (Bucharest)|Palace of Justice]], the [[CEC Palace]], the [[Geology Museum (Romania)|Geology Museum]] etc. (''see [[History of Bucharest]]'').<ref name="apcaroli">{{ro icon}} [[Andrei Pippidi]], [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/ieri-cu-vedere-spre-azi/articol/tot-despre-carol-i "Tot despe Carol I"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Nr. 227, June 2008</ref> Despite the approval, and the ceremonial placement of a foundation stone,<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref name="abmeteor"/> construction was remarkably slow or under-financed, and Tzigara, who came to resent Ghica-Budești, did not live to see its completion.<ref name="mparhiva"/>
Tzigara's scientific work for 1913, when he also attended the ''[[Tentoonstelling De Vrouw 1813-1913|Tentoonstelling De Vrouw]]'' event in [[Amsterdam]],<ref name="dhradio"/> includes a monograph on the [[Curtea de Argeș Cathedral|Curtea de Argeș Cathedral Church]].<ref name="luc266"/> That year, as Romania joined the [[Second Balkan War]] coalition against the [[Kingdom of Bulgaria]], and although spared from [[conscription]], Tzigara volunteered for service in the [[Romanian Land Forces]].<ref name="dhradio"/><ref name="ln(07)91">Nastasă (2007), p.91</ref> He motivated this initiative by stating that his skill was needed for documenting the war and creating its archive.<ref name="dhradio"/> Tzigara served in the [[4th Infantry Division (Romania)|4th Army Corps]], under [[Ferdinand I of Romania|Crown Prince Ferdinand]] (Carol I's designated successor).<ref name="ln(07)91"/>
In 1914, Tzigara was appointed Director of the Carol I Foundation.<ref name="mparhiva"/> At around the same time, he began a new series of conferences in Austria-Hungary, lecturing on art for the benefit of Romanians in Transylvania and [[Banat]] regions. He was also interested in the collection of Transylvanian Romanian artifacts, added to the Bucharest Museum collection.<ref name="luc265"/> Initially, he was in [[Lugoj|Lugosch (Lugoj)]], informing locals about Romanian folk art.<ref name="luc265"/> One other such event took place in [[Sibiu|Hermannstadt (Sibiu)]], where he was invited by ASTRA to speak about the 50 years of development in Romanian art.<ref>''Luceafărul'' (1914), ''passim''</ref>
This conference contained Tzigara' artistic credo: he believed that art was an objective reflection of social and cultural development, identifying the [[Westernization]] process, the proclamation of the [[Kingdom of Romania|1881 Kingdom]] and later events with a profound transformation of Romania.<ref>''Luceafărul'' (1914), p.266-267</ref> However, Tzigara suggested, these efforts did not yet find a suitable answer in the artistic field, that is the birth of a specifically Romanian art phenomenon and the proper conservation of artistic legacies: he deplored the destruction of old Bucharest townhouses and their replacement with Westernized villas; he commended the restoration of [[Horezu Monastery]] in its original ''[[Brâncovenesc style|Brâncovenesc]]'' style, but criticized those who introduced [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic revival]] elements at [[Tismana Monastery|Tismana]], [[Bistrița Monastery|Bistrița]] or [[Arnota Monastery|Arnota]]; lastly, he expressed support for the "healthy" [[Neo-Brâncovenesc]] style of [[Ion Mincu]] and criticized muralist [[Octavian Smigelschi]] for his work on the [[Holy Trinity Cathedral, Sibiu|Sibiu Cathedral]].<ref>''Luceafărul'' (1914), p.267-268</ref> The conference included ample praise of Carol I as a patron of conservation, and nods in the direction of Carol's French architect, [[André Lecomte du Nouÿ]].<ref>''Luceafărul'' (1914), p.267, 268</ref>
The second part of Tzigara's Hermannstadt conference focused on the Romanian school of oil painting. He paid homage to its traditionalist founder, [[Nicolae Grigorescu]], and to Aman, before summarizing the later contributions of Ș[[Ștefan Luchian|tefan Luchian]], [[Arthur Verona]] and [[Jean Alexandru Steriadi]].<ref name="luc268">''Luceafărul'' (1914), p.268</ref> The third part highlighted his own research of Transylvanian folk art, and spoke about Romania's Queen Elisabeth as a collector of folk art from Sibiu area.<ref name="luc268"/>
Tzigara preserved these principles during the rest of his professional life, and the themes of his conferencing resurface in his old age memoirs. These too shed light on Carol I's architectural role, and express approval for Lecomte de Nouÿ's since-criticized methods of conservation (including the decision to the tear down and rebuild Curtea de Argeș Cathedral).<ref name="zomarturisiri"/> They also return to Smigelschi's murals, criticizing his depiction of saints in [[Romanian dress|national Romanian dress]] as highly inappropriate.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/>
===World War I and Germanophilia=== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-R36187, Bukarest, Parade einziehender Truppen.jpg|thumb|350px|[[August von Mackensen]] reviewing [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] troops in occupied [[Bucharest]]]] Tzigara's international and scholarly activities suffered from the outbreak of [[World War I]] in summer 1914, even though Romania remained neutral until mid-1916. His purported father, Carol I, died in September 1914. According to his Archbishop Netzhammer, Tzigara was deeply affected by the event: "Like a child, he loosened his suffering, deploring in front of me this terrible and unexpected loss".<ref name="abmoartea"/> By then, however, Tzigara had befriended Ferdinand I, the new king, and was an admirer of Ferdinand's wife, [[Marie of Edinburgh]]. He found that Ferdinand was "gentle", "jocular" and usually self-effacing, "in all things the opposite of his uncle" Carol I.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/> In Queen Marie, the art historian recognized a political woman, more active in public affairs than Carol's Elisabeth.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref>Ciupală, p.100</ref> Tzigara also shared Marie's artistic taste, including her passion for the work of [[Symbolist movement in Romania|Romanian Symbolist]] sculptors [[Oscar Späthe]] and [[Friedrich Storck]] (whom, in 1903, he had called them "innovators of Romanian sculpture").<ref>Șotropa, p.21</ref>
Unlike Ferdinand and his [[Francophile]] circle, who desired a Romanian alliance with the [[Entente Powers|Entente]] for the sake of [[Union of Transylvania with Romania|union with Transylvania]], Tzigara was opposed to any move against Germany. He represented the [[Germanophile]] lobby within the University of Bucharest, at the same junior level as another substitute professor, [[Constantin Litzica]].<ref name="lb108">Boia, p.108</ref> For a while, he was also co-opted on the leadership committee of the Romanian Writers' Society, but lost his seat there in 1915 (probably owing to his presence among the minority of Germanophile writers).<ref>Boia, p.104</ref>
The [[Romania in World War I|subsequent campaign]] ended abruptly in southern Romania's invasion by the [[Central Powers]] (Germans and their allies). In November 1916, shortly before King Ferdinand and the pro-Entente government retreated to [[Iași]], they appointed Tzigara-Samurcaș a custodian of the Crown and Royal Domains, tasked with preventing acts of vandalism on the occupiers' part.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref name="lb327"/><ref name="dhradio"/> He stayed behind in Bucharest and met with [[August von Mackensen]], head of the occupation forces. As a result of this encounter, the Germans asked Tzigara to discuss an offer of [[Collaborationism|collaboration]] with the senior Conservative Party Germanophiles: Maiorescu, [[Alexandru Marghiloman]], [[Petre P. Carp]]. All three refused to openly associate with Mackensen's military rule, but a puppet civilian administration was set up under Carp's disciple [[Lupu Kostaki]].<ref>Boia, p.327; Ornea (1998), p.390-393</ref> Carp's reply to Tzigara's proposition is recorded as: "Such a thing is of no interest to me; it is nonsense, and at this moment counts as weakness."<ref>Ornea (1998), p.391</ref> Maiorescu's deteriorating relationship with Carp was also a factor: Carp flatly refused to attend any meeting where Maiorescu was present, and alienated the other two by stating that King Ferdinand should be deposed.<ref>Ornea (1998), p.393</ref> Maiorescu himself explained that it was a question of principle: "Tzigara has been proposing this to me, but I did not wish to. If [Mackensen] orders me to go, let him send in armed soldiers to take me."<ref>[[Ion S. Floru]], "Întâlniri cu Titu Maiorescu", in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', December 1995, p.51</ref>
On {{OldStyleDate|December 13|1916|November 30}}, the art historian took over as Police chief in occupied Bucharest. This proved to be a highly controversial decision, the consequences of which would harm Tzigara's [[Interwar period|interwar]] career. While his political adversaries later alleged that Tzigara had been granted the appointment through German pressures, he himself claimed that Carp and Kostaki had asked him to become involved.<ref name="lb327"/> Also according to Tzigara, his appointment resolved a practical issue, since his legitimate predecessor, General [[Alexandru Mustață]], could not speak any [[German language|German]].<ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref name="lb327"/> Kostaki's administration also included Litzica, who was puppet [[Ministry of Education, Research, Youth and Sport (Romania)|Minister of Education]] in spring 1917.<ref name="lb108"/> Tzigara personally intervened in the selection of other bureaucrats. In February 1917, he brought writer [[I. A. Bassarabescu]] into his Police apparatus, obtaining his release from German [[internment]] and appointing him head of division.<ref>Boia, p.166</ref> Reportedly, he did the same for philosopher [[Mircea Florian]], who became his Carol I Foundation subordinate.<ref>Boia, p.350</ref>
As recorded by Archbishop Netzhammer, Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș was open and cooperative in his relationship with the new authorities and the [[Regat Germans|German community]].<ref name="abmeteor"/> In September 1917, the Romanian scholar greeted [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Wilhelm II]], [[German Emperor]], who was visiting the occupied half of Romania. Reportedly the only Romanian in attendance, he followed Wilhelm to the [[Curtea de Argeș Cathedral]], where they both paid their respects to Carol I's tomb.<ref name="lb328">Boia, p.328</ref> Tzigara was also a personal guest at the imperial table, and Wilhelm had several long conversations with him in private.<ref name="lb328"/> At the end of their encounter, Tzigara received from the emperor's hand a diamond-and-ruby [[tie pin]].<ref name="lb328"/>
Tzigara-Samurcaș nonetheless had a complex relationship with his German supervisors. He refused to cooperate with them on several occasions, objecting to the creation of a German Institute within the University, and being strongly opposed to the Central Powers' interventions on [[National Museum of Art of Romania|Bucharest Royal Palace]] grounds.<ref name="lb328"/> In late 1916 and early 1917, he was in intense correspondence with [[Ioan Bianu]], a fellow scholar and disillusioned Germanophile, who complained about the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]] pressures on the [[Romanian Academy]] and asked Tzigara to intervene on his colleagues' behalf.<ref>Boia, p.175-176, 328</ref> On one occasion, as a result of Bianu's plea, Tzigara sent in his policemen to prevent German soldiers from stealing the Academy's firewood reserves.<ref>Boia, p.176, 328</ref> Boia argues that the main objective of Tzigara's term, "the security of people and property", was competently met.<ref name="lb328"/> The same is noted by Ornea, who cautions: "the nude fact of his, all things considered, willing collaboration with the German occupier, is still a litigious issue".<ref name="zomarturisiri"/> The Police chief was also critical of his more docile colleagues: as recorded in Marghiloman's diary, Tzigara was present at the October 1917 [[Athénée Palace]] gala organized by Mackensen (October 1917), but was irritated to find himself in the company of junior bureaucrats who were well liked by the Germans. He referred to this category, which included poet [[Luca Caragiale]], as the "nippers".<ref>Boia, p.203</ref> In December of the same year, Caragiale enraged Tzigara by going over his head: the poet used German connections to obtain Police guards at an official function, after Tzigara had refused to grant his request.<ref>Boia, p.203-204</ref>
===Collaborationism scandal and late 1920s=== In January 1918, while the Iași authorities were considering a way out of the war, Tzigara-Samurcaș handed in his resignation to the Germans.<ref name="lb327"/> A [[Treaty of Bucharest (1918)|separate peace with the Central Powers]] followed: in March–April, the new [[national unity government]] of Marghiloman reassigned him to the position of Police chief.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref name="lb328"/> This posting, made legitimate by King Ferdinand's royal decree, Tzigara kept until November 14, 1918—that is, three days after the [[Armistice with Germany]] reshuffled Romania's commitments.<ref name="lb328"/> During the interval, with only 220 forces under his command, he was powerless to deal with the growing protest movement of [[Căile Ferate Române|Romanian Railways]] workers.<ref>V. Liveanu, "Note și însemnări. Cu privire la evenimentele din 26(13) decembrie 1918", in ''Studii. Revistă de Istorie'', Nr. 1/1958, p.97</ref>
Romania's sudden return to Francophilia had also brought Marghiloman's downfall, described by Tzigara as an anti-Conservative "''[[coup d'état]]''".<ref name="zomarturisiri"/> Zigu Ornea finds this expression of resentment especially problematic, since, he argued, it meant that Tzigara placed Germanopilia above the establishment of [[Greater Romania]]: "[he] understood next to nothing from the reality of the wartime political phenomenon."<ref name="zomarturisiri"/>
The end of the war signified a slump in Tzigara's career. His imperial tie pin, Boia notes, became a "''[[corpus delicti]]''" for those accusing Tzigara of [[treason]].<ref name="lb328"/> Such accusations were given ample exposure in Rector [[Ion Atanasiu]]'s essay ''Rătăciri naționale'' ("National Ravings", 1919), answered to in detail by Tzigara's own ''[[List of Latin phrases: P#pro domo|pro domo]]'', ''Mărturisiri silite'' ("Forced Confessions", 1920), and later by his posthumously published ''Memorii'' ("Memoirs").<ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref>Boia, p.328, 353</ref> Athanasiu was the first who suggested holding Tzigara accountable for his wartime behavior, and, in his University report, alluded to the possibility of sacking both him and the Germanophile biologist [[Victor Babeș]].<ref>Boia, p.353</ref> Ornea finds that, in those years, Athanasiu and Tzigara's traditional foe Nicolae Iorga were waging "a veritable war against Tzigara-Samurcaș".<ref name="zomarturisiri"/>
Tzigara was omitted from an early purge of University Germanophiles, but, on November 29, 1919, was subjected to questioning by Rector Atanasiu, Iorga and the Board of Professors. As he later recalled, his defense tactic was to recall that, back in 1906, Iorga himself was seen as a radical [[Francophobia|Francophobe]] (''see [[Sămănătorul]]'').<ref name="lb353-354">Boia, p.353-354</ref> On Iorga and Atanasiu's proposal, but against the advice of [[Ion Cantacuzino]] and [[Dimitrie Onciul]], the Board took a vote to ban Tzigara-Samurcaș; the result was indecisive, and Tzigara preserved his chair.<ref>Boia, p.354, 355-356</ref> Atanasiu however took the vote as evidence that Tzigara had lost his support, and requested a decision from higher authorities. As Boia notes, this was a political miscalculation: the anti-Germanophile lobby had been defeated in [[Parliament of Romania|Parliament]] by [[Prime Minister of Romania|Prime Minister]] [[Alexandru Vaida-Voevod]], who could not be expected to grant Atanasiu a victory.<ref>Boia, p.354-355</ref> In the end, Education Minister and zoologist [[Ioan Borcea]] sent a letter to Atanasiu, asking him to desist frustrating Tzigara "in his attributions without legal decision", adding: "Especially at this moment in time, we find it necessary that peace and harmony be restored for University to function properly."<ref>Boia, p.354</ref> These and other moral defeats prompted Atanasiu to present his resignation, which came with his final protest that Minister Borcea had snubbed University during the "Tzigara-Samurcaș affair".<ref>Boia, p.355</ref> In later years, Tzigara took his main accusers, Iorga and journalist [[Stelian Popescu]], to court, in what became two celebrity trials.<ref name="dhradio"/>
As noted by literary critic Dumitru Hîncu, the art historian's wartime conduct was never censured by the interwar governments.<ref name="dhradio"/> He was again received into Queen Marie's circle, who allegedly told him: "Iorga is jealous that he sees you coming over to visit with us."<ref>{{ro icon}} [[G. T. Kirileanu]], [http://www.zf.ro/ziarul-de-duminica/g-t-kirileanu-1921-culise-regale-v-3041447/ "1921. Culise regale (V)"], in ''[[Ziarul Financiar]]'', March 9, 2007</ref> Tzigara was still an art columnist for ''Convorbiri Literare'',<ref name="goarta860"/> and, in 1921, became its new editor in chief. According to ASTRA's newspaper, ''Transilvania'', Tzigara rescued ''Convorbiri'' from bankruptcy, but only catered to a niche audience.<ref>{{ro icon}} S[evastian] V[oicu], [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/transilvania/1929/BCUCLUJ_FP_279996_1929_060_002.pdf "Mișcarea culturală. Reviste"], in ''Transilvania'', Nr. 2/1929, p.158 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> He was thus unable to steer the magazine back into the cultural mainstream, its previous dominance replicated by the [[left-wing]] ''[[Viața Românească]]''.<ref name="tv11"/>
In 1923, he was the Inspector General of Museums, under the National Liberals' [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]] cabinet, in which capacity he revisited the ASTRA Museum and awarded it a 50,000 lei grant from the state.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/transilvania/1924/BCUCLUJ_FP_279996_1924_055_010_011.pdf "Raportul general. Muzee"], in ''Transilvania'', Nr. 10-11/1924, p.387-388 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> The period also witnessed his first private visits to the Transylvanian [[spa town]], [[Sovata]].<ref>Nastasă (2010), p.244</ref> His main home in Bucharest was a large villa on Kogălniceanu Street, where he was living with his family.<ref>Nastasă (2010), p.390</ref>
Despite his confirmation at the university, Tzigara-Samurcaș found it impossible to achieve [[tenure]],<ref name="Boia, p.356">Boia, p.356</ref> and was also ousted from the Fine Arts School over his Germanophilia.<ref name="mparhiva"/> With the diplomatic recognition of Greater Romania came new opportunity, and, in 1926, Tzigara left for [[Bukovina]], taking over the art history department at [[Chernivtsi University|Cernăuți University]].<ref name="mparhiva"/><ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref>Boia, p.356; Nastasă (2007), p.297</ref> Also that year, a mortally ill King Ferdinand made him a Grand Officer of the [[Order of the Star of Romania]].<ref name="dhradio"/> Again touring Germany with a series of conferences (1926), Tzigara also spoke at [[Reichs-Rundfunk-Gesellschaft|Radio Berlin]], making his debut in radio programming.<ref name="dhradio"/> Reportedly, his request of creating a special Romanian section on Berlin's [[Museum Island]] was granted by the [[Weimar Republic]] in early 1927.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/societateademaine/pdf/BCUCLUJ_FP_279802_1927_004_003.pdf "Cronică măruntă"], in ''[[Societatea de Mâine]]'', Nr. 3/1927, p.33 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref>
On November 1, 1928, Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș provided the first-ever [[Romanian Radio Broadcasting Company|Radio Romania]] broadcast in history, with an art lecture specifically written for this purpose.<ref name="dhradio"/> This, Tzigara recalled, was a ''[[pro bono]]'' activity to please Radio Romania's president [[Constantin Angelescu]], but made the speaker himself very nervous: Tzigara thought his own text bland and his voice ill-adapted for the medium, but took pains to improve them in later broadcasts.<ref name="dhradio"/> In 1929, Tzigara was a first judge at the original [[Miss Romania]] beauty contest, in a panel which also included Vaida-Voevod, writers [[Liviu Rebreanu]] and [[Nicolae Constantin Batzaria]], woman activist [[Alexandrina Cantacuzino]] and other public figures.<ref name="dhradio"/><ref>{{ro icon}} Ana Zidărescu, [http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/miss-romania-are-80-de-ani-840995.html "Miss România are 80 de ani"], in ''[[Evenimentul Zilei]]'', February 29, 2009</ref>
Romanian cabinets appointed him a national representative at the [[1929 Barcelona International Exposition|Universal Exposition]] in [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]], and organizer of the folk art exhibit at the [[International Peace Bureau]]'s [[Balkans|Balkan]] Conference in [[Athens]], [[Greece]].<ref name="dhradio"/> He also attended the 13th International Congress of Art History in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]], and organized the Romanian pavilion at an Art Conference in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]].<ref name="dhradio"/> His efforts won international recognition, and the French state, through [[French Ambassador to Romania|Bucharest Ambassador]] [[Gabiel Puaux]], presented Tzigara with a gift of [[Manufacture nationale de Sèvres|Sèvres porcelain]].<ref name="dhradio"/> He was also awarded the [[Order of St. Sava]] by the [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]].<ref name="dhradio"/>
===1930s=== Tzigara's position was threatened in 1930, when Ferdinand's deposed son [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]] retook his throne. It was alleged that Iorga, a supporter of the new king, asked for Tzigara to be removed from the royal Foundation, but that Carol had stated not being willing to sack "my own uncle."<ref name="zomarturisiri"/><ref name="vdcurtea"/> Iorga was however in a position to limit his rival's access to academia when, in 1931, he became Carol II's Prime Minister. His legislative proposal, limiting the number of academic positions an individual could hold, was probably aimed specifically at Tzigara and other personal enemies (as Lucian Nastasă writes, Iorga was himself collecting some five monthly salaries from his work with the state).<ref name="ln(10)371">Nastasă (2010), p.371</ref>
At around the same time, Tzigara became a contributor to the official literary and scientific magazine, ''[[Revista Fundațiilor Regale]]'',<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.524</ref> and again toured the country with lectures on folk art.<ref>{{ro icon}} Grigore Bugarin, [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/societateademaine/pdf/BCUCLUJ_FP_279802_1939_016_003.pdf "Stilul clădirilor publice"], in ''[[Societatea de Mâine]]'', Nr. 3/1939, p.103 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> With [[Simion Mehedinți]] and the ASTRA Society, he returned to the field of public activism with controversial lectures on the biology of the Romanian nation, which sometimes included overt advocacy of [[eugenics]].<ref>[[Maria Bucur]], ''Eugenics and Modernization in Interwar Romania'', [[University of Pittsburgh Press]], Pittsburgh, 2002, p.33-34, 169. {{ISBN|0-8229-4172-4}}</ref> His [[Racialism (racial categorization)|racialist]] theory had it that the [[geometric abstraction]] of peasant art, purported to have been strongly resistant to foreign influence, placed Romanians in the "[[Alpine race]]" cluster—an idea rejected in its day by anthropologist [[Henric Sanielevici]], who contrarily believed that Romanians were "[[Mediterranean race|Mediterranean]]".<ref>[[Henric Sanielevici|H. Sanielevici]], "Supraviețuiri din mysterele<!-- sic --> dionysiace la ereticii din Basarabia", in ''[[Viața Românească]]'', Nr. 11-12/1930, p.116-118</ref> In 1933, he was briefly affiliated with the [[National Socialist Party (Romania)|Romanian National Socialist Party]] and its "Romanian–German Cultural Institute".<ref>Mihai A. Panu, ''Capcanele ideologiei. Opțiuni politice ale etnicilor germani în România interbelică'', Editura Mega, Cluj-Napoca, 2015, p. 188. {{ISBN|978-606-543-631-2}}</ref>
Moving away from Germanophilia, Tzigara saluted the [[Brussels International Exposition (1935)|Brussels World Fair]] of 1935 by highlighting the special connection between Romania, on one hand, and, on the other France, [[Belgium]] and the Francophone countries.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Ioan Stanomir]], [http://www.revista22.ro/imagini-si-identitate-nationala-piese-pentru-dosarul-unei-dezbateri-2150.html "Imagini și identitate națională: piese pentru dosarul unei dezbateri"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 816, October 2005</ref> He spoke on [[Radio France]] and the [[RTBF|INR]] (he found the [[Francophone]] services to be more relaxing, but less organized, than their German counterpart).<ref name="dhradio"/> In the 1920s and '30s, Tzigara was host to several foreign researchers. [[Columbia University]] professor [[Charles Upson Clark]] called his institution "splendid", finding it partly responsible for a "distinct revival" in peasant crafts.<ref>Clark, p.262</ref> He described the museum as "a revelation of the artistic endowment of the Roumanian peasant."<ref>Clark, p.310</ref> French archivist François de Vaux de Foletier visited his museum in 1934, later writing, in ''Monde et Voyages'' magazine, that it featured "very interesting galleries of Romanian ethnography".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Andrei Pippidi]], [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/bordeie-obiceie/articol/impresiile-unui-oaspete-francez-ii "Impresiile unui oaspete francez (II)"], in ''[[Dilema Veche]]'', Nr. 344, September 2010. For the full context of Vaux de Foletier's visit, see [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/editoriale-opinii/articol/impresiile-unui-oaspete-francez-i "Impresiile unui oaspete francez (I)"], in ''Dilema Veche'', Nr. 343, September 2010.</ref>
Beginning 1933, Tzigara was several times interviewed by [[Eugen Wolbe]], the German biographer of Romanian kings, who had been sent to him by Carol II. Tzigara also reviewed Wolbe's texts, including his work on Queen Elisabeth (a "weak" study, in Tzigara's opinion), and described the visiting writer as an unreliable amateur: "that pensioned ex-''[[Gymnasium (Germany)|Gymnasiallehrer]]'' still had the audacity to select himself such august subjects, with the pretext of 'gaining many new friends for the beautiful country' of Romania, of which yet he himself knew so little!"<ref name="afferdbio">{{ro icon}} Alexandru Florescu, [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/FLORESCUian5.html "Istorie și istorii: o biografie a regelui Ferdinand"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317061502/http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/FLORESCUian5.html |date=2012-03-17 }}, in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', January 2005</ref> Tzigara was upset to receive a copy of Wolbe's 1937 work on Ferdinand, which, he claimed, entirely ignored specific criticism; he also approved of Prime Minister [[Gheorghe Tătărescu]]'s decision to ban the volume in its Romanian edition (the censoring left Wolbe indifferent, a fact noted in one of his letters to Tzigara).<ref name="afferdbio"/> Tzigara's rival Iorga, probably incited by this controversy and by his own work with Wolbe, gave the book a positive review in his journal ''[[Neamul Românesc]]'', calling the government measure "regrettable", and receiving further criticism from Tzigara, through ''Convorbiri''.<ref name="afferdbio"/>
The Carol I Museum increased in size throughout the interwar, organized several exhibits,<ref name="il146">Longuet, p.146</ref> and, in 1931, inaugurated its Ethnographic Section at the new Kiseleff location.<ref name="abmeteor"/> In parallel, Tzigara popularized Romanian handicrafts abroad with his new French-language tract, ''Tapis Roumains'' ("Romanian Carpets").<ref>Kurt Erdmann, ''Seven Hundred Years of Oriental Carpets'', [[University of California Press]], Berkeley & Los Angeles, 1970, p.233. {{ISBN|0-520-01816-8}}</ref> Other contributions, published by ''Convorbiri Literare'' in 1934, include an introduction to [[Alexandru Odobescu]]'s posthumous texts, ''Ineditele lui Odobescu'' ("Odobescu's Unpublished Texts")<ref>Călinescu, p.996</ref> and an edition of Odobescu' 1895 suicide note.<ref>Nastasă (2010), p.442-443</ref> Another work, grouping his articles in defense of the Museum's construction, was published in 1936 as ''Muzeografie românească'' ("Romanian Museography").<ref name="culturatzs"/> Tzigara and cultural historian [[Nicolae N. Condeescu]] also left a monograph on the [[Peleș Castle]], Carol I's residence in [[Sinaia]].<ref name="dapolul">{{ro icon}} Dan Arsenie, [http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/povestea-polului-lui-carol-o-moneda-de-100000-de-euro-910716.html "Povestea polului lui Carol, o monedă de 100.000 de euro"], in ''[[Evenimentul Zilei]]'', October 30, 2010</ref>
As editor of ''Convorbiri Literare'', Tzigara also entered a polemic with a younger Maiorescu disciple, the critic and novelist [[Eugen Lovinescu]]. At the root of this debate stood Lovinescu's book on [[Mite Kremnitz]] and her affair with [[national poet]] (and ''Junimist'' herald) [[Mihai Eminescu]]. Joining in with other conservatives who accused Lovinescu of being a "[[Pornography|pornographer]]", Tzigara claimed to defend Eminescu's image from the book's impiety.<ref name="goglose">{{ro icon}} Gabriela Omăt, [http://www.romlit.ro/glose_la_o_fotografie_e._lovinescu_...victim_a_mitului_eminescian "Glose la o fotografie: E. Lovinescu ...victimă a mitului eminescian"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 49/2002</ref> Lovinescu offered his replies in the daily ''[[Adevărul]]'', accusing Tzigara of "literary incompetence", and deploring the decline of ''Convorbiri'' beyond the threshold of professionalism: "if, under previous directions, the magazine steered away from its stated mission [...], the deviance was at least made in an honorable direction, that is to say in the direction of history writing; the scientific seriousness of its two former directors had made it possible for ''Convorbiri'' to have valid contributions in areas other than literature."<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.adevarul.ro/cultura/literar_si_artistic/retro/Adevaruri_de_altadata-_Reactie_la_o_critica_0_242976107.html "Adevăruri de altădată: Reacție la o critică"], in ''[[Adevărul]]'', April 13, 2010</ref> In reaction to claims of irreverence, he derided his adversary's artistic expertise as being about "[[Easter egg]]s", and defended his narrative as a sample of respect for Eminescu's life and legacy.<ref name="goglose"/>
Tzigara met significant opposition in his bid for [[Romanian Academy]] membership, primarily from Academy member Iorga.<ref>Boia, p.356. See also Nastasă (2007), p.510</ref> He was eventually elected a corresponding member<ref name="abmeteor"/> in 1938, when Iorga's influence was being challenged by his younger peers.<ref name="Boia, p.356"/> The same year, he was pensioned from his positions at Cernăuți University and the Foundation.<ref name="mparhiva"/><ref name="ln(10)409">Nastasă (2010), p.409</ref> In 1939, he dedicated himself to completing his homage to the memory of Carol I, on his 100th birthday: ''Din viața regelui Carol I. Mărturii contemporane și documente inedite'' ("From the Life of King Carol I. Contemporary Testimonials and Never-before Published Documents"), called "splendid" by Lucian Nastasă.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.88</ref> He resigned from his editorial office at ''Convorbiri'', which was taken over by writer and linguist [[I. E. Torouțiu]]. Tzigara announced this change with a final editorial piece, which read: "Satisfied to have insured the magazine's future, we announce at this moment that we are placing our directorial office in the hands of a new generation, which is led by Professor I. E. Torouțiu, [...] who with his valuable and sizable published works, appreciating ''Junimea''{{'}}s role in the movement to renew the Romanian literary language, will know how to carry on the ever-lasting flame of ''Junimist'' ideas".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Cassian Maria Spiridon]], [http://convorbiri-literare.dntis.ro/TATAian4.html "Eminescu la 1939"], in ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', January 2004</ref>
At that point in life, Tzigara was also pleased with the state and popularity of museology in Greater Romania; in 1937, he had claimed: "all the country is presently a museum".<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Tita Chiper]], [http://www.dilemaveche.ro/sectiune/dileme-line/articol/ce-se-pastreaza-convorbire-cu-horia-bernea "Ce se păstrează?"], in ''[[Dilema Veche|Dilema]]'', Nr. 347, October 1999</ref> His hostility to [[open-air museum]]s was by then a thing of the past, since, it was argued, Greater Romania's peasant society seemed threatened by modern urbanization.<ref name="msrskansen"/> In the late 1930s, this judgment prompted sociologist [[Dimitrie Gusti]] to create the [[Dimitrie Gusti National Village Museum in Bucharest|National Village Museum]], located a short distance away from Tzigara's own building site.<ref name="msrskansen"/>
===World War II and final years=== A final moment of preeminence in Tzigara's career occurred during [[World War II]]. Initially, with war looming, [[Chief of the Romanian General Staff]] [[Florea Țenescu]] tasked Tzigara with drafting an ''Ex-ante International Convention Project for the Protection of Monuments and Works of Art'', which was never put into motion.<ref name="dhradio"/> In summer 1940, during a period when Carol II was trying to calm tensions between Romania and [[Nazi Germany]], Tzigara, [[Ion Nistor]], [[Grigore Antipa]], [[Ion Sân-Giorgiu]] and other academics greeted a Nazi visitor, scholar [[Herbert Cysarz]].<ref>Frank-Rutger Hausmann, ''»Auch im Krieg schweigen die Musen nicht«: die Deutschen Wissenschaftlichen Institute im Zweiten Weltkrieg'', [[Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht]], Göttingen, 2001, p.75-76. {{ISBN|3-525-35181-X}}</ref>
After 1940, Romania ousted Carol II's [[National Renaissance Front]] government, replacing it with an openly [[Fascism|fascist]], pro-[[Axis Power|Axis]] regime, the [[National Legionary State]]. In parallel, Tzigara managed to gather political support for terminating [[Nicolae Ghica-Budești]]'s contract and, in 1941, hired architect Gheorghe Ionescu to finalize the Museum's construction.<ref name="mparhiva"/> Late in the same year, he was one of the Romanian scholars who welcomed German [[Romance studies]] expert [[Ernst Gamillscheg]] on his visit to Bucharest.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/web/bibdigit/periodice/gandirea/1941/BCUCLUJ_FP_279479_1941_020_009.pdf "Cronici. Idei, oameni, fapte. În cinstea d-lui profesor Ernst Gamillscheg"], in ''[[Gândirea]]'', Nr. 9/1941, p.500 (digitized by the [[Babeș-Bolyai University]] [http://documente.bcucluj.ro/ Transsylvanica Online Library])</ref> In 1942, he was tasked by Romania's military dictator [[Ion Antonescu]] with creating a monumental National Heroes' Cemetery in [[Carol Park]], but the building works were cut short by the reversal of fortunes on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]].<ref>{{ro icon}} Edward Pastia, [http://www.sfin.ro/articol_10248/romania_nu_are_bani_nici_macar_sa_scrie_istoria.html "România nu are bani nici măcar să scrie istoria"], in ''[[Săptămâna Financiară]]'', August 17, 2007</ref> Also then, he returned to research with a book about the carpets and rugs of [[Oltenia]], which notably stated his [[Ethnic nationalism|ethnic nationalist]] credo in art: "By using the everlasting heritage of our beautiful folk art in different fields, we will be easily able to get rid of the foreign influences that pervaded Romanian households."<ref name="ipfragile"/>
Shortly after the [[King Michael's Coup|August 1944 Coup]] deposed Antonescu, the daily ''[[România Liberă]]'', which was at the time a [[Romanian Communist Party]] tribune, featured Tzigara's name on a list of "national betrayal", which also included Germanophile or fascist intellectuals.<ref>{{ro icon}} Cristina Diac, [http://www1.jurnalul.ro/scinteia/jurnalul-national/comunism-artisti-si-ziaristi-in-febra-epurarilor-23564.html "Comunism - Artiști și ziariști în febra epurărilor"], in ''[[Jurnalul Național]]'', April 12, 2006</ref> Two years later, the pro-communist cabinet of [[Petru Groza]] sidelined Tzigara-Samurcaș, appointing him honorary director of the museum, but effectively stripping him of his responsibilities.<ref name="mparhiva"/> At that stage, plans were being examined for the disestablishment of the Peasant Art Section at the Museum, but Tzigara obtained support from Communist Party man [[Emil Bodnăraș]] and from [[President of Romania|Presidium Chief]] [[Constantin Ion Parhon]].<ref name="dhradio"/> Tzigara attended the clandestine meetings of the [[Mihai Eminescu]] Association, an [[anti-communist]] group formed through the efforts of critic [[Pavel Chihaia]], and which disappeared in 1948.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Gheorghe Grigurcu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/destinul_unui_rezistent_pavel_chihaia "Destinul unui rezistent: Pavel Chihaia"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 41/2001</ref> His chief activity, from 1948 to 1952, was the writing of his memoirs.<ref name="zomarturisiri"/>
The official establishment of [[Communist Romania|Romania's communist regime]] was the start of several new problems for the aging scholar: many of his belongings were taken away during [[Nationalization in Romania|nationalization]], others were sold in [[public auction]], while he himself was taken to court by some of his former employees.<ref name="mparhiva"/> In 1948, he was also [[List of purged members of the Romanian Academy|stripped of his Academy membership]].<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.511</ref> The following year, his pension was suspended,<ref name="ln(10)409"/> although, in 1950, he was elected to the International Committee of the History of Art.<ref name="dhradio"/> The National Museum was reopened in 1951 as a "National Museum of Folk Art", under new management.<ref name="il146"/>
Marginalization aggravated Tzigara's illnesses, and he died on April 1, 1952.<ref name="culturatzs"/><ref name="mparhiva"/> He was buried at [[Bellu Cemetery]], with a small ceremony attended by family and a few of his intellectual friends: ''Convorbiri'' colleague Mehedinți, ''Junimist'' philosopher [[Constantin Rădulescu-Motru]], physician [[Daniel Danielopolu]] and writer [[Gala Galaction]].<ref>Nastasă (2010), p.470</ref> He had lost his public profile, and the international community was left uninformed of his death: in 1955, an invitation to the 18th Art History Congress was mistakenly addressed to him.<ref name="dhradio"/>
==Legacy== Tzigara's contribution as an art historian has received mixed evaluations. According to Lucian Nastasă, his 1911 course at the Bucharest University was the first professional approach to the subject, after the "somewhat organized" attempts on Odobescu's part.<ref>Nastasă (2007), p.36</ref> Writing in 1920, art historian [[Gheorghe Oprescu]] also suggested that, with Nicolae Iorga's reviews, Tzigara's "intelligent articles" were the only ones in the Romanian press to properly educate the public taste.<ref name="goarta860"/> [[Charles Upson Clark]] also rated "Tzigara-Samurcash" as one of Romania's "best-known modern writers" in the field of archeology or ancient art, with [[Alexandru Lapedatu]], [[George Murnu]] and [[Abgar Baltazar]].<ref>Clark, p.301</ref> Contrarily, a later assessment made by ethnologist [[Romulus Vulcănescu]] rated both Tzigara, Iorga and Oprescu as authors of "ethnological essayistics and cultural [[microhistory]]", who lacked a global approach to folk art research.<ref>{{ro icon}} Iordan Datcu, [http://www.romlit.ro/profesorul_alexandru_dima "Profesorul Alexandru Dima"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091128092355/http://www.romlit.ro/profesorul_alexandru_dima |date=2009-11-28 }}, in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 39/2005</ref> Dumitru Hîncu, writing in 2007, noted that, once "a first-rate cultural figure", Alexandru Tzigara-Samurcaș "no longer says a great deal for your average present-day reader".<ref name="dhradio"/>
The art historian's figure inspired literary critic [[George Călinescu]] in writing his novel ''[[Scrinul negru]]'', about the decline of Romanian aristocracy.<ref name="abmeteor"/> A more unusual trace of his activity is preserved in ''Tzigara-Samurkasch'', the name of a fictional place in the writings of Bukovina native [[Gregor von Rezzori]].<ref>Andrei Corbea-Hoișie, "''Maghrebinien''—ein Gedächtnisort ''ex negativo''", in Jacques Lajarrige (ed.), ''Austriaca 54: Gregor von Rezzori'', [[University of Rouen]], 2003, p.17. {{ISBN|2-87775-340-9}}</ref> A comment left by Tzigara in his [[Peleș Castle]] book has fueled [[cyberculture]] speculation and an urban legend about the existence of 20 lei coins from the 1860s, which are supposedly extremely valuable items.<ref name="dapolul"/>
Tzigara-Samurcaș's Museum building was only finished after his death, later in the 1950s.<ref name="mparhiva"/> By the time of its completion, however, the building's purpose had changed, and, historian [[Andrei Pippidi]] writes, it "passed through the most humiliating of its stages".<ref name="apcaroli"/> Its collections were moved to a new location, and, in 1978, merged into the Village Museum.<ref name="ndiurban"/><ref name="il146"/> The Kiseleff building was assigned to the "[[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]]-[[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]] Museum", which later became the Communist Party Museum.<ref name="abmeteor"/><ref name="il146"/> Shortly after the [[Romanian Revolution of 1989]] toppled communism, the [[National Salvation Front (Romania)|Salvation Front]] Minister of Culture [[Andrei Pleșu]] created, on National Museum grounds, a Museum of the Romanian Peasant, which he placed under the direction of painter [[Horia Bernea]].<ref>Longuet, p.146-147</ref> It was officially inaugurated in 1993.<ref>Longuet, p.147</ref> Although sometimes described as Tzigara's successor, Bernea, helped by ethnologist [[Irina Nicolau]], merged the scientific function into a [[conceptual art]] project, which is described by various commentators as a radical break with the interwar National Museum.<ref>{{ro icon}} Radu Bercea, Ioana Popescu, [http://www.revista22.ro/scandal-la-mtr-1085.html "Scandal la MȚR"], in ''[[Revista 22]]'', Nr. 754, August 2004; [[Vintilă Mihăilescu]], Maria Bercea, [http://www.revista22.ro/mtr-e-mai-mult-decat-un-muzeu-e-o-institutie-culturala-2364.html "MȚR e mai mult decât un muzeu: e o instituție culturală"], in ''Revista 22'', Nr. 827, January 2006. See also Longuet, p.146sqq</ref>
