{{Other people|James Lovell|James Lovell (disambiguation)}} {{redirect|Marilyn Lovell|singer and AIDS activist|Marilyn Lovell Matz}} {{pp-semi-protected|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox astronaut |image = Jim Lovell official 1966 portrait.jpg |type = [[NASA]] astronaut |nationality = American |status = Retired |birth_name = James Arthur Lovell Jr. |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1928|03|25}} |birth_place = [[Cleveland, Ohio]], United States |occupation = [[Test pilot]] |rank = [[Captain (U.S. Navy)|Captain]], [[United States Navy|USN]] |selection = [[List of astronauts by selection#1962|1962 NASA Group]] |time = 29d 19h 03m |mission = [[Gemini 7]], [[Gemini 12]],
[[Apollo 8]], [[Apollo 13]] |insignia =
[[File:Gemini VII patch.png|40px]] [[File:Gemini 12 insignia.png|40px]]
[[File:Apollo-8-patch.png|50px]] [[File:Apollo 13-insignia.png|40px]]
}} '''James Arthur Lovell Jr.''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|ʌ|v|əl}}; born March 25, 1928) is a former [[NASA]] [[astronaut]], [[Naval Aviator]], and retired [[United States Navy|Navy]] [[Captain (United States O-6)|captain]]. Lovell is known for being the commander of the ill-fated [[Apollo 13]] mission, which suffered a critical failure en route to the [[Moon]] but was brought back safely to Earth through the efforts of the crew and mission control. In addition to being part of the Apollo 13 crew, Lovell was the [[Apollo Command/Service Module|command module]] pilot of [[Apollo 8]], the first Apollo mission to enter lunar orbit. He is one of only [[List of Apollo astronauts#Apollo astronauts who flew to the Moon without landing|24 people to have flown to the Moon]] and the first of only three people to fly to the Moon twice as well as the only one to have flown there twice without making a [[Moon landing|landing]]. Lovell was the first person to fly in space four times. He is a recipient of the [[Congressional Space Medal of Honor]] and the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] (in 1970, one of 17 recipients in the group Space Exploration).{{Cite web|url=https://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/lovell-ja.html|title=Astronaut Bio: James A. Lovell|website=www.jsc.nasa.gov|access-date=2018-04-30}} ==Early life== Born in 1928 in [[Cleveland, Ohio]], James Lovell was the only child of his mother Blanche (Masek), who was of [[Czechs|Czech]] descent, and his father, James, Sr., an [[Ontario]], Canada-born coal furnace salesman, who died in a car accident in 1933.{{Cite web |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=Uh8foEYDQlAC&pg=PA290&lpg=PA290#v=onepage&q=jim%20lovell%20Czech%20mother%20%20blanche |title=Selecting the Mercury Seven: The Search for America's First Astronauts |last=Burgess |first=Colin |website=books.google.ca |access-date=March 18, 2018}} For about two years, Lovell and his mother lived with a relative in [[Terre Haute, Indiana]]. After relocating with his mother to [[Milwaukee|Milwaukee, Wisconsin]], he graduated from [[Solomon Juneau Business High School|Juneau High School]]. A member of the [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scouts]] during his childhood, Lovell eventually achieved [[Eagle Scout rank (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout]], the organization's highest level.{{cite web | title=Collecting the Final Frontier: Ohio Historical Society's Collections Blog | publisher=ohiohistory.org | url=http://ohiohistory.wordpress.com/2011/12/15/collecting-the-final-frontier/ | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331034731/http://ohiohistory.wordpress.com/2011/12/15/collecting-the-final-frontier/ | archivedate=March 31, 2012 | df= }}{{cite web | title=Newsletter Spring 2000: Notable Americans with Czech Roots | publisher=afocr.org | url=http://www.afocr.org/newsletters/spring2000.htm | accessdate=November 29, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080123234750/http://www.afocr.org/newsletters/spring2000.htm |archivedate = January 23, 2008}}{{cite book | last=Townley | first=Alvin | date=December 26, 2006 | title=Legacy of Honor: The Values and Influence of America's Eagle Scouts | publisher=St. Martin's Press|location=New York|pages=80–86|isbn=0-312-36653-1 }}{{cite web | last=Ray | first=Mark |year=2007 | url=http://www.scoutingmagazine.org/issues/0701/a-what.html | title=What It Means to Be an Eagle Scout | work=Scouting Magazine|publisher=Boy Scouts of America | accessdate=January 5, 2007}} Lovell became interested in rocketry and built flying models as a boy.{{cite book | last=Lovell | first=Jim |author2=Kluger, Jeffrey | title=Apollo 13: Lost Moon | location=New York | publisher=Pocket Books | year=1995 | isbn=0-671-53464-5}} After graduating from high school, he attended the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] for two years under the [[Aviation Cadet Training Program (USN)#Aviation Midshipman (AVMIDN) Program (1946–1950)|"Flying Midshipman" program]] from 1946 to 1948. While at Madison, he played football and pledged to the [[Alpha Phi Omega]] fraternity. While Lovell was attending pre-flight training in the summer of 1948, the navy was beginning to make cutbacks in the program, and cadets were under a great deal of pressure to transfer out. There were concerns that some or most of the students who graduated as Naval Aviators would not have pilot billets to fill. This threat persisted until the outbreak of the Korean War in 1950. Lovell applied and was accepted to the [[United States Naval Academy]] in the fall of 1948. During his first year he wrote a treatise on the liquid-fueled rocket engine. He attended Annapolis for the full four years, graduating as an ensign in the spring of 1952 with a B.S. degree. He then went to flight training at [[NAS Pensacola]] from October 1952 to February 1954. [[File:US Navy 090824-N-9876C-013 Retired Navy captain and former astronaut Jim Lovell and his wife, Marilyn Gerlach, sign the final roofing beam to be lifted into place during the topping off ceremony for the Captain James A. Lovell.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Lovell and his wife Marilyn in 2009]] ==Marriage and family== In 1952, following his graduation from the Naval Academy, Lovell married his high school sweetheart, Marilyn Lillie Gerlach (born July 11, 1930), the daughter of Lillie ([[née]] Nordrum) and Carl Gerlach. The two had attended Juneau High School in Milwaukee.[http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1966/02/24/page/50/article/lovells-given-big-reception-in-milwaukee Lovells Big Reception in Milwaukee] accessed July 15, 2015 While she was a college student, Gerlach transferred from [[Wisconsin State College of Milwaukee|Wisconsin State Teachers College]] to [[George Washington University]] in [[Washington D.C.]] so she could be near him while he was training in [[Annapolis]].[https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:K1HN-CM5 Marilyn Lovell public record] accessed July 15, 2015{{Cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=799&dat=19700410&id=EsNOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=I0gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1145,657505 |title=Lovell, Haise married high school sweethearts |website=news.google.com |access-date=March 18, 2018}} The couple have four children: Barbara, James, Susan, and Jeffrey. The 1995 film ''[[Apollo 13 (film)|Apollo 13]]'' portrayed the family's home life during the [[Apollo 13]] mission of 1970 with actress [[Kathleen Quinlan]] being nominated for a [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|supporting actress Oscar]] for her performance as Marilyn Lovell.{{Cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19620918&id=B_8pAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JycEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7197,4432820 |title=Selection of Lovell Puts Kin Into Orbit |website=news.google.com |access-date=March 18, 2018}} In 1999 the Lovell family opened "Lovell's of Lake Forest", a fine dining restaurant in [[Lake Forest, Illinois]]. The restaurant displayed many artifacts from Lovell's time with NASA, as well as from the filming of ''[[Apollo 13 (film)|Apollo 13]]''. The restaurant was sold to son and executive chef James ("Jay") in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.lovellsoflakeforest.com/ |title=Lovells of Lake Forest |publisher=Lovells of Lake Forest |accessdate=June 9, 2013}} The restaurant was put on the market for sale in February 2014{{cite news|first=Linda |last=Blaser |url=http://lakeforest.suntimes.com/news/business/lovells-LFR-02132014:article |title=Lovell family confirms sale of Lake Forest restaurant |newspaper=Lake Forester |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222042230/http://lakeforest.suntimes.com/news/business/lovells-LFR-02132014%3Aarticle |archive-date=February 22, 2014 |date=February 19, 2014 |accessdate=July 30, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and closed in April 2015, with the property auctioned the same month.{{Cite web |url=http://www.lovellsoflakeforest.com/events |title=Lovells of Lake Forest Easter Brunch Sunday, April 5, 2015 |website=lovellsoflakeforest.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429051440/http://www.lovellsoflakeforest.com/events |archive-date=April 29, 2015 |dead-url=yes |access-date=March 18, 2018}} ==United States Navy== Lovell was designated a Naval Aviator on February 1, 1954. Upon completion of pilot training, he was assigned to [[VFAW-3|VC-3]] at [[Moffett Field]] near San Francisco, California. From 1954 to 1956 he flew [[F2H Banshee|F2H-3 Banshee]] night fighters. This included a WestPac deployment aboard the carrier {{USS|Shangri-La|CVA-38|6}}, when the ship emerged from refit as only the second USN carrier with the new angled deck. Upon his return to shore duty, he was reassigned to provide pilot transition training for the [[McDonnell F3H Demon|F3H Demon]].{{cite web|url=http://www.epnaao.com/BIOS_files/REGULARS/Lovell-%20James%20A.pdf|title=The Golden Eagles, Regulars: James A. Lovell jr, Capt USN (Ret)|website=epnaao.com|access-date=March 18, 2018}} In January 1958, Lovell entered a six-month [[test pilot]] training course at what was then the Naval Air Test Center (now the [[United States Naval Test Pilot School|U.S. Naval Test Pilot School]]) at [[Naval Air Station Patuxent River]], [[Maryland]]. Two of his classmates were [[Pete Conrad|Charles (Peter) Conrad]] and [[Wally Schirra]]; Lovell graduated first in his class. Later that year, Lovell, Conrad, and Schirra became three of 110 military test pilots selected as potential [[astronaut]] candidates for [[Project Mercury]]. Schirra went on to become one of the [[Mercury Seven]], with Lovell and Conrad failing to make the cut for medical reasons: Lovell because of a temporarily high [[bilirubin]] count in his blood and Conrad for refusing to take the second round of invasive medical tests. At NAS Patuxent River, Lovell was assigned to Electronics Test (later Weapons Test), with his assigned [[Aviator call sign|call sign]] being "Shaky", a nickname given him by Conrad.{{Cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yuC82VWpa30C&pg=PA15&lpg=PA15#v=onepage&q=lovell%20instructor%20pax%20river |title=James Lovell: The Rescue of Apollo 13 |last=Goldberg |first=Jan |website=books.google.com |access-date=March 18, 2018}} He became [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II|F4H]] program manager, during which time [[John Young (astronaut)|John Young]] served under him. In 1961 he received orders for [[VFA-101|VF-101 "Detachment Alpha"]] as an F4H instructor for the first East Coast squadron personnel assigned to that aircraft.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} ==NASA career== In 1962 NASA needed a second group of astronauts for the [[Project Gemini|Gemini]] and [[Apollo program|Apollo]] programs. Lovell applied a second time and was accepted into [[NASA Astronaut Group 2]], "The New Nine", as was Conrad.{{cite web|url=http://www.americaspace.com/2012/09/15/the-best-all-around-group-nasas-astronauts-of-62/|title="The Best All-Around Group": NASA's Astronauts of '62|last1=Evans|first1=Ben|publisher=AmericaSpace|access-date=February 12, 2018}} ===Gemini program=== [[File:Lovell and Aldrin on Deck - GPN-2000-001356.jpg|thumb|[[Buzz Aldrin]] and Lovell on the deck of their recovery ship after Gemini 12.]] Lovell was selected as backup pilot for [[Gemini 4]]. This put him in position for his first space flight three missions later, as pilot of [[Gemini 7]] with Command Pilot [[Frank Borman]] in December 1965. The flight's objective was to evaluate the effects on the crew and spacecraft from fourteen days in orbit.{{cite web|url=http://www.drewexmachina.com/2015/12/04/rendezvous-in-space-the-launch-of-gemini-7/|title=Rendezvous in Space: The Launch of Gemini 7 {{!}} Drew Ex Machina|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=April 2, 2017}} This fourteen-day flight set an endurance record making 206 orbits. It was also the target vehicle for the first [[space rendezvous]] with [[Gemini 6A]].{{cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/masterCatalog.do?sc=1965-100A|title=Gemini 7, NSSDCA/COSPAR ID: 1965-100A|access-date=May 28, 2017|publisher=NASA}} Lovell was later scheduled to be the backup command pilot of [[Gemini 10]]. But after the [[1966 NASA T-38 crash|deaths of the Gemini 9 prime crew]] [[Elliot See]] and [[Charles Bassett]], he replaced [[Thomas P. Stafford]] as backup commander of [[Gemini 9A]]. This again positioned Lovell for his second flight and first command, of [[Gemini 12]] in November 1966 with Pilot [[Buzz Aldrin]]. This flight had three [[Extravehicular activity|extravehicular activities]], made 59 [[orbit]]s, and achieved the fifth space rendezvous and fourth [[Docking and berthing of spacecraft|space docking]] with an [[Agena target vehicle]]. This mission was successful because it proved that humans can work effectively outside the spacecraft, paved the way for the [[Apollo program|Apollo]] missions, and helped reach the goal of getting man on the Moon by the end of the decade.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} ===Apollo program=== ====Apollo 8==== [[File:Apollo 8 Lovell at Guidance and Navigation station.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Lovell at the Command Module Guidance and Navigation station during the Apollo 8 mission.]] {{Main|Apollo 8}} Lovell was originally chosen as [[Apollo Command/Service Module|Command Module]] pilot (CMP) on the backup crew for Apollo 9 along with [[Neil Armstrong]] as commander and Buzz Aldrin as [[lunar module]] pilot (LMP). Apollo 9 was planned as a high-[[apogee]] Earth orbital test of the Lunar Module (LM). Lovell later replaced [[Michael Collins (astronaut)|Michael Collins]] as CMP on the Apollo 9 prime crew when Collins needed to have surgery for a [[bone spur]] on his spine. This reunited Lovell with his Gemini 7 commander Frank Borman, and LM pilot [[William Anders]].{{Cite web |url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4205/ch11-3.html |title=Selecting and Training Crews |website=history.nasa.gov |access-date=March 18, 2018}} Construction delays of the first manned LM prevented it from being ready in time to fly on Apollo 8, planned as a [[low Earth orbit]] test. It was decided to swap the Apollo 8 and [[Apollo 9]] prime and backup crews in the flight schedule so that the crew trained for the low-orbit test could fly it as Apollo 9, when the LM would be ready. A lunar orbital flight, now Apollo 8 replaced the original Apollo 9 medium Earth orbit test. Borman, Lovell and Anders were launched on December 21, 1968, becoming the first men to travel to the [[Moon]].{{cite book |last1=Ertel |first1=Ivan D. |last2=Newkirk |first2=Roland W. |last3=Brooks |first3=Courtney G. |title=The Apollo Spacecraft: A Chronology |url=http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4009/contents.htm#Volume%20IV |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080205020128/http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4009/contents.htm |archivedate=February 5, 2008 |accessdate=January 29, 2008 |volume=IV |year=1969–1978 |publisher=NASA |location=Washington, D.C. |id=NASA SP-4009 |oclc=23818 |lccn=69060008 |chapter=Part 2 (N): Recovery, Spacecraft Redefinition, and First Manned Apollo Flight: August through September 1968 |chapterurl=http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4009/v4p2n.htm |display-authors=2 |deadurl=no}} As CM Pilot, Lovell served as the navigator, using the spacecraft's built-in [[sextant]] to determine its position by measuring star positions. This information was then used to calculate required mid-course corrections. The craft entered lunar orbit on Christmas Eve and made a total of ten orbits, most of them circular at an altitude of approximately {{convert|70|mi|km}} for a total of twenty hours. They broadcast black-and-white television pictures of the lunar surface back to Earth. Lovell took his turn with Borman and Anders in reading a passage from the Biblical creation story in the [[Apollo 8 Genesis reading|Book of Genesis]].{{cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/lunar/apollo8_xmas.html|title=The Apollo 8 Christmas Eve Broadcast|publisher=NASA|access-date=December 29, 2017}} They began their return to Earth on Christmas Day with a rocket burn made on the Moon's far side, out of radio contact with Earth. (For this reason, the lunar orbit insertion and trans-Earth injection burns were the two most tense moments of this first lunar mission.) When contact was re-established, Lovell was the first to announce the good news, "Please be informed, there is a [[Santa Claus]]." The crew splashed down safely on Earth on December 27.{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/topics/history/features/apollo_8.html|title=Apollo 8: Christmas at the Moon|date=December 18, 2014|publisher=NASA|access-date=December 29, 2017}} ====Apollo 13==== [[File:Jim Lovell at LC-39.png|thumb|left|Lovell in front of the launch pad before the Apollo 13 mission]] [[File:Jim Lovell newspaper.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Lovell reads a newspaper account of Apollo 13's safe return aboard recovery vessel [[USS Iwo Jima (LPH-2)|USS ''Iwo Jima'']].]] {{Main|Apollo 13}} Lovell was backup commander of [[Apollo 11]] and was scheduled to command [[Apollo 14]]. Instead, he and his crew swapped missions with the crew of Apollo 13, as it was felt the commander of the other crew, [[Alan Shepard]], needed more time to train after having been grounded for a long period by an ear problem.{{Cite book |title=Deke! U.S. Manned Space: From Mercury to the Shuttle |last1=Slayton |first1=Donald K. "Deke" |authorlink1=Deke Slayton |last2=Cassutt |first2=Michael |authorlink2=Michael Cassutt |year=1994 |edition=1st |publisher=[[Tor Books|Forge]] |location=New York |isbn=0-312-85503-6 |page=236}} Lovell lifted off aboard Apollo 13 on April 11, 1970, with CM Pilot [[Jack Swigert]] and LM Pilot [[Fred Haise]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/apollo/missions/apollo13.html|title=Apollo 13|date=July 8, 2009|publisher=NASA|access-date=December 29, 2017}} He and Haise were to land on the Moon.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/apr/16/apollo-13-mission-control-unsung-heroes-jim-lovell-interview|title=Apollo 13: celebrating the unsung heroes of mission control|publisher=The Guardian|access-date=December 29, 2017|last1=McKie|first1=Robin|date=April 16, 2017}} During a routine [[liquid oxygen|cryogenic oxygen]] tank stir in transit to the Moon, a fire started inside an oxygen tank. The most probable cause determined by NASA was damaged electrical insulation on wiring that created a spark that started the fire.{{Citation |last=Cortright |first=Edgar M. |title=Report of the Apollo 13 Review Board |date=June 15, 1970 |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19700076776_1970076776.pdf |publisher=NASA |location=Washington, D.C. |format=PDF }} Text (.TXT) file of report [http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/lunar/apollo_13_review_board.txt here]. Multi-part PDF files of the report are available [https://history.nasa.gov/ap13rb/ap13index.htm here] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606113947/http://history.nasa.gov/ap13rb/ap13index.htm |date=June 6, 2013}} and [http://drushel.cwru.edu/apollo13/ here] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130518094130/http://drushel.cwru.edu/apollo13/ |date=May 18, 2013 }}. Liquid oxygen rapidly turned into a high-pressure gas, which burst the tank and caused the leak of a second oxygen tank. In just over two hours, all on-board oxygen was lost, disabling the hydrogen [[fuel cell]]s that provided electrical power to the [[Apollo Command/Service Module|Command/Service Module]] ''Odyssey''. This required an immediate abort of the Moon landing mission; the sole objective now was to safely return the crew to Earth. Apollo 13 was the second mission not to use a [[free return trajectory]], so that they could explore the western lunar regions.{{sfn|Chaikin|2008|p=298}} Using the LM as a "life boat" providing battery power, oxygen, and propulsion, Lovell and his crew re-established the free return trajectory that they had left, and swung around the Moon to return home.{{sfn|Chaikin|2008|pp=304–305}} Based on the flight controllers' calculations made on Earth, Lovell had to adjust the course twice by manually controlling the Lunar Module's thrusters and engine.{{sfn|Chaikin|2008|pp=314, 322}} Apollo 13 returned safely to Earth on April 17.{{sfn|Chaikin|2008|p=611}} Lovell is one of only three men to travel to the Moon twice, but unlike [[John Young (astronaut)|John Young]] and [[Eugene Cernan]], he never walked on it. He accrued over 715 hours, and had seen a total of 269 sunrises from space, on his Gemini and Apollo flights. This was a personal record that stood until the [[Skylab 3]] mission in July through September 1973.The Skylab 3 crew spent 1427 hours in space, in addition to commander [[Alan Bean]]'s over 244 hours on [[Apollo 12]], giving him the second record. Apollo 13's flight trajectory gives Lovell, Haise, and Swigert the record for the farthest distance that humans have ever traveled from Earth.{{cite web | url=http://www.adlerplanetarium.org/pressroom/lovell/lovell_timeline.pdf | title=Captain James A. Lovell Jr. Timeline | accessdate=2007-10-04 | author=Salgado, José Francisco | date=June 30, 2006 | format=PDF | publisher=Adler Planetarium & Astronomy Museum |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071127022319/http://www.adlerplanetarium.org/pressroom/lovell/lovell_timeline.pdf |archivedate = November 27, 2007}}{{Cite book |editor-last=Glenday |editor-first=Craig |editor-link=Craig Glenday |title=Guinness World Records 2010 |year=2010 |publisher=[[Bantam Books]] |location=New York |isbn=0-553-59337-4 |page=13}}{{cite web|url=https://www.space.com/11337-human-spaceflight-records-50th-anniversary.html|title=The Most Extreme Human Spaceflight Records|publisher=Space.com|last1=Wall|first1=Mike|date=April 5, 2016}} ==Later career== [[File:Jim_Lovell.jpg|thumb|right|Lovell speaking at the [[North Carolina Science Festival]] in April 2017]] Lovell retired from the Navy and the space program in 1973 and went to work at the Bay-Houston Towing Company in [[Houston, Texas]], becoming [[CEO]] in 1975. He became president of Fisk Telephone Systems in 1977, and later worked for [[Centel]], retiring as an executive vice president on January 1, 1991. Lovell, a recipient of the [[Distinguished Eagle Scout Award]],{{cite web |url = http://www.scouting.org/filestore/pdf/02-529.pdf |title = Distinguished Eagle Scouts |publisher = Scouting.org|accessdate = November 4, 2010}} later served as the President of the [[National Eagle Scout Association]] in the mid-1990s. He was also recognized by the [[Boy Scouts of America]] with their prestigious [[Silver Buffalo Award]].{{cite web|url=http://www.buckeyecouncil.org/Scouting/Awards/Service/Silver-Buffalo-Award|title=Silver Buffalo Award|publisher=Boy Scouts of America: Buckeye Council|access-date=December 26, 2017}} Along with [[Jeffrey Kluger]], Lovell wrote a book about the Apollo 13 mission, ''[[Lost Moon|Lost Moon: The Perilous Voyage of Apollo 13]]''. It was the basis for the [[Ron Howard]] movie ''Apollo 13''. Lovell's first impression on being approached about the film was that [[Kevin Costner]] would be a good choice to portray him, given the physical resemblance,{{cite video | title = Apollo 13: 2-Disc Anniversary Edition (Disc 1), Special Features:Commentary track by Jim and Marilyn Lovell | medium = DVD | publisher = [[Universal Studios]] | date=March 19, 2005}} but [[Tom Hanks]] was cast in the role. In order to prepare, Hanks visited Lovell and his wife at their home in Texas and even flew with Lovell in his private airplane. In the film, Lovell has a cameo as the captain of the [[USS Iwo Jima (LPH-2)|USS ''Iwo Jima'']], the naval vessel that led the operation to recover the Apollo 13 astronauts after their successful [[splashdown]]. Lovell can be seen as the naval officer shaking Hanks' hand, as Hanks speaks in [[voice-over]], in the scene where the astronauts come aboard the ''Iwo Jima''. Filmmakers initially offered to make Lovell's character an admiral aboard the ship (presumably Rear Admiral [[Donald C. Davis]], Commander Task Force 130 (CTF 130), who was the senior officer aboard and welcomed them home). However, Lovell said "I retired as a Captain and a Captain I will be." He was cast as the ship's skipper, Captain Leland E. Kirkemo.{{cite web|url=http://grin.hq.nasa.gov/ABSTRACTS/GPN-2000-001318.html |title=NASA photographic archive |publisher=Grin.hq.nasa.gov |accessdate=June 9, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130306040121/http://grin.hq.nasa.gov/ABSTRACTS/GPN-2000-001318.html |archivedate=March 6, 2013 |df= }} Along with his wife Marilyn, who also has a cameo in the film, he provided a commentary track on both the single disc and the two-disc special edition DVD.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0112384/fullcredits|title=Apollo 13 Full Cast and Crew|publisher=IMDb|access-date=December 29, 2017}} He has served on the Board of Directors for several organizations, including [[Federal Signal Corporation]] in Chicago (1984–2003), [[Astronautics Corporation of America]] in his hometown of Milwaukee (1990–1999), and [[Centel|Centel Corporation]] in Chicago (1987–1991).{{cite web |url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/lovell-ja.html |title=Astronaut Bio: James A. Lovell |accessdate=December 16, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://astronautics.com/company/about/history/astronautics-timeline/ |title=Astronautics Timeline |accessdate=December 16, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/federal-signal-corporation-announces-board-of-director-changes-election-of-robert-m-gerrity-and-robert-s-hamada-retirement-of-james-a-lovell-jr-72578342.html |title=Federal Signal Corporation Announces Board of Director Changes: Election of Robert M. Gerrity and Robert S. Hamada; Retirement of James A. Lovell Jr. |accessdate=December 16, 2016}}{{cite news |author= |title= J. Peter Morris was named chairman, Edmond V. Russ was... |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1987-05-18/business/8702060768_1_central-operations-centel-corp-president |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |location= |date=1987-05-18 |access-date=December 16, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautix.com/l/lovell.html |title=Lovell |accessdate=December 16, 2016}} Lovell also visits colleges and universities where he gives speeches on his experiences as an astronaut and businessman. He strongly urges students to get involved in science and the space program, and he credits NASA in the 1960s with bringing much of the country together for a common goal.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} ==Tributes== A small crater on the [[far side of the Moon]] is named ''[[Lovell (crater)|Lovell]]'' in his honor.{{cite web|url=http://www.servinghistory.com/topics/Lovell_%28crater%29 |title=Lovell (crater) : Who, What, Where, When |publisher=Servinghistory.com |accessdate=December 3, 2012}} ''North James Lovell Street'' is the stretch of 7th Street between W. State Street and W. Clybourn Street in downtown [[Milwaukee|Milwaukee, Wisconsin]].{{cite web|url=https://maps.google.com/maps?q=north%20james%20lovell%20street&oe=utf-8&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&um=1&ie=UTF-8&sa=N&tab=wl |title=north james lovell street – Google Maps |publisher=Maps.google.com |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=June 9, 2013}} [[Discovery World]] in Milwaukee was also named ''The James Lovell Museum of Science, Economics and Technology''. It was located on James Lovell St., also named for Lovell.{{cite book |last=Hintz |first=Martin|title=Wisconsin Portraits: 55 People who Made a Difference |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n8ZjA8PWogUC&pg=PA91 |accessdate=August 27, 2013 |year=2000 |publisher=Big Earth Publishing |isbn=9780915024803 |oclc=44508414 |page=91 |quote=Discovery World, next to the Milwaukee Public Museum, is also named the James Lovell Museum of Science, Economics and Technology. The former astronaut attended the ribbon-cutting ceremony in 1996. At the same time, Milwaukee's 7th Street outside the museum was renamed James Lovell Street.}} The ''[[Captain James A. Lovell Federal Health Care Center]]'' was completed in October 2010, merging the [[Naval Station Great Lakes|Naval Health Clinic Great Lakes]] and the North Chicago Veterans Affairs Medical Center.{{cite web|author=Captain James A. Lovell Federal Health Care Center, North Chicago, Illinois |url=http://www.lovell.fhcc.va.gov/ |title=Lovell Federal Health Care Center |publisher=Lovell.fhcc.va.gov |accessdate=June 9, 2013}} Lovell Court is a street in the [[North Harbour, New Zealand|North Harbour]] Industrial Estate on the north shore of [[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]]. Several streets in the area have names whose origins honor the US Apollo and [[Space Shuttle program]]s, including [[Neil Armstrong|Armstrong Drive]], [[Space Shuttle Columbia|Columbia Place]], [[John Glenn|John Glenn Avenue]], and [[Sally Ride|Ride Way]].{{cite web |url=http://www.roaddir.net/NZ/Auckland/Upper-Harbour/Cities/North-Harbour-Industrial-Estate/ |title=North Harbour Industrial Estate in Upper Harbour – Auckland |accessdate=2017-01-17}} ==Formal education== Lovell's formal education consisted of the following:{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/04/05/us/james-lovell-fast-facts/index.html|title=James Lovell Fast Facts|last=Library|first=C. N. [[National Eagle Scout Association|National Eagle Scouts Association]] ==In popular culture== About a month after the return to Earth of Apollo 13, Lovell and his crewmates, Fred Haise and Jack Swigert, appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' with host [[Johnny Carson]]. The introduction of this segment of the show is featured on ''Lost Moon: The Triumph of Apollo 13'' on the single disc DVD version of the movie. In 1976, Lovell made a cameo appearance in the Nicolas Roeg movie ''[[The Man Who Fell to Earth (film)|The Man Who Fell to Earth]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0074851/fullcredits|title=The Man Who Fell to Earth: Full Cast and Crew|publisher=IMDb|access-date=December 26, 2017}} In 1995, actor [[Tom Hanks]] portrayed Lovell in the hit movie ''Apollo 13'', based on Lovell's book ''Lost Moon''.{{cite web|url=https://www.space.com/20320-astronaut-jim-lovell-apollo-13-biography.html|title=Astronaut Jim Lovell: Apollo 13 Commander|last1=Howell|first1=Elizabeth|publisher=Space.com|date=March 20, 2013|access-date=December 26, 2017}} Lovell himself makes a cameo in this movie, playing the captain of the USS ''Iwo Jima'' at the end of the film. In 1998, actor [[Tim Daly]] portrayed Lovell in portions of the [[HBO]] miniseries ''[[From the Earth to the Moon (miniseries)|From the Earth to the Moon]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/03/movies/television-review-boyish-eyes-on-the-moon.html|title=Television Review; Boyish Eyes on the Moon|work=The New York Times|date=April 3, 1998|access-date=August 5, 2018|last1=James|first1=Caryn}} The film depicts Lovell during his missions aboard Gemini 12, Apollo 8, and Apollo 13, though he is not seen on screen during the latter mission. Lovell is one of the astronauts featured in the book and documentaries ''[[In the Shadow of the Moon (film)|In the Shadow of the Moon]]'' and ''[[When We Left Earth]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1233514/fullcredits|title=When We Left Earth: Full Cast and Crew|publisher=IMDb|access-date=December 26, 2017}} On November 13, 2008, Lovell and fellow Apollo 8 crew members Frank Borman and [[Bill Anders]] appeared on the [[NASA TV]] channel to discuss the Apollo 8 mission. The three former astronauts later appeared together for a panel discussion centering on Apollo 8 at the [[Lyndon Baines Johnson Library]] on April 23, 2009, a discussion that was videotaped by [[C-SPAN]].{{cite web|url=http://www.c-spanvideo.org/jameslovell |title=C-SPAN Apollo 8 Reunion |publisher=C-spanvideo.org |date=April 23, 2009 |accessdate=June 9, 2013}} On July 20, 2014, the 45th anniversary of Apollo 11's landing on the Moon, ''[[CBS Sunday Morning]]'' correspondent [[Lee Cowan]] and his crew did a piece called "Astronaut wives: The other space pioneers" featuring James Lovell and his wife Marilyn. They celebrated their 62nd wedding anniversary in June.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/astronaut-wives-the-other-space-pioneers-2/ |title=Astronaut wives: The other space pioneers|accessdate=July 20, 2014 | work=CBS News|date=July 20, 2014}} In 2018, actor [[Pablo Schreiber]] portrayed Lovell in the film ''[[First Man (film)|First Man]]''.{{cite web | title = First Man | work = | publisher = [[The Internet Movie Database]] | date = 2018 | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1213641/ | accessdate = October 18, 2018 }} {{Portal bar|Spaceflight|United States Navy}} {{About|the UK Member of Parliament|the philosopher and theologian|John Hick}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = John Hick, [[Esquire|Esq]]., JP | image = John Hick (MP) colour.jpg | alt = | caption = May 1861 by [[Francis Grant (artist)|Francis Grant]] [[Royal Academy of Arts|RA]] (1803–1878) | birth_name = | birth_date = 2 July 1815 | birth_place = [[Bolton]], [[Lancashire]], [[England]] | death_date = {{d-da|2 February 1894|2 July 1815}} | death_place = [[Whalley, Lancashire]], England | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = Civil and Mechanical engineer
Politician
Company director }} '''John Hick''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|JP|DL|MP|FRSA}} (2 July 1815 – 2 February 1894) was a wealthy English [[industrialist]], [[art collector]] and [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] politician who sat in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] from 1868 to 1880.{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=John Hick|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg04.htm#73|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher= dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}} He is associated with the improvement of [[steam-engine]]s for [[cotton mill]]s and the work of his firm Hick, Hargreaves and Co. universal in countries where [[fibre]] was [[Spinning (textiles)|spun]] or [[fabrics]] [[Power loom|woven]]. ==Family== Hick was the eldest son of [[Benjamin Hick]] (1790–1842), a civil and mechanical engineer{{cite web|last=Unknown|title=OBITUARY. BENJAMIN HICK, BORN 1790|url=http://www.icevirtuallibrary.com/doi/pdf/10.1680/imotp.1843.24570|work=Minutes of the Proceedings |volume=2 |issue=1843|pages=12|date=1 January 1843 |issn=1753-7843 |publisher=Institution of Civil Engineers|accessdate=14 December 2012|doi=10.1680/imotp.1843.24570}} responsible for improvements to the steam-engine, and his wife Elizabeth Routledge (1783–1826), daughter of William Routledge of [[Elvington, City of York|Elvington]] Yorkshire. Elizabeth's brother and Hick's uncle, [[Joshua Routledge]] (1773–1829) also an engineer living in [[Bolton]], designed the ''Engineer's Improved [[Slide Rule]]'' and [[patented]] improvements to the Rotary Steam Engine.{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Benjamin Hick|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg03.htm#72|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher=dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=William Routledge|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg03.htm#56|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher= dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Joshua Routledge|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg02.htm#50|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher=dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite journal|last1=Routledge|first1=Joshua|title=Improvement or Improvements upon the Rotary Steam Engine|journal=Repertory of Arts, Manufactures, and Agriculture |date=August 1818|volume=XXXIII – Second Series |pages=129–133|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dO80AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=joshua+routledge+rotary+steam+engine#v=onepage&q=joshua%20routledge%20rotary%20steam%20engine&f=false|accessdate=26 November 2015|publisher=G. and T. Wilkie|location=[[University of Michigan]], USA }} ==Education and early career== Educated at a [[private school]] near [[Alderley, Cheshire|Alderley]], Cheshire and [[Bolton School|Bolton Grammar School]]{{cite news|title=HICK(Bolton)|issue=26299|publisher=The Times|date=4 Dec 1868|page=3}} where he received a commercial and [[Classical education movement|classical education]], Hick entered Benjamin Hick's Soho Works from school and from a young age, management of the Bolton engineering firm [[B. Hick and Sons|Benjamin Hick and Son]] with his father. Following Benjamin Hick's death in 1842, Hick became senior partner in the family business, later Hick, Hargreaves, & Co and a member of the [[Institution of Civil Engineers]] in 1845. He was [[Church Warden]] for [[James Slade]],{{cite book|last1=Hardman|first1=Malcolm|title=Classic Soil: Community, Aspiration, and Debate in the Bolton Region of Lancashire, 1819-1845|date=2003|publisher=Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press|isbn=9780838639665|page=311|edition=illustrated|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dx6gXAU-bc0C&pg=PA311&lpg=PA311&dq=john+hick+church+warden+slade#v=onepage&q=john%20hick%20church%20warden%20slade&f=false|accessdate=4 December 2015|ref=15 |chapter=NOTES TO CHAPTERS 14 AND 15}} [[School governor|Governor of]] [[Grammar School|Bolton Grammar School]], [[Town councillor]] for nine years from 1844, a member of the [[Royal Society of Arts|Society of Arts]], founder member of the [[Institution of Mechanical Engineers]] from 1847 until 1852, member of the London Association of [[Shop foreman|Foreman]] Engineers and [[Draughtsman]],{{cite news|title=FOREMEN ENGINEERS AND DRAUGHTSMEN |issue=28263|publisher=The Times|date=15 March 1875|page=10}} [[National Society for Promoting Religious Education|National Society for Promoting the Education of the Poor in the Principles of the Established Church in England and Wales]],{{cite journal|journal=Thirtieth Annual Report of the NATIONAL SOCIETY FOR PROMOTING FOR PROMOTING THE EDUCATION OF THE POOR IN the Principles of the Established Church THROUGHOUT ENGLAND AND WALES | title=Thirtieth Annual Report |date=1841|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_LYEAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=26 November 2015|location=Oxford University}} Justice of the Peace for the [[County Borough of Bolton|Borough of Bolton]] and [[Salford (hundred)|Salford Hundred]], liberal [[patron]] of the [[fine arts]][https://archive.org/stream/debrettshouseo1870londuoft#page/142/mode/2up Debretts House of Commons and the Judicial Bench 1870] and a director of the [[London and North Western Railway]] under the chairmanship of [[Richard Moon (1814–1899)|Sir Richard Moon]] and [[Richard Grosvenor, 1st Baron Stalbridge|Lord Stalbridge]], from 1871 until his death.{{cite magazine|last1=Dunn|first1=J.M. |title=F.W. Webb, Crewe |magazine=Railway Magazine|date=1961|volume=107|pages=756–762, 840–844|url=http://www.steamindex.com/people/webb.htm|accessdate=1 December 2015}} In 1839 (age 23) while working for B. Hick and Son, John Hick Jr as he was referred to at the time, was awarded the Silver Medal by the [[Royal Society of Arts|Society of Arts]] for his novel invention of an expanding [[mandrel]] for turning [[lathes]], it was an adaptation of a principle developed by [[Marc Brunel]] for [[pully]] [[Block (sailing)|block]] manufacture at [[Portsmouth Block Mills|Portsmouth]] and received the praise of three eminent engineers; [[Bryan Donkin]], [[Joshua Field (engineer)|Joshua Field]] and [[John Rennie the Younger|John Rennie]].{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=No. XI. EXPANDING MANDREL|journal=Transactions of the Society, Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce|date=1 January 1839|volume=LIII|pages=87–92|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-41326867/41326867#page/n1/mode/2up|accessdate=13 November 2015|location=JSTOR}} During 1842 Hick was awarded a second silver medal by the Society of Arts for his invention of an [[Elliptograph]]; conceived in 1840,{{cite web|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=Elliptograph devised in 1840 by John Hick of Bolton|url=https://collection.sciencemuseum.org.uk/objects/co60100/elliptograph-devised-in-1840-by-john-hick-of-bolto-curve-drawing-instruments-ellipsographs|website=Science Museum Group|accessdate=10 November 2016|date=1840}} the device provided a simple and accurate solution for the drawing ''[[ellipse|ellipsoid forms]]'' of various proportions. Hick received further praise from [[James Nasmyth]], [[William Fairbairn]], [[Joseph Whitworth]], and amongst others, [[Charles Holtzapffel]], Chairman of the Committee of Mechanics. Models of both devices were placed in the Society's repository.{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=NO. II. ELLIPTOGRAPH|journal=Transactions of the Society, Instituted at London, for the Encouragement of Arts, Manufactures, and Commerce|date=1 January 1843|volume=LIV|pages=8–13|url=https://archive.org/stream/jstor-41326879/41326879#page/n1/mode/2up|accessdate=13 November 2015|location=JSTOR}} Hick contributed a paper to the Institute of Mechanical Engineers in 1849 on a friction [[clutch]] ''for connecting and disconnecting the driving power with shafts and machinery''. A B. Hick and Son, 1:12 [[Scale (ratio)|scale]] [[patent model]] of ''disconnecting apparatus, for [[screw propeller]]s'', c. 1855 is held in the [[Science Museum, London|Science Museum]] [[Marine propulsion|marine engines]] collection.{{cite web|last1=B. Hick & Son|title=Model of disconnecting apparatus, for screw propellers.|url=http://collectionsonline.nmsi.ac.uk/detail.php?type=related&kv=39375&t=objects|website=Science Museum Group|accessdate=11 November 2016|date=c. 1855}} ==Marriage== John Hick married Margaret Bashall (1824–1872), eldest daughter of [[industrialist]] William Bashall, partner in [[Bashall & Boardman]] of [[Farington]] Lodge, near [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]] on 24 June 1846,{{cite book|last=Lewis|first=Brian|title=The Middlemost and the Milltowns: Bourgeois Culture and Politics in Early Industrial England|year=2001|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-4174-3 |page=361|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3vqbJLHsbIMC&pg=PA361&lpg=PA361&dq=Benjamin+Hick+patron#v=onepage&q=Benjamin%20Hick%20patron&f=false}}{{cite web|title=The Victorians: The Directory of the Cotton Mills of South Ribble |url=https://south-ribble.co.uk/srmuseum/pages/schools/05_directory_of_mills.pdf |website=South Ribble Primary Schools Local History Project |publisher=[[South Ribble Museum & Exhibition Centre]] |accessdate=1 December 2015 |page=5 }} they raised four daughters. Following Margaret Hick's death in 1872,{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Margaret Bashall|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg04.htm#73|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher=dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}} Hick married the sister of his son-in-law, Rebecca Maria Ashworth (1838–1908), eldest daughter of [[Edmund Ashworth]] [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|JP]] (1800–1881) of [[Egerton, Greater Manchester|Egerton]] Hall on 16 December 1874 at [[Clapham Sect|Holy Trinity Church]], [[Clapham]]; the couple were married by Margaret Hick's cousin and brother-in-law [[Reverend]] William Bashall (1830–1902), Vicar of [[St Mary the Virgin's Church, Deane|Deane]], Lancashire, by special licence from the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Archibald Tait]].{{cite web|title=Marriage Registration|website=Ancestry.com|page=183|date=16 December 1874}} Edmund Ashworth was a cotton manufacturer, proprietor of E. Ashworth & Sons and Egerton Mill, founder member of the [[Anti-Corn Law League]] with his brother [[Henry Ashworth (nonconformist)|Henry Ashworth]] (1794–1880){{cite web|title=A history of the Ashworth family|url=http://egertonvillage.medianewsonline.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=7|work=Egerton Village Online – Bolton Lancashire|accessdate=29 December 2012}} JP, in association with [[John Bright]] and [[Richard Cobden]] (Henry Ashworth's brother-in-law), and supporter of reforming, [[abolitionism in the United Kingdom|anti-slavery]] and peace organisations.{{cite web|title=Edmund Ashworth|url=http://www.boltonsmayors.org.uk/ashworth-e.html|website=Links in a Chain – the Mayors of Bolton|publisher=Bolton Council|accessdate=11 November 2015}} The Ashworths are both thought to have been Oswald Millbank in [[Benjamin Disraeli]]'s novel [[Coningsby (novel)|''Coningsby'']].{{cite book|last1=Axon|first1=William Edward Armytage|title=THE ANNALS OF MANCHESTER, A CHRONOLOGICAL RECORD FROM THE EARLIEST TIMES TO THE END OF 1885|date=1886|publisher=John Heywood, Deansgate and Ridgefield|page=380|url=https://archive.org/stream/annalsmancheste00axongoog#page/n404/mode/1up/search/edmund+ashworth|accessdate=11 November 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Grindon|first1=Leo Hartley|title=LANCASHIRE, HISTORICAL & PICTORIAL NOTES|date=1892|publisher=SEELY & CO., LIMITED|url=http://www.mirrorservice.org/sites/gutenberg.org/4/0/5/8/40584/40584-h/40584-h.htm#FNanchor_22_22|chapter=Footnotes [22]}}{{cite book|last1=Musson|first1=A. E. |title=Enterprise in Soap and Chemicals: Joseph Crosfield & Sons, Limited 1815–1965|date=1965|publisher=[[Manchester University Press]] |page=133|url=https://books.google.com/?id=TsG8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA133&lpg=PA133&dq=henry+ashworth+oswald+millbank#v=onepage&q=henry%20ashworth%20oswald%20millbank&f=false|accessdate=11 November 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Eccleshall|first1=Robert|title=English Conservatism Since the Restoration: An Introduction and Anthology|date=11 Sep 2002|publisher=Routledge|url=https://books.google.com/?id=K-GKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT305&lpg=PT305&dq=Henry+Ashworth+Disraeli#v=onepage&q=Henry%20Ashworth%20Disraeli&f=false|accessdate=11 November 2015|chapter=Sir Rhodes Boyson (1925-)|isbn=9781134997749}}{{cite book|last1=Roberts|first1=F. David|title=The Social Conscience of the Early Victorians|date=2002|publisher=Stanford University Press, Stanford, California|isbn=0-8047-4532-3|page=68|url=http://graduateinstitute.ch/files/live/sites/iheid/files/sites/mia/shared/mia/cours/IA023/Week%204/Roberts_The_Social_Conscience_of_the_Early_Victorians.pdf|accessdate=11 November 2015}} The two families (Hick and Ashworth) were linked by marriage in 1868 when Hick's first child and eldest daughter Margaret (1847–1929) married Edmund Ashworth Jr (1833–1901).{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Margaret Elizabeth Hick|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg21.htm#92|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher= dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=Edmund Ashworth Jnr|url=http://www.boltonsmayors.org.uk/ashworth-e-2.html|website=Links in a Chain – the Mayors of Bolton|publisher=Bolton Council|accessdate=18 November 2015|date=2015}} The "highly respected" Reverend Bashall retired to the position of [[curate]] at [[St Barnabas's, Kensington|St Barnabas church]], [[Addison Road, London|Addison Road]], [[Kensington]] from about 1876{{cite book|last1=Bishop M.A. |first1=Rev. Kenneth M. |title=Dean Church|date=1952|url=http://www.deanechurch.co.uk/Library/Guides/1952.pdf|page=38|accessdate=18 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=Census|website=Ancestry.com|ref=R.G. 11 28|location=Public Record Office|page=4|date=1881}}{{cite book|editor1-last=Farrer |editor2-last=Bronbill |editor1-first=William | editor2-first=J. |title=THE VICTORIA HISTORY OF THE COUNTY OF LANCASTER|date=1911|publisher=LONDON CONSTABLE AND COMPANY LIMITED|pages=4–5|url=https://archive.org/stream/victoriahistoryo05farruoft#page/4/mode/2up/search/curate+of+st+barnabas's|accessdate=2 December 2015|chapter=TOPOGRAPHY, THE HUNDRED OF SALFORD, DEAN}} remaining in the area until his death, 1902.{{cite web|title=Census|website=Ancestry.com|ref=R.G. 13/22|location=Public Record Office|page=18|date=1901}}{{cite web|last1=Crangle|first1=Richard|title=Person record: BASHALL, Reverend W.
