Machines for Direct Use, Including [[Carriage]]s, Railway and Marine Mechanism.''{{cite book|title=Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of all Nations, 1851. OFFICIAL DESCRIPTIVE AND ILLUSTRATED CATALOGUE. Vol I. SECTION II. CLASSES 5 TO 10|date=1851|page=45|url=https://archive.org/stream/b21495361_0001#page/n245/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=21 November 2015|chapter=LIST OF JURORS }}{{cite journal| title=REPORT OF VISCOUNT CANNING, PRESIDENT OF THE COUNCIL OF CHAIRMEN OF JURIES, ON PRESENTING THE AWARDS OF THE JURIES TO THE ROYAL COMMISSION |journal=The London Gazette|date=17 October 1851|page=2596|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/21254/page/2596/data.pdf|accessdate=20 November 2015}} Condition 6. of the Exhibition's ''Decisions Regarding Juries'' restricted Jurors from competing for prizes in the Class to which they were appointed; prizes could not be awarded to the individual or the companies the Juror represented.{{cite book|title=Reports by the juries on the subjects in the thirty classes into which the exhibition was divided.|date=1852|publisher=London: : Spicer Brothers, wholesale stationers; : W. Clowes and Sons, printers; contractors to the Royal Commission, Tudor Street, New Bridge Street, Blackfriars.|location=Getty Research Institute|page=iii|url=https://archive.org/stream/reportsbyjurieso00grea#page/n11/mode/2up/search/jurors|accessdate=2 January 2018|chapter=Appendix A: DECISIONS REGARDING JURIES}} In 1855 Hick exhibited two pieces from his collection of art works: ''The [[Stag]] Hunt''{{cite journal|last1=Great Britain. Imperial commission, Paris universal exhibition|journal=Paris universal exhibition, 1855. Catalogue of the works exhibited in the British section of the exhibition, in French and English; together with exhibitors' prospectuses, prices current, &c. |date=1855|page=84|title=FINE ARTS DIVISION |url=https://archive.org/stream/parisuniversale01goog#page/n98/mode/2up/search/hunt|accessdate=13 November 2015|publisher=London, Chapman and Hall|location=University of Michigan}} and ''[[Lady Jane Grey]] and [[Roger Ascham]]'' by [[John Callcott Horsley]] in the Fine Art Division of the [[Exposition Universelle (1855)]] alongside his father-in-law William Bashall who presented ''The [[Madrigal]]'', also by Horsley.{{cite journal|last1=Great Britain. Imperial commission, Paris universal exhibition|journal=Paris universal exhibition, 1855. Catalogue of the works exhibited in the British section of the exhibition, in French and English; together with exhibitors' prospectuses, prices current, &c. |date=1855|page=77|title=FINE ARTS DIVISION |url=https://archive.org/stream/parisuniversale01goog#page/n90/mode/2up/search/Beaux-Arts+|accessdate=13 November 2015|publisher=London, Chapman and Hall|location=University of Michigan}} Hick and Bashall used the same pair again for the 1857 [[Art Treasures Exhibition, Manchester 1857|Art Treasures Exhibition]] in Manchester with ''[[Cupid and Psyche]]'' by [[Benjamin West]] PRA{{cite journal|last1=Peck|first1=John|title=B. WEST P.R.A. |journal=Catalogue of the art treasures of the United Kingdom: collected at Manchester in 1857|date=1857|page=288|url=https://archive.org/stream/catalogueofarttr00artt#page/n287/mode/2up|accessdate=13 November 2015|location=Getty Research Institute}} and ''Crossing the [[stream|Brook]]'' by [[Paul Falconer Poole]].{{cite journal|last1=Peck|first1=John|title=P.F. Poole A.R.A. |journal=Catalogue of the art treasures of the United Kingdom: collected at Manchester in 1857|date=1857|page=352|url=https://archive.org/stream/catalogueofarttr00artt#page/n352/mode/2up|accessdate=13 November 2015|location=Getty Research Institute}} Hick was a force behind the movement that led to the formation of the [[Volunteer Force (Great Britain)|27th Lancashire Rifle Volunteers]] from the [[Bolton]] area, he was offered command, but declined;{{cite book|last1=Scholes|first1=James Christopher|editor1-last=Pemblett|editor1-first=William|title=HISTORY OF BOLTON: WITH MEMORIALS OF THE OLD PARISH CHURCH |date=1892|location=Bolton | publisher=The Daily Chronicle Office |page=451|url=https://archive.org/stream/historyboltonwi00schogoog#page/n198/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=18 November 2015}} The Regiment was formed on 15 November 1859 following tensions between the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] and [[Second French Empire|France]]{{cite web|title=The Lancashire Rifle Volunteers|url=http://www.lancashireinfantrymuseum.org.uk/the-lancashire-rifle-volunteers/|website=The Duke of Lancaster's Regiment, [[Lancashire Infantry Museum]]|accessdate=19 November 2015|date=2015}} and the out break of [[Second Italian War of Independence|war]] between France and the [[Austrian Empire]] during April of the same year.{{cite book|last=Grierson|first=James Moncrieff|title=Records of the Scottish volunteer force, 1859-1908|year=1909|publisher=W Blackwood|location=[[Edinburgh]]|pages=3–11|url=https://archive.org/stream/recordsofscottis00grieuoft#page/2/mode/2up|authorlink=James Grierson}} [[William Gray (Conservative politician)|William Gray MP]] [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|JP]] (1814–1895) and former Mayor of Bolton became [[Lieutenant Colonel]] 1 January 1861;{{cite web|title=Lt Col William Gray|url=http://www.boltonsmayors.org.uk/gray-w.html|website=Links in a Chain – the Mayors of Bolton|publisher=Bolton Council|accessdate=19 November 2015|date=2015}}{{cite journal|title=27th Lancashire Rifle Volunteer Corps|journal=The London Gazette|date=15 January 1861|page=163|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/22471/page/163/data.pdf|accessdate=19 November 2015}} John Hick's nephew Benjamin Hick (1845–1882),{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Benjamin Hick|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg05.htm#90|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher=dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304044001/http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg05.htm#90|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} manager in [[Hick, Hargreaves & Co]],{{cite book|title=P. W. Pilling, ''Hick Hargreaves and Co., The History of an Engineering Firm c. 1833 – 1939, a Study with Special Reference to Technological Change and Markets'' (Unpublished Doctoral Thesis, University of Liverpool, 1985)|pages=121, 451–452}} was made a Captain 16 March 1872,{{cite journal|title=27th Lancashire Rifle Volunteer Corps|journal=The London Gazette|date=29 March 1872|page=1680|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/22471/page/163/data.pdf|accessdate=19 November 2015}} resigning his commission about four years later 23 February 1876.{{cite journal|title=27th Lancashire Rifle Volunteer Corps|journal=The London Gazette|date=22 February 1876|page=816|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/22471/page/163/data.pdf|accessdate=19 November 2015}} ==Bolton Iron and Steel Company== In 1860 partners in [[B. Hick and Sons|B. Hick and Son]], John Hick and William Hargreaves joined Thomas Lever Rushton's brother-in-law Henry Sharp as partners in Sharp and Eckersley, formerly Rushton and Eckersley before Rushton's retirement from the firm in 1859. The three partners Sharp, Hick and Hargreaves formed the Bolton Iron & Steel Company;{{cite web|title=Thomas Lever Rushton|url=http://www.boltonsmayors.org.uk/rushton-t-l.html|work=Links in a Chain – the Mayors of Bolton|publisher=Bolton Council|accessdate=7 May 2015}} situated next door to Rothwell's [[Rothwell, Hick and Rothwell#Rothwell and Company|Union Foundry]] (now [[Bolton bus station]]) the company supplied basic metals required by the major manufacturers in the area.{{cite book|last1=O’Connor|first1=Denis|title=THE RISE OF BOLTON AS AN IMPORTANT ENGINEERING AND TEXTILE TOWN IN EARLY 1800 ENGLAND|page=60|url=http://www.torpedo150rijeka.org/docs/protorpedoEN/documents/14/1.0/Original.pdf}} [[Henry Bessemer|Bessemer]] [[Bessemer process|steel making]] began about 1860{{cite book|last1=Reed|first1=Brian|title=Crewe Locomotive Works and Its Men|date=1982|publisher=David & Charles|isbn=9780715382288|edition=Illustrated|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wzlPAAAAMAAJ&q=Bolton+iron+%26+steel+1860&dq=Bolton+iron+%26+steel+1860}} – four six-ton Bessemer converters were installed during the 1860s,{{cite book|last1=Erickson|first1=Charlotte|title=British Industrialists|date=1959|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=147|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0o2TmT8-544C&pg=PA147&lpg=PA147&dq=bolton+iron+and+steel+company+four+bessemer+converters#v=onepage&q=bolton%20iron%20and%20steel%20company%20four%20bessemer%20converters&f=false|accessdate=11 November 2015|isbn=9780521049405}} and experiments with the [[Carl Wilhelm Siemens|Sieman]]'s [[Siemens-Martin process|open-hearth process]] began in 1867.{{cite book|last1=Erickson|first1=Charlotte|title=British Industrialists|date=1959|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=158|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0o2TmT8-544C&pg=PA158&dq=Siemens+open-hearth+process+in+1867+bolton+iron+and+steel#v=onepage&q=Siemens%20open-hearth%20process%20in%201867%20bolton%20iron%20and%20steel&f=false|accessdate=11 November 2015|isbn=9780521049405}} [[Rolling (metalworking)|Rolling]], [[casting]] and [[forge|forging]] equipment was installed, its products included steel deck [[beam (structure)|beam]]s for ships and [[sheet metal]] for [[shovel]]s,{{cite book|last1=Timmins|first1=Geoffrey|title=Made in Lancashire: A History of Regional Industrialisation|date=1998|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=9780719045394|page=195|url=https://books.google.com/?id=hRANAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA195&lpg=PA195&dq=Made+in+Lancashire:+a+history+of+regional+industrialisation.++bolton+iron+and+steel#v=onepage&q=Made%20in%20Lancashire%3A%20a%20history%20of%20regional%20industrialisation.%20%20bolton%20iron%20and%20steel&f=false|edition=illustrated}} during 1865 Bolton Iron & Steel cast the largest [[anvil]] block made in England, weighing 210 tons. By 1869 the company was making open hearth [[steel]] and manufacturing [[steam hammer]]s to the design of [[Francis Webb (engineer)|Francis Webb]].{{cite web|title=Bolton Iron and Steel Co|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Bolton_Iron_and_Steel_Co|website=Grace's Guide|publisher=Grace's Guide Ltd|accessdate=6 December 2014}} Hick's nephew became a shareholder following incorporation on 9 June 1876.{{cite book|title=P. W. Pilling, ''Hick Hargreaves and Co., The History of an Engineering Firm c. 1833 – 1939, a Study with Special Reference to Technological Change and Markets'' (Unpublished Doctoral Thesis, University of Liverpool, 1985)|pages=152, 158–160, 485, 521}} [[File:Mrs Margaret Hick.jpg|thumb|left|Mrs Margaret Hick by Francis Grant RA, presented at the [[Royal Academy of Arts]], May 1861.]] About 1861 society painter [[Francis Grant (artist)|Francis Grant]] produced portraits of John Hick and his wife Margaret, both works eventually hung together in the family home at [[Little Mitton|Mytton]] Hall.{{cite book|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=CATALOGUE OF THE PRINCIPLE PAINTINGS, DRAWINGS, BOOKS, BRONZES, &C., AT MYTTON HALL, The Residence of John Hick, Esq. |date=1893|publisher=Ede, Dearberg & Co 40 QUEEN STREET CITY}} Hick was an associate of Bolton engineer, artist and photographer Reuben Mitchell (1812–1895), and pursued his own interest in photography,{{cite book|last1=MacLeod|first1=Christine|title=Heroes of Invention: Technology, Liberalism and British Identity, 1750-1914|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521873703|page=260|edition=illustrated|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZhMHZdm4U-QC&pg=PA260&lpg=PA260&dq=sans+pareil+john+hick+1864#v=onepage&q=sans%20pareil%20john%20hick%201864&f=false|accessdate=27 November 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Sims|title=Mitchell, Reuben |url=http://books.simsreed.com/photography/photography.php?category=photography&stk=41861|website=Sims Reed Rare Books|publisher=Sims Reed Rare Books Ltd|accessdate=10 June 2014}} he was also a supporter of the artists [[Copley Fielding]], [[William Powell Frith]], [[Patrick Nasmyth]], [[Samuel Prout]], [[Edward Matthew Ward]] and others; the engineer and artist [[James Nasmyth]] described John Hick as an "excellent friend".{{cite book|last=Nasmyth|first=James|title=James Nasmyth engineer: an autobiography, Edited by Samuel Smiles|year=1883|publisher=John Murray | location=[[Albemarle Street]], London|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/James_Nasmyth_by_James_Nasmyth:_Chronological_List#1848._Application_of_Hydraulic_Power_to_the_Punching_of_Large_Holes_in_Iron_Bars.2C_and_Plates_of_Great_Thickness. }} Hick wrote a history of [[Timothy Hackworth]]'s [[locomotive]] ''[[Sans Pareil]]'' and presented the restored engine to the [[Intellectual Property Office (United Kingdom)|Patent Office Museum]] (now the [[Science Museum (London)|Science Museum]]) in 1864,{{cite book|last1=Ahrons|first1=Ernest Leopold|title=The British steam railway locomotive, 1825-1925|date=1927|publisher=THE LOCOMOTIVE PUBLISHING COMPANY LIMITED|page=14|url=https://archive.org/stream/britishsteamrail00ahro#page/14/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=27 November 2015}} he also photographed William M. Gowland for [[Bennett Woodcroft]]. Gowland was driver of Hackworth's ''[[Timothy Hackworth#The Royal George|Royal George]]'' and driver of ''Sans Pareil'' at the [[Rainhill Trials]].{{cite web|title=Photograph portrait of William M. Gowland 1850-1864|url=http://collectionsonline.nmsi.ac.uk/detail.php?t=objects&type=all&f=&s=william+gowland&record=0|website=Science Museum Group|accessdate=10 November 2016|date=1864}} ''Sans Pareil'' was previously owned by Hick's brother-in-law and eventual business partner [[John Hargreaves (early railway operator)|John Hargreaves Jr]] (1800–1874) who had the engine fully repaired and running on the [[Bolton and Leigh Railway]] in 1837.{{cite book|last1=SEKON|first1=G. A. | title=Evolution of the Stream Locomotive (1803 to 1898.)|date=1899|publisher=THE RAILWAY PUBLISHING CO., Ltd. | location=79 to 83 Temple Chambers, Temple Avenue, E.C., London |pages=34–35|url=http://www.forgottenbooks.com/readbook_text/The_Evolution_of_the_Steam_Locomotive_1803_1000108809/43|accessdate=27 November 2015}}{{cite web|title=Liverpool & Manchester Railway – Hackworth's "Sans Pareil"|url=http://www.railalbum.co.uk/early-railways/sans-pareil.htm|website=Rail Album|publisher=Parthenon Consultancy Limited|accessdate=27 November 2015|date=2010}} ''Sans Pareil'' is now housed at the [[National Railway Museum]]'s [[Shildon Locomotion Museum]] annexe.{{cite web|last1=Physick|first1=Liam|title=Sans Pareil|url=http://www.edgehillstation.co.uk/resources/sans-pareil/|website=EDGE HILL|publisher=Edge Hill Station|accessdate=27 November 2015|date=2015}}{{cite web|title=Timothy Hackworth – Railway Pioneer 1786–1850|url=http://www.railcentre.co.uk/RailHistory/Hackworth/Pages/HackworthPage2.html|website=Railcentre|publisher=J. Metcalfe|accessdate=27 November 2015|date=2015}} In 1867 Hick first published a paper, reprinted from ''[[The Engineer (magazine)|The Engineer]]'', 1 June 1866, ''Experiments on the Friction of the Leather Collars in [[Hydraulic Press]]es'', that expanded on the work of [[William John Macquorn Rankine|Dr William Rankine]], describing an important series of experiments carried out using a joint invention of Hick and Robert Lüthy (1840–1883),{{cite web|title=Robert Luthy|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Robert_Luthy|website=Grace's Guide|publisher=Institution of Mechanical Engineers|accessdate=22 March 2017|date=1884}} a [[Swiss people|Swiss]] engineer employed by Hick, and inventor of a hydraulic [[cotton]] packing press. Hick's father was the inventor of the self tightening collar, used universally in hydraulic pressess.{{cite journal|title=MR. HICK'S EXPERIMEN'TS ON 'THE FRICTION OF LEATHER COLLARS IN HYDRAULIC CY- LINDERS.|journal=The Engineer|date=1 June 1866|volume=21|pages=393–394|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/images/4/45/Er18660601.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=Experiments on the friction of the leather collars in hydraulic presses.|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Experiments-friction-hydraulic-presses-Conducted/dp/B000XD460E|website=Amazon|accessdate=18 March 2017|date=1867}}{{cite journal|last1=Hick|first1=John|title=EXPERIMENTS ON THE FRICTION COLLARS IN HYDRAULIC PRESSES|journal=Reprinted from ("THE ENGINEER")|date=1884|issue=Second Edition|url=https://archive.org/stream/experimentsonfr00hickgoog#page/n4/mode/2up|accessdate=18 March 2017|publisher=E & F. N. SPON CHARING CROSS.|location=University of Michigan}}{{cite book|title=P. W. Pilling, ''Hick Hargreaves and Co., The History of an Engineering Firm c. 1833 – 1939, a Study with Special Reference to Technological Change and Markets'' (Unpublished Doctoral Thesis, University of Liverpool, 1985)|page=122}} ==Parliament== On [[United Kingdom general election, 1868|17 November 1868]] Hick was elected as Member of Parliament (MP) for [[Bolton (UK Parliament constituency)|Bolton]]. After election and to avoid a [[conflict of interest]], he immediately resigned his position within Hick, Hargreaves and Co., the firm were already in possession of government contracts,{{cite journal| author=Unknown |title=Memoirs |journal=1894 Institution of Mechanical Engineers: Obituaries|date=1894|volume=|pages=161–162|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/1894_Institution_of_Mechanical_Engineers:_Obituaries|accessdate=24 November 2015|issn=}} and withdrew from the Bolton Iron and Steel Company.{{cite book| first=P. W. | last=Pilling | title=Hick Hargreaves and Co., The History of an Engineering Firm c. 1833 – 1939, a Study with Special Reference to Technological Change and Markets | publisher=Unpublished Doctoral Thesis, [[University of Liverpool]] | year=1985 |pages=118–119, 123–125, 158}} Hick [[United Kingdom general election, 1874|held the seat]] until [[United Kingdom general election, 1880|24 March 1880]]{{Rayment-hc|b|4|date=March 2012}} when as a result of ill-health, he chose not to stand for re-election.{{cite book|last=Clegg |first=James |title=ANNALS OF BOLTON, HISTORY, CHRONOLOGY, POLITICS, PARLIAMENTARY AND MUNICIPAL POLLS|date=1888|publisher=The Chronicle Office | location=Knowsley Street, Bolton |agency=Allen County Public Library Genealogy Center|page=184 |url=https://archive.org/stream/annalsofboltonhi00cleg#page/357/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=13 November 2015}} Hick was a [[liberal Conservative]] in favour of education based on religion, a supporter of the general principles of the [[Education Act 1870]] and an adherent to the view that religious and secular education should not be separated. As a Conservative he was a member of the [[Carlton Club|Carlton]], [[Conservative Club|Conservative]] and [[St Stephen's Club|St Stephen's]] Clubs.{{cite book|last1=Walford|first1=Edward|title=The county families of the United Kingdom; or, Royal manual of the titled and untitled aristocracy of England, Wales, Scotland, and Ireland |date=1873| location=Allen County Public Library Genealogy Center | publisher=R. Hardwicke|page=496|url=https://archive.org/stream/countyfamiliesof13walf#page/496/mode/2up|accessdate=1 December 2015}} In May 1870 Hick chaired a [[Select committee (United Kingdom)|Select Committee]] to investigate [[boiler|steam-boiler]] [[Boiler explosions|explosions]]; following the report in August 1870, he introduced a [[Bill (law)|Bill]] "...to provide a more efficient remedy to persons injured and property damaged by the explosion of steam-boilers through [[negligence]]". In April 1871 he seconded a [[motion (democracy)|motion]] by Colonel [[Sir Walter Barttelot, 1st Baronet|Barttelot]] (1820–1893), Conservative MP for [[West Sussex (UK Parliament constituency)|Sussex Western]] 1860–1885, for a Select Committee "...to inquire into the merits of the [[Martini-Henry Rifle]]...whether it is the most suitable rifle as compared with others now manufactured to arm our troops with."{{cite web|title=MOTION FOR A SELECT COMMITTEE |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1871/apr/28/motion-for-a-select-committee#S3V0205P0_18710428_HOC_47|website=HANSARD 1803–2005|accessdate=13 November 2015|date=28 April 1871}} and debated ''Supply – [[British Army|Army]] Estimates'', June 1873 drawing attention to the improvement of [[Artillery|heavy ordnance]].{{cite web|title=SUPPLY—ARMY ESTIMATES |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1873/jun/23/supply-army-estimates#S3V0216P0_18730623_HOC_73|website=HANSARD 1803–2005|accessdate=13 November 2015|date=23 June 1873}} As a parliamentarian he was frequently consulted by Government on subjects relating to [[armaments]] and the construction of boilers for [[War vessel|war-vessels]]. Hick also served on a Select Committee appointed June 1874 to investigate the testing of [[chain|chain cable]] and [[anchors]] for the [[British navy|Navy]], and debated ''[[Classification of railway accidents|Railway accidents]] – the adoption of [[continuous brakes]]'', June 1879.{{cite web|title=RAILWAYS—RAILWAY ACCIDENTS — THE ADOPTION OF CONTINUOUS BRAKES —OBSERVATIONS |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1879/jun/13/railways-railway-accidents-the-adoption#S3V0246P0_18790613_HOC_61|website=HANSARD 1803–2005|accessdate=13 November 2015|date=13 June 1879}} As a director of LNWR, Hick defended the railway's position, stating he "regarded all automatic machinery with distrust".{{cite web|last1=Jones|first1=Kevin|title=Brief Biographies of Major Mechanical Engineers|url=http://www.steamindex.com/people/engrs.htm#surnha|website=STEAMINDEX|accessdate=21 January 2016|date=2015}} He was [[Deputy Lieutenant]] for the [[County Palatine]] from 1870 until death{{cite book|last1=SPIKE|first1=ARCHIBALD|title=BIBLIOGRAPHIA BOLTONIENSIS: being a bibliography, with biographical details of Bolton authors, and the books written by them from 1550 to 1912; books about Bolton; and those printed and published in the town from 1785 to date|date=1913|publisher=MANCHESTER: THE UNIVERSITY PRESS|page=82|url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924029566019#page/n103/mode/2up|accessdate=18 December 2015}} and on taking up residence at Mytton Hall, [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|Justice of the Peace]] for [[Whalley, Lancashire]], he rejoined the [[Institute of Mechanical Engineers]] in 1871, proposed by [[Frederick Bramwell]]{{cite book|title=Membership records|location=Institute of Mechanical Engineers}} and elected a Member of Council in 1872, a Vice-President of the institute from 1874 to 1876. [[File:Mytton Hall.jpg|thumb|Mytton Hall – entrance c.1893, by Thomas Parkinson, Bolton.]] For his contribution to the 1873 [[Annual International Exhibitions (London 1871–74)|International Exhibition]] at [[South Kensington]] Hick was presented with a Bronze Medal,{{cite web|title=COMMEMORATIVE MEDALS, BRITISH HISTORICAL MEDALS|url=http://www.baldwin.co.uk/media/cms/auction-archive/auction-a214/BALDWINS%20Argentum%20Auction%20-%20June%202014%20-%2002%20-%20COMMEMORATIVE%20MEDALS%20AND%20BANKNOTES.pdf|website=Baldwin's|publisher=A. H. Baldwin & Sons Ltd|accessdate=6 November 2014|location=Lot No. 384}} he was a member of the ''Permanent Committee for the Representation for British Pictures'' for the 1874 International Exhibition with fellow MPs [[Henry Bolckow]], [[Sir Alexander Brown, 1st Baronet|Alexander Brown]], [[Henry Eaton, 1st Baron Cheylesmore|Henry Eaton]], [[Joshua Fielden (politician)|Joshua Fielden]], [[William Graham (Glasgow MP)|William Graham]], [[John Snowdon Henry]], [[John Pender]] and others.{{cite journal|title=APPENDIX H. FORM NO.11. LONDON INTERNATIONAL EXHIBITION OF 1874. Permanent Committee for the Representation of British Pictures|journal=Victoria Government Gazette|date=7 November 1873|issue= 79|page=1951|url=http://gazette.slv.vic.gov.au/images/1873/V/general/79.pdf}} On 15 March 1879, towards the end of his time as an [[Member of Parliament|MP]], John Hick along with C.D. Abel, Colonel [[Frederick Beaumont]] (1833–1899) [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] MP for [[South Durham]] 1868–1880, F. Bolton, [[Alexander Brogden]] [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|JP]] (1825–1892) of [[John Brogden and Sons]], Liberal MP 1868–1885 for [[Wednesbury]], J.T. Jones and J. Turay registered the Aqueous Works and [[Exploration diamond drilling|Diamond Rock-boring]] Company (Limited), Crown Works, Guildford Street, York Road, [[Lambeth]].{{Citation|title=The Mining journal, railway and commercial gazette:forming a complete record of the proceedings of all public companies|publication-date=15 March 1879|publisher=H. English|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/19188816|accessdate=13 November 2015|page=252}} The company "...bought out and patented the system of using diamonds for boring".,{{cite web|title=ARTESIAN WELLS |url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/File:1891_KentSurreySussex4_i0793.png|website=Graces's Guide|publisher=Grace's Guide|accessdate=13 November 2015|page=24|date=1890}} Hick was elected a member of the [[Iron and Steel Institute]] the same year.{{cite journal|last1=UNKNOWN|title=''OBITUARY.''|journal=1894 Iron and Steel Institute: Obituaries|date=1894|volume=|page=389|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/1894_Iron_and_Steel_Institute:_Obituaries|accessdate=25 November 2015|issn=}} The Aqueous Works and Diamond Rock-boring Company was liquidated about 1892.{{cite journal|journal=The London Gazette|title=Aqueous Works and Exploration Diamond Rock-boring Company|date=26 February 1892|page=1145|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/26262/page/1145/data.pdf|accessdate=13 November 2015}} ==Pollution trial== After leaving parliament Hick and [[Lieutenant Colonel|Lt-Col.]] [[High Sheriff of Lancashire|Ralph John Aspinall]] [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|JP]], [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]], campaigned against the pollution and poisoning of [[salmon]] and [[trout]] in the [[River Ribble]] and its tributories by local industry; Hick raised the issue of pollution in the Ribble during the [[third reading]] of the [[Rivers Pollution Prevention Act 1876]].{{cite web|title=[BILL 276.] THIRD READING |url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1876/aug/04/bill-276-third-reading#S3V0231P0_18760804_HOC_172|website=HANSARD 1803–2005|accessdate=13 November 2015|date=4 August 1876}} Aspinall and Hick fought a publicised and successful legal battle in the [[Court of Chancery]] against the [[cotton mill]]s of [[Mitchell and Carlisle]] during July 1880 leading to a landmark judgement that set a precedent for controlling environmental pollution.{{cite web|last1=Kingsley|first1=Nicholas|title=Aspinall of Standen Hall|url=http://landedfamilies.blogspot.co.uk/2016/04/214-aspinall-of-standen-hall.html|website=Landed families of Britain and Ireland|publisher=Nicholas Kingsley|accessdate=11 May 2016|date=22 April 2016}} The river ran close to Mytton Hall where [[landlord]] Aspinall held the [[Fishing license|fishing rights]] and John Hick was lessee from 1874.{{cite web|last1=Unknown|title=Mitton Hall Mitton, Lancashire – Heritage Statement|url=https://www.ribblevalley.gov.uk/planx_downloads/Heritage_Statement.pdf|website=Ribble Valley Borough Council|publisher=JWRC Chartered Building Surveyors & Historic Building Consultants|accessdate=27 November 2015|page=8|date=October 2012}} The trial was presided over by the [[Chancellor of the High Court|Vice-Chancellor]] of England, Sir [[James Bacon (judge)|James Bacon]].{{cite news|title=HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE. CHANCERY DIVISION. (Before VICE-CHANCELLOR SIR J.BACON.) ASPINALL V. MITCHELL|issue=29927|publisher=The Times|date=7 July 1880|page=4}}{{cite news|title=HIGH COURT OF JUSTICE. CHANCERY DIVISION. (Before VICE-CHANCELLOR SIR J.BACON.) ASPINALL V. MITCHELL|issue=29945|publisher=The Times|date=28 July 1880|page=4}} In December 1880 Hick and Aspinall received presentations at Mytton Hall from the local [[angling]] community in recognition of "...their services in preventing pollution to the River Ribble and its tributories".{{cite book|last=Clegg |first=James |title=ANNALS OF BOLTON, HISTORY, CHRONOLOGY, POLITICS, PARLIAMENTARY AND MUNICIPAL POLLS|date=1888| location=Bolton | publisher=The Chronicle Office, Knowlsey Street |agency=Allen County Public Library Genealogy Center|page=186|url=https://archive.org/stream/annalsofboltonhi00cleg#page/361/mode/2up/search/HICK|accessdate=13 November 2015}} ==Science Museum== During 1887 Hick was a member of the mechanical collections committee chaired by [[John Slagg|John Slagg, MP]] with other experts and politicians; [[William Armstrong, 1st Baron Armstrong|Sir William Armstrong]], [[Joseph Bazalgette|Sir Joseph Bazelgette]], [[James Brunlees]], [[Edward Alfred Cowper|Edward Cowper]], Professor T. M. Goodeve, [[Charles Hutton Gregory|Sir Charles Gregory]], [[James Howard (agriculturalist)|James Howard, MP]], [[Charles Manby]], [[John Hinde Palmer]] (d.1884), [[Edward James Reed|Sir Edward Reed, MP]] and [[Bernhard Samuelson|Sir Bernhard Samuelson, MP]] established with several committees for the purpose of advising a central committee appointed by the Treasury to investigate the forming of a [[Science Museum (London)|Science Museum]] and [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Gallery of Portraits]] in [[South Kensington]], situated between the [[Natural History Museum, London|Natural History Museum]] and what was to be the [[Imperial Institute]].{{cite news|author=From a Correspondent |title=The Need of a Science Museum |issue=32137| newspaper=[[The Times]]|date=29 July 1887|page=4}} ==Death== [[File:LNWR engine No.20 John Hick.jpg|thumb|LNWR engine no. 20 ''John Hick'', built at [[Crewe Works]].{{cite book|last1=Steel|first1=Wilfred. L|title=The History of the London & North Western Railway|date=1914|publisher="The Railway and TravelMonthly"|location=University of California|page=465|url=https://archive.org/stream/historylondonno00steegoog#page/n478/mode/2up|accessdate=4 February 2016|chapter=CONCERNING LOCOMOTIVE MATTERS}}]] Previously of Hill Top, [[Belmont, Lancashire]] Hick died at the age of 78 after some months of failing health when living at [[Little Mitton|Mytton]] Hall, [[Whalley, Lancashire]] and [[Lezayre]], [[Isle of Man]],{{cite book|last=Kermode, M.A. |first=Canon R. D. |title=THE ANNALS OF KIRK CHRIST LEZAYRE|date=1954|publisher=THE NORRIS MODERN PRESS LTD. | location=Victoria Street, Douglas |url=http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/fulltext/ker1954/ch14.htm |accessdate=2 December 2015|chapter=XIV – ST. STEPHEN'S, SULBY}} where he was also a [[Magistrate (England and Wales)|Justice of the Peace]].{{cite book|last1=Walford|first1=Edward|title=The county families of the United Kingdom; or, Royal manual of the titled and untitled aristocracy of England, Wales, Scotland, and Ireland |date=1919| location=London | publisher=R. Hardwicke|page=654|url=https://archive.org/stream/countyfamiliesof591919walf#page/654/mode/2up |accessdate=2 December 2015}} Like his father Benjamin, John Hick accumulated a large and valuable collection of art works, some of which was [[inheritance|inherited]], others purchased from the auction of [[Benjamin Hick]]'s [[Estate (law)|estate]] in 1843,{{cite journal|title=SALE OF AN IMPORTANT AND GENUINE COLLECTION OF PICTURES, DRAWINGS, ENGRAVINGS, BRONZES &c|journal=The Art-Union|date=1 January 1843|volume=|page=26|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CGZRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26&dq=benjamin+hick+art+journal#v=onepage&q=benjamin%20hick%20art%20journal&f=false |accessdate=23 January 2014}}{{cite journal|editor1-last=Cave (URBAN)|editor1-first=Edward (SILVANUS)|authorlink=Edward Cave|title=SALES OF PICTURES|journal=The Gentleman's Magazine|date=1843|volume=XIX |pages=507–508|url=https://books.google.com/?id=6CZIAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA507&lpg=PA507&dq=hick+sale+of+pictures+The+gentleman%27s+magazine#v=onepage&q=hick%20sale%20of%20pictures%20The%20gentleman%27s%20magazine&f=false|accessdate=20 May 2015| location=London | publisher=WILLIAM PICKERING; JOHN BOWYER NICHOLS AND SON }} and devoted his final years at Mytton Hall to compiling an elaborately illustrated catalogue of the collection;{{cite journal|author=Unknown |title=Obituary, John Hick, 1815-1894|journal=Proceedings of the Institution of Civil Engineers|date=1894|volume=117|issue=1894|pages=379–380|url=http://www.icevirtuallibrary.com/doi/pdf/10.1680/imotp.1894.19959|accessdate=13 November 2015|issn=1753-7843|doi=10.1680/imotp.1894.19959}} some of these works were auctioned by [[Christie's]] during June and July 1909{{cite journal|title=A RECORD OF SALE PRICES AT CHRISTIE'S DURING THE SEASON|journal=Art Prices Current|date=1909|volume=II|issue=1908–9|pages=xix, 229, 278|url=https://archive.org/stream/artpricescurrent02lond#page/278/mode/1up/search/hick|accessdate=13 November 2015|publisher=London, Offices of the Fine Art Trade Journal|location=Philadelphia Museum of Art, Library}} following Rebecca Hick's death in 1908.{{cite web|last1=Redfern|first1=Diane|title=Rebecca Maria Ashworth|url=http://www.dianeredfern.ca/pafg04.htm#131|website=Diane Redfern ANCESTRY & FAMILY HISTORY|publisher= dianeredfern.ca|accessdate=26 November 2015}}{{cite journal|title=Mrs. REBECCA MARIA HICK, Deceased |journal=The London Gazette|date=26 January 1909|page=692|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/28218/page/692/data.pdf|accessdate=4 December 2015}} The Hick library at Mytton Hall was dispersed at Capes Dunne & Co. [[Manchester]] in November 1909.{{cite journal|last1=Butterworth|first1=Walter|title=Henry Leverseege – the Ancoats artist|journal=PAPERS OF THE Manchester Literary Club|date=1920|volume=XLVI |pages= 14–15|url=https://archive.org/stream/papersman46mancuoft#page/14/mode/2up/search/hick|accessdate=7 May 2015|publisher=SHERRATT & HUGHES Manchester: 34 Cross Street|location=Robarts – [[University of Toronto]], Canada }} From the year of his death the [[London North Western Railway]] (LNWR) produced 10 [[steam locomotives]] of the [[LNWR John Hick Class|''John Hick'' Class]] (1894–1912); a [[Francis Webb (engineer)|Francis Webb]] design of [[2-2-2-2]] configuration,{{cite web|title=John Hick Class|url=http://www.lnwrs.org.uk/PassLocos/PassLoco.php?loco=09|website=London and North Western Railway Society, Passenger Engines of the LNWR|publisher=LNWR Society|accessdate=13 November 2014|date=1914}} engine No. 20 named ''John Hick''. The following 9 engines were named after [[engineers]] and inventors, principally from the [[Industrial Revolution|industrial]] and [[Second industrial revolution]]: No. 1505 ''[[Richard Arkwright]]'', No. 1512 ''[[Henry Cort]]'', No. 1534 ''[[William Froude]]'', No. 1535 ''[[Henry Maudslay]]'', No. 1536 ''[[Hugh Myddelton]]'', No. 1548 ''[[John Penn (engineer)|John Penn]]'', No. 1549 ''[[John Rennie the Younger|John Rennie]]'', No. 1557 ''[[Thomas Savery]]'' and No. 1559 ''[[William Siemens]]''.{{cite magazine|last1=Hambleton | first1=F.C. |title=Webb compounds: "John Hick" class L.N.W.R. |magazine=The Locomotive Magazine and Railway Carriage and Wagon Review|date=15 February 1940|volume=46|issue=570|pages=36–37| location=London | publisher=Locomotive Pub. Co., 1896–1959 }}{{cite book|last1=Baxter, Bertram|editor1-last=Baxter|editor1-first=David|title=British Locomotive Catalogue 1825–1923, Volume 2B: London and North Western Railway and its constituent companies |date=1979|publisher=Ashbourne, Derbyshire: Moorland Publishing Company |isbn=0903485842|pages=196–197}}{{cite book|last1=Sharman|first1=M. |title=The London and North Western Railway: A Selection of 7mm Locomotive Drawings|date=1986|publisher=Oakwood Press & Video Library|isbn=9780853613152|edition=illustrated}} Hick was unique in that he was the only LNWR director to have a locomotive class named after him ''[[wikt:in memoriam|in memoriam]]''.{{cite book|last1=Baxter, Bertram|editor1-last=Baxter|editor1-first=David|title=British Locomotive Catalogue 1825–1923, Volume 2A: London and North Western Railway and its constituent companies |date=1978|publisher=Ashbourne, Derbyshire: Moorland Publishing Company |isbn=0903485516|pages=}}{{cite book|last1=Baxter, Bertram|editor1-last=Baxter|editor1-first=David|title=British Locomotive Catalogue 1825–1923, Volume 2B: London and North Western Railway and its constituent companies |date=1979|publisher=Ashbourne, Derbyshire: Moorland Publishing Company |isbn=0903485842|pages=}} Following withdrawal of the ''John Hick'' Class in 1912, during the month of the anniversary of Hick's death, February 1913, 5 of 6 names were transferred to the LNWR [[LNWR George the Fifth Class|''George the Fifth'' Class]], locomotive No. 752 named ''John Hick'', serving up to 1935 with the [[London Midland and Scottish Railway]] (LMS).{{cite web|title=JOHN HICK|url=http://www.brdatabase.info/locoqry.php?action=locodata&type=S&id=125311&loco=752|website=BRDatabase – Complete BR Locomotive Database {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Use British English|date=August 2011}} [[File:John Tom.jpg|thumb|200px|right|John Nichols Thom]] '''John Nichols Tom''' (sometimes spelt '''Thom'''; 1799 – 31 May 1838) was a [[Cornwall|Cornish]] wine-merchant and maltster who re-invented himself as Sir William Courtenay, stood for parliament in Canterbury, was convicted of perjury in a smuggling case, spent three years in the Kent County Lunatic Asylum, and, following his release, gathered a small band of followers and paraded in the Kent countryside. He, using the title ''Sir William Percy Honeywood Courtney, King of Jerusalem'',{{cite podcast |title=Who Goes There - Episode 6, Season 4 |publisher = [[BBC Radio 4 Extra]] |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0075zbk |year=1984 |series=4|time= 14:45}} along with several of his followers, was killed in a confrontation with soldiers in Bossenden Wood, in what has sometimes been called the [[Battle of Bossenden Wood|last battle to be fought on English soil]]. ==Early life== John Nichols Tom (or Thom) was born the son of innkeepers in 1799 at [[St Columb Major]], Cornwall. He was baptised in the parish church on 10 November 1799. His parents were William and Charity Tom who kept the Joiners' Arms.Rogers: 1-2 Tom went to school in [[Penryn, Cornwall|Penryn]], attending Bellevue Academy (a "Classical and Commercial Academy"). At the age of about fourteen he transferred to the private school in [[Launceston, Cornwall|Launceston]] that was run by [[Richard Cope (minister)|Reverend Richard Cope]], pastor of the local Congregational Church.Rogers: 2 Tom stayed at school until he was eighteen and was then articled to solicitor Mr Paynter of St Columb. He decided, however, against a career in the law and left after three years. After a short spell as an innkeeper in [[Wadebridge]] he settled down as a clerk in the firm of Lubbock and Co, wine merchants of [[Truro]], and took over the business when the partners retired, extending it to include [[malting]]. In 1821 he married Catherine Fisher Fulpitt, the daughter of a market gardener in Truro.Rogers: 3 Tom was a tall, strongly built, good-looking man, who became known in Truro for his skill as a cricketer. During a visit to London he joined the [[Thomas Spence|Spencean Society]].Rogers: 4 When Tom was in his late twenties a series of disasters struck. His mother Charity was removed to Cornwall Lunatic Asylum in 1827, and died there. Then, in 1828, his business premises in Pydar Street burnt down. Tom claimed the insurance and was able to rebuild the premises.Rogers: 5-6 At the [[Quarter Sessions]] held at [[Bodmin]] on 15 July 1828, Tom applied successfully for the return of £304 paid in [[excise duty]] on [[malt]] destroyed in the fire at his malthouse on 17 June 1828.[[Cornwall Record Office]], Sessions held at Bodmin QS/1/11/370-397 15 July 1828, abstract at National Archives online, [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/a2a/records.aspx?cat=021-qs_6&cid=1-1-14#1-1-14 QS/1/11/387]: "Application by John Nicholls Tom of Truro, maltster, who stated that on 17 June last his malthouse in Truro contained 2,358 "Winchester bushels" [a standard weight] of malt, the duty on which he had paid £304.11s.6d. His warehouse had been destroyed by fire together with the contents: Collector of Excise to allow John Nicholls Tom full amount of duty paid." In 1831 Tom received treatment from a surgeon for an attack of insanity but recovered and the following spring sailed from Truro to Liverpool with a cargo of malt. He wrote to his wife from Liverpool to tell her he had sold the malt, and wrote again from Birmingham to tell her he was going to France. Nothing more was heard from him until over a year later, when his family heard that a man who fitted his description and went by the name of Sir William Courtenay was being held in Maidstone prison.Rogers: 7-8; Reay: 111. ==Canterbury== In September 1832 Thom arrived in [[Canterbury]], dressed in exotic costumes and wearing long hair and a beard. He put up at the Rose Inn at the junction of Rose Lane and the main street and went first by the name of Count [[Rothschild]], and then by the name of Sir William Percy Honeywood Courtenay, Knight of Malta, heir to the [[Earl of Devon]] and the Kentish estates of Sir Edward Hales.Rogers: 8-16 Although many people realized he was an imposter he nevertheless became a colourful and popular figure in the town, partly because he frequently made comical and insulting speeches directed at the unpopular mayor and magistrates of the city and the Archbishop of Canterbury. In the December 1832 general election Liberal support in the town was so strong that the Conservatives decided not to field candidates. Stung by jeers about not standing, some local Conservatives asked Tom to stand as an independent candidate for [[Canterbury (UK Parliament constituency)|Canterbury]], hoping he would inconvenience the Liberals. He polled a creditable 375 votes (against 834 for [[Richard Watson (politician)|Richard Watson]] and 802 for [[George Cowper, 6th Earl Cowper|Viscount Fordwich]], the Liberal candidates).Rogers: 20-24 He then decided to stand in the [[East Kent (UK Parliament constituency)|East Kent]] election, but polled only three votes, and turned his attention to publishing a weekly paper, ''The Lion''. Eight issues of the paper were produced. Full of biblical quotations, it argued for the rights of the poor, expressed loyalty to the Crown, and was critical of the clergy, aristocracy, town corporations and Parliament.Rogers: 32 Tom's biographer described the views expressed in ''The Lion'' as showing "amazing common sense... far in advance of those generally held in his time", for example, regarding rents, taxation, the Irish problem, and corporal punishment, although these "occasional shafts of light" were surrounded by "turgid nonsense".Rogers: 40-41 ==Barming Heath== At the beginning of March 1833, Thom intervened in the case of some Faversham smugglers, acting as a witness for the defence. The smugglers were nevertheless convicted, and Tom was prosecuted for [[perjury]].Rogers: 40-45 His trial took place on 25 July at the Kent Summer Assizes at [[Maidstone]] before Mr Justice Parke and a crowded court. Evidence was heard from the Vicar of [[Boughton-under-Blean]] that Tom had been at church when he claimed to have witnessed events off the [[Goodwin Sands]]. In spite of the testimony of a number of character witnesses, the jury returned a verdict of guilty and Tom was sentenced to three months imprisonment and seven years [[penal transportation|transportation]] to Australia.Rogers: 57-67 Tom's family in Truro had heard about the trial and Catherine Tom arrived in Maidstone in August to see if Courtenay was her missing husband. He was produced by the governor of Maidstone Gaol and she made a positive identification. Although Tom always denied any connection with the Truro family, Catherine Tom was believed. She told the authorities about her husband's previous attack of insanity; he was then examined by two surgeons who declared him of unsound mind. Tom was transferred to [[Oakwood Hospital|Barming Heath Asylum]] on 28 October 1833.Rogers: 69-71 Tom was a model patient in the asylum and in 1837 the superintendent suggested to his wife that she should petition the home secretary for his release. Tom's father in Truro brought his son's case to the attention of [[Richard Hussey Vivian, 1st Baron Vivian|Sir Hussey Vivian]], the Liberal candidate for [[East Cornwall (UK Parliament constituency)|East Cornwall]] in the August 1837 election. Vivian, after his election, took the matter up with the home secretary, [[John Russell, 1st Earl Russell|Lord John Russell]], and Tom was granted a free pardon by [[Queen Victoria]], on condition he was returned into the care of his family in Cornwall.Rogers: 74-80 Thom was still refusing to acknowledge the Cornish family and, instead of returning to Cornwall, went to live with a local farmer and supporter, Mr Francis of Fairbrook, Boughton-under-Blean, who had offered to be his guardian. This was permitted, due to some ambiguous wording on the pardon, and in October 1837, four years after his admission to the asylum, Tom was released.Rogers: 81 ==Battle and death== {{Main|Battle of Bossenden Wood}} [[Image:Plaque in Hernhill Churchyard.jpg|thumb|right|Plaque in [[Hernhill]] churchyard]] By January 1838, Tom had fallen out with Mr Francis, and he spent the next few months riding through East Kent, relying on the hospitality of supporters.Rogers: 89 With promises of a better future, fairer distribution of wealth and greater equality, he attracted a following of agricultural labourers, artisans and small-holders. In particular, he addressed their concerns about low wages, lack of work, and the [[Poor Law Amendment Act 1834|New Poor Law]], which ordered all able-bodied men to [[workhouse]]s if they could not find work.J. Lowerson, ed. Charlesworth, ''An Atlas of Rural protests in Britain, 1548-1900'' (1983), pp. 139-141: "The 1834 Poor Law Amendment Act was designed specifically to cope with the severe problems of rural England and to prevent... a repetition of the 1830s incidents in the epicentres of Kent... There, complex soil patterns, small-scale farming and low investment rates combined with a rapid population surge to produce... dependence on permanent relief of 25% of population... groups of labourers (1835) ...besieged local magistrates in the workhouse... 37 labourers were imprisoned for... up to two years." Until the end of May, the activities of Tom and his small band of followers were entirely peaceful as they marched around the local countryside trying to drum up support amongst the workers. Some wealthier landowners were however becoming alarmed and, on 31 May 1838, a local magistrate, Dr Poore, issued a warrant for Tom's arrest for inciting workmen to leave their work.Rogers: 93-110 Early on the morning of 31 May, the parish constable of Boughton-under-Blean enlisted the help of his assistant and also of his brother, Nicholas Mears, and set off to find Tom. When they arrived at Bossenden Farm, where Tom and his followers were staying, Tom shot and killed Nicholas Mears. The constable and his assistant fled.Rogers: 110-112 News of the murder reached the magistrates and soldiers were called out from the barracks at Canterbury. A detachment of the [[45th (Nottinghamshire) Regiment of Foot|45th Infantry]] under Major Armstrong, with three junior officers and about one hundred men, met up with the magistrates and tracked Tom and his followers down to a clearing in Bossenden Wood. Tom's followers numbered between thirty and forty (a few having managed to escape after the killing of the constable), and, with the exception of Tom and one other who had pistols, were armed only with sticks. As the soldiers advanced, Lieutenant Bennet was shot dead by Tom. In the ensuing confrontation, which lasted only a few minutes, Tom and eight of his followers were killed or mortally wounded by the soldiers, and a young special constable who was helping the soldiers was caught in their fire and killed. One soldier was slightly injured by a stick.Rogers: 128-130 ==Aftermath and legacy== Tom's body, together with those of his followers who had been killed, was taken to the Red Lion Inn at [[Dunkirk, Kent|Dunkirk]].Rogers: 139 The inn was besieged by souvenir and relic hunters, and the simply curious. The landlord of Red Lion claimed 20,000 people had visited the neighbourhood over the next few days.Reay: 155 Tom's biographer describes public feeling:
"This was an insignificant casualty list as battles go; but it was a terrible price to pay for the capture, dead, of one man. When the disastrous results of the affray became known, public opinion was deeply shocked at what seemed an unnecessary loss of life. The repercussions of the Battle of Bossenden wood were soon, in fact, to reach Westminster itself."Rogers: 137
An inquest was held at the White Horse, Boughton, the Saturday after the battle, with the jury returning a verdict of "justifiable homicide" on the deaths of Tom and his followers.Rogers: 152-153 On the following Tuesday Tom was buried in [[Hernhill]] cemetery.Rogers: 154-157 Few of Tom's followers had been arrested at the scene of the battle, but some were picked up over the next few days.Reay: 153 Thirty men and two women were arrested, and of these ten were tried for murder - two for the murder of the constable's brother and nine for the murder of Bennett (with Thomas Mears being charged with both).Reay: 159 Thomas Mears and William Price were convicted of the murder of the constable's brother, then the rest pleaded guilty. Thomas Mears and William Wills were transported for life, William Price for ten years, and the others received one year's imprisonment.Reay: 161-164 Local magistrates and politicians, especially Lord John Russell, were attacked for their role in the affair. There were accusations that Sir Hussey Vivian had requested Tom's release in return for his father's vote. A parliamentary select committee was appointed and sat for three days in June.Rogers: 170-178 Barrister Frederick Liardet was sent to survey the area for the Central Society of Education, and a school and a church were built in Dunkirk. Journalists talked of the ignorance and moral degradation of the area. [[Feargus O'Connor]] suggested a monument should be erected in memory of Courtenay's followers.Reay: 152 == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== * B Reay 1990 ''The last rising of the agricultural labourers: rural life and protest in nineteenth-century England''. [[File:Mormantul lui Leon Negruzzi.jpg|thumb|Grave at Hermeziu]] '''Leon C. Negruzzi''' (June 5, 1840 – July 15/16, 1890) was a [[Moldavia]]n, later [[Romania]]n politician and writer.
Born in [[Iași]],<ref name="Rosetti137"/> he was the first child of [[Constantin Negruzzi]].<ref name="Lecca363">Lecca, p. 363</ref> He began his education at ''[[Academia Mihăileană]]'', but completed high school in Berlin, where he was sent with his brother [[Iacob Negruzzi|Iacob]] in 1853. He wanted to study medicine at [[Berlin University]], but was too revolted by the anatomical dissections, and switched to philosophy and law. He attended lectures at Berlin and [[University of Vienna|Vienna]], but did not graduate. He returned home in 1864, where he was named a judge at the Iași tribunal. He gradually advanced to become a member of the appeals court as well as general prosecutor.<ref name="Rosetti137"/> A member of the [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|Conservative Party]],<ref name="Maiorescu346"/> he was [[Prefect (Romania)|Prefect]] of [[Iași County]] under the [[Lascăr Catargiu]] government (1871-1876), resuming this office in March 1888.<ref name="Rosetti137"/> He also served as mayor of Iași, as [[Romanian Chamber of Deputies|deputy]] and as [[Romanian Senate|senator]].<ref name="Rosetti137"/><ref name="Maiorescu346">Maiorescu (2001), p. 346</ref> Near the end of his life, he was administrator of [[Sfântul Spiridon Hospital]]. He died at the family estate in [[Trifești, Iași|Hermeziu]] village.<ref name="Rosetti137"/>
Also interested in literature, he belonged to the cultural milieu surrounding ''[[Junimea]]'' and ''[[Convorbiri Literare]]'', which his brother edited.<ref name="Rosetti137">Rosetti, p. 137</ref> He wrote six novellas: ''Vântul soartei'' (1867), ''Evreica'' (1868-1869), ''O răzbunare'' (1874), ''Țiganca'' (1877), ''Serghie Pavlovici'' (1881) and ''Osândiții'' (1881-1882). All appeared in his brother's magazine, and were judged by [[Titu Maiorescu]] as "distinguished neither by the originality of their concept nor through their style".<ref name="Maiorescu654">Maiorescu (2005), p. 654</ref> He had five daughters and two sons.<ref name="Lecca363"/>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Octav George Lecca, ''Familiile boerești române: istoric și genealogie dupe isvoare autentice'', Editura Minerva, Bucharest, 1899 *[[Titu Maiorescu]], [[Constantin Schifirneț]] (ed.), ''Discursuri parlamentare'', Editura Albatros, Bucharest, 2001, {{ISBN|978-973-2408-71-1}} *Titu Maiorescu; Dimitrie Vatamaniuc, Eugen Simion (eds.), ''Opere: Critice'', Editura Fundației Naționale pentru Știință și Artă, Bucharest, 2005, {{ISBN|978-973-7934-46-8}} *[[Dimitrie Rosetti]], ''Dicționarul Contimporanilor'', Editura Lito-Tipografiei "Populara", Bucharest, 1897

{{chinese name|[[Lin (surname)|Lin (林)]]}} {{infobox person |birth_date = {{birth date|1895|10|10}} |birth_place = [[Banzai Town|Banzai]], [[Pinghe County|Pinghe]], [[Zhangzhou]], [[Fujian]] |image = Linyutang.jpg |caption = Lin Yutang, photographed by
[[Carl Van Vechten]], 1939 |occupation = Writer, translator, inventor, linguist, philosopher |alma_mater = [[Saint John's University, Shanghai|Saint John's University]]
[[Harvard University]]
[[Leipzig University]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1976|3|26|1895|10|10}} |death_place = [[Hong Kong]] }} {{Chinese|showflag=poj|t=林語堂|s=林语堂|j=lam4 jyu5 tong4|p=Lín Yǔtáng|gr=Lin Yeutarng|poj=Lîm Gí-tông}} '''Lin Yutang''' ({{zh|t=林語堂|p=Lín Yǔtáng}}; October 10, 1895 – March 26, 1976) was a [[List of Chinese authors|Chinese writer]], translator, linguist, philosopher and inventor. His informal but polished style in both Chinese and English made him one of the most influential writers of his generation, and his compilations and translations of [[Chinese classic texts|classic Chinese texts]] into English were bestsellers in the West. ==Youth== Lin was born in 1895 in the town of [[Banzai Town|Banzai]], [[Pinghe County|Pinghe]], [[Zhangzhou]], [[Fujian]]. The mountainous region made a deep impression on his consciousness, and thereafter, he would constantly consider himself a child of the mountains (in one of his books he commented that his idea of hell was a city apartment). His father was a Christian minister. His journey of faith from [[Christianity]] to [[Taoism]] and [[Buddhism]], and back to Christianity in his later life was recorded in his book ''From Pagan to Christian'' (1959). ==Academic career and Shanghai intellectual world== Lin studied for his bachelor's degree at [[Saint John's University, Shanghai|Saint John's University]] in [[Shanghai]], then received a half-scholarship to continue study for a doctoral degree at [[Harvard University]]. He later wrote that in the [[Widener Library]] he first found himself and first came alive, but he never saw a Harvard-Yale game.{{cite web|last1=Brooks|first1=E Bruce|title=Lin Yutang |archive-date=2013-08-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130809193313/http://www.umass.edu/wsp/sinology/persons/lin.html |website=Sinology |date=9 August 2013 |url=http://www.umass.edu/wsp/sinology/persons/lin.html}} He left Harvard early, since he couldn't afford to study in Harvard anymore,and moved to work with the [[Chinese Labor Corps]] in France and eventually to Germany, where he completed his requirements for a doctoral degree in Chinese philology at the [[University of Leipzig]]. From 1923 to 1926 he taught English literature at [[Peking University]]. Enthusiastic about the success of the [[Northern Expedition]], he briefly served in the new [[Kuomintang|Nationalist government]], but soon turned to teaching and writing. He found himself in the wake of the [[New Culture Movement]] which criticized China's tradition as feudal and harmful. Instead of accepting this charge, however, Lin immersed himself in the Confucian texts and literary culture which his Christian upbringing and English language education had denied him.{{cite book|last=Yang|first=Rain Liu|editor=Carol Lee Hamrin| editor2=Stacey Bieler|title=Salt and Light, Volume 3: More Lives of Faith That Shaped Modern China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HutMAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA164|year=2011|publisher=Wipf and Stock Publishers|location=Eugene, OR|isbn=978-1-61097-158-4|pages=164-166|chapter=Lin Yutang: Astride the Cultures of East and West}} His humor magazine, ''Lunyu banyuekan'' (The Analects Fortnightly, 1932-40, 1945-49) featured essays by prominent writers such as [[Hu Shi]], [[Lao She]], [[Lu Xun]], and [[Zhou Zuoren]] and attracted a wide readership. He was a key figure in introducing the Western concept of [[humor]], which he felt China had lacked. Lin coined the term ''youmo'' (humor) in 1924 and used The Analects to promote his conception of humor as the expression of a tolerant, cosmopolitan, understanding and civilized philosophy of life.Christopher Rea, "The Age of Irreverence: A New History of Laughter in China" (California, 2015), chapter 6: "The Invention of Humor"Qian, Suoqiao, "Discovering 'Humor' in Modern China: The Launching of the Analects Fortnightly Journal and the 'Year of Humour' (1933)," in Chey and Davis, "Humour in Chinese Life and Letters: Classical and Traditional Approaches" (Hong Kong University Press, 2011), ch. 10. In 1933, Lu Xun attacked the ''Analects'' for being apolitical and dismissed Lin's elegant xiaopin wen 小品文, or small essays, as "bric a brac for the bourgeoisie." Lu Xun nevertheless maintained a cordial relationship with Lin and continued to contribute to his journal.[http://mclc.osu.edu/rc/bios/lxbio.htm Kirk A. Denton, "Lu Xun Biography," MCLC Resource Center, (2002)] Lin's writings in Chinese were critical of the [[History of the Republic of China|Nationalist government]] to the point that he feared for his life. Many of his essays from this time were later collected in ''With Love and Irony'' (1940). In 1933, he met [[Pearl Buck]] in Shanghai, who introduced him and his writings to her publisher, [[Richard Walsh (publisher)|Richard Walsh]], head of [[John Day Company|John Day publishers]], who published Lin's works for many years.{{cite book|author=Lin Yutang|editor-last=Qian |editor-first=Suoqiao|title=Selected bilingual essays of Lin Yutang|date=2010|publisher=Chinese University Press|location=Hong Kong|isbn=9789629964351|edition=Traditional Chinese-English bilingual}}{{cite book|last1=Suoqiao|first1=Qian|title=Liberal Cosmopolitan: Lin Yutang and Middling Chinese Modernity|date=2011|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden|isbn=9789004192133}} Lin's relation with Christianity changed over the years. His father, of course, was a second-generation Christian, but at Tsinghua, Lin asked himself what it meant to be a Christian in China. Being a Christian meant acceptance of Western science and progress, but Lin became angry that being a Christian also meant losing touch with China's culture and his own personal identity. On his return from study abroad, Lin renewed his respect for his father, yet he plunged into study of Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism and did not identify himself as Christian until the late 1950s.[http://www.bdcconline.net/en/stories/l/lin-yutang.php Stacey Bieler, "Lin Yutang"] ''Biographical Dictionary of Christianity in China'' ==Career after leaving China and death== [[File:The Lin Yutang House 20120907.jpg|thumb|[[Lin Yutang House]] in [[Taipei]]]] After 1935, Lin lived mainly in the United States, where he became known as a "wise and witty" popularizer of Chinese philosophy and way of life.{{cite news|title=Chinese Says Our Virtues Are Our Vices|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19370414&id=VxoyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jeIFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2666,3155368|accessdate=9 December 2017|publisher=[[Reading Eagle]]|date=4 April 1937}} Lin's first best sellers were ''My Country and My People'' ({{zh|t=吾國與吾民|labels=no}}) (1935) and ''The Importance of Living'' ({{zh|t=生活的藝術|labels=no}}) (1937), written in English in a charming style. Others include ''Between Tears and Laughter'' ({{zh|t=啼笑皆非|labels=no}}) (1943), ''The Importance of Understanding'' (1960, a book of translated Chinese literary passages and short pieces), ''The Chinese Theory of Art'' (1967). The novels ''[[Moment in Peking]]'' (1939), ''[[A Leaf in the Storm]]'' (1940), and ''The Vermilion Gate'' ({{zh|t=朱門|labels=no}}) (1953) were well received epics of China in turmoil while ''[[Chinatown Family]]'' (1948) presented the lives of Chinese Americans in New York. Partly to avoid controversial contemporary issues, Lin in 1947 published ''The Gay Genius: The Life and Times of Su Tungpo'', which presented the struggle between [[Su Dongpo]] and [[Wang Anshi]] as parallel to the struggle between Chinese liberals and totalitarian communists. Lin's political writings in English sold fewer copies than his cultural works and were more controversial. ''Between Tears and Laughter'' (1943) broke with the genial tone of his earlier English writings to criticize Western racism and imperialism. After the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]], Lin traveled in China and wrote favorably of the war effort and [[Chiang Kai-shek]] in ''Vigil of a Nation'' (1944). American [[China Hands]] such as [[Edgar Snow]] criticized the works.{{cite journal|last1=Qian|first1=Suoqiao|title=Representing China: Lin Yutang vs. American "China Hands" in the 1940s|journal=Journal of American-East Asian Relations|date=1 October 2010|volume=17|issue=2|pages=99–117|doi=10.1163/187656110X528974}} [[File:Ming Kwai 1952 US 2613795 A.png|thumb|Lin's Mingkwai [[Chinese typewriter]] played a pivotal role in the Cold War machine translation research.]] Mechanics had been a long time avocation. Since Chinese is a character-based rather than an alphabet-based language, with many thousands of separate characters, it was difficult to employ modern printing technologies. Many doubted that a [[Chinese typewriter]] could be invented. Lin, however, worked on this problem for decades and eventually came up with a workable typewriter, brought to market in the middle of the [[Sino-Japanese War (1937-1945)|war with Japan]]. The Mingkwai "Clear and Quick" Chinese-language typewriter played a pivotal role in the Cold War machine translation research.{{cite book|last1=Tsu|first1=Jing|title=Sound and Script in Chinese Diaspora |date=2010|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, Mass.|isbn=978-0674055407 |chapter=Lin Yutang's Typewriter |pages=49–79}} Lin also invented and patented several lesser inventions, such as a toothbrush that dispensed toothpaste. In the mid-1950s, he served briefly and unhappily as president (or chancellor) of the [[Nanyang University]], which was newly created in [[Singapore]] specifically for Chinese studies as parallel to the English-oriented [[National University of Singapore|University of Singapore]]. He did not, however, choose to continue in that role when the faculty resisted his plans to demolish and rebuild the new school building (which though grand, was not "Western" enough), his demands to have sole control over finances, and a budget clearly beyond its means. Lin accepted a dismissal fee of $305,203, entirely contributed by [[Tan Lark Sye]], to prevent depleting the university's funds. He would later claim that Nanyang (South Seas) University became a focus of the struggle for control of Singapore between the Communist-directed left and the liberal, social democratic right and that he was too old for the conflict. The episode left a bad taste in the Malayan Chinese community, who felt betrayed by his actions during and after the fiasco. After he returned to New York in the late 1950s, Lin renewed his interest in Christianity. His wife was a devout believer, and Lin admired her serenity and humility. After attending services with her at the [[David H. C. Read|Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church]] for several months, he joined the church and announced his return to the faith. His 1959 book ''From Pagan to Christian'' explained this move, which many of his readers found surprising. With his facility for both Chinese and English idiom, Lin presided over the compilation of a Chinese-English dictionary, ''[[Lin Yutang's Chinese-English Dictionary of Modern Usage]]'' (1972), which contains a massive English index to definitions of Chinese terms. The work was undertaken at the newly founded [[Chinese University of Hong Kong]]. His many works represent an attempt to bridge the cultural gap between the East and the West. He was nominated for the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] in 1940 and 1950.{{cite web |last=Nobel Media AB |title=Nomination Database - Literature |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nomination/archive/show_people.php?id=5492 |publisher=Nobel Media AB |year=2013 |accessdate=21 December 2013}} He continued to live up his work until his death in 1976. Lin was buried at his home in [[Yangmingshan]], [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]]. His home has been turned into a museum, which is operated by Taipei-based [[Soochow University (Taiwan)|Soochow University]]. The town of Lin's birth, Banzai, has also preserved the original Lin home and turned it into a museum. ==Lin's reputation and scholarship on Lin== [[File:Lin Yutang.jpg|left|thumb|Lin Yutang]] Although his major books have remained in print, Lin is a thinker whose place in modern Chinese intellectual history has been overlooked until recently.William Sima, "New Scholarship: The Cross-Cultural Legacy of Lin Yutang in China and America," China Heritage Quarterly 29 (2012). {{cite web |url=http://chinaheritagenewsletter.anu.edu.au/scholarship.php?searchterm=029_sima.inc&issue=029 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121129192030/http://chinaheritagenewsletter.anu.edu.au/scholarship.php?searchterm=029_sima.inc&issue=029 |archivedate=2012-11-29 |df= }} Lin themed conventions have been organized in Taiwan and Lin's native Fujian, and in December 2011, the International Conference on the Cross-cultural Legacy of Lin Yutang in China and America was held at City University of Hong Kong, with professional and private scholars from mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Japan, Malaysia, the United States, Germany and Slovakia. The organizer of the conference was Dr. Qian Suoqiao, author of the book, ''Liberal Cosmopolitan: Lin Yutang and Middling Chinese Modernity'' (Leiden; Boston: Brill, 2010).International Conference on the Cross-cultural Legacy of Lin Yutang in China and America [http://ctl.cityu.edu.hk/Portal_Root/subsites/conferences/2011/dec/LinYutang/] The first full-length academic study of Lin in English is Diran John Sohigian's "The Life and Times of Lin Yutang" (Columbia University Ph.D. diss., 1991). Jing Tsu's Sound and Script in Chinese Diaspora (Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2010) gives a detailed account of Lin Yutang's typewriter and its role in the context of late 19th century script reform, Chinese national language reform in the early twentieth century and the fascinating story of his typewriting keyboard and [[machine translation]] research during the [[Cold War]]. ==Family== His wife, Liao Tsui-feng (廖翠鳳), was an author, who, along with her daughter Lin Hsiang Ju, wrote three cookery books which popularized [[Chinese cuisine]] in the English speaking world. Dr. Lin wrote introductions which explained the historical background and relevance for American life. His first daughter [[Adet Lin|Lin Feng-ju]] (林鳳如; 1923–1971), known as Adet, was an author who also used the pseudonym Tan Yun. His second daughter [[Tai-yi Lin|Lin Taiyi]] (林太乙; 1926–2003) was also known as Anor Lin in her earliest writing, and had the Chinese name Yu-ju 玉如. She was an author and the general editor of Chinese [[Reader's Digest]] from 1965 until her retirement in 1988. She also wrote a biography of her father in Chinese (林語堂傳), which shows some signs of her father's literary flair. His third daughter Lin Hsiang-ju (林相如; born 1931), was referred to as MeiMei in childhood. She was co-author of cookbooks with her mother, and was a biochemist at Queen Mary hospital in Hong Kong. The daughters all had names containing the character 如 (Ju): Adet 鳳如, Anor 玉如, and HsiangJu 相如. ==Works== ===China=== Works by Lin in Chinese or published in China to 1935 include:{{Cite web | title = {{Infobox artwork/wikidata}} The '''Mecklenburg Ancestral Table''' ({{lang-da|den Mecklenburgske anetavle}}) is an illustrated 17th-century genealogical table of 63 ancestors of [[Sophie of Mecklenburg-Güstrow|Queen Sophie of Denmark]] (1557–1631). It hangs in the [[Abbey Church, Nykøbing Falster|Abbey Church]] in [[Nykøbing Falster|Nykøbing]] on the [[Denmark|Danish]] island of [[Falster]].<ref name=natmus>[http://danmarkskirker.natmus.dk/uploads/tx_tcchurchsearch/Maribo_0206-0241.pdf Kirsten Weber-Andersen, Otto Norn, Aage Roussell, Gertrud Købke Knudsen, "Nykøbing Kirke"], ''Danmarks kirker: Maribo amt, Volume 8'', 1951, Nationalmuseet, pages 206–241. {{da icon}} Retrieved 4 December 2012.</ref>
==Description== Queen Sophie's genealogical table was the work of [[Antonius Clement]] from [[Odense]]. It was donated by the queen to Nykøbing's Abbey Church. Evert Decker, Clement's closest pupil, began the work in 1622, receiving a partial fee of 500 [[Danish rigsdaler|courant daler]] in 1624. The table, however, was not completed until 1626 when Frantz Kraeg received payment for the upper sections, one of which bears the date of fitting, 1627.<ref name=natmus/>
The table consists of boards of oak (top sections in pine) which are arranged into two halves. Its surface, covering {{convert|33|m2|abbr=on}} is painted with oils on a chalk base. It shows Queen Sophie (in the centre below the two halves) with five generations of her ancestors, 63 in all, with half-length portraits, coats-of-arms and name plates. Each row covers a generation with the queen's paternal relatives on the right and the maternal ancestors on the left.<ref name=natmus/>
[[File:Mecklenburgske anetavle.jpg|thumb|left|Antonius Clement: Mecklenburg ancestral table, detail of paternal ancestors]]
The value of the images as portraits is however limited to the closest family members, especially those of the queen dowager herself and her parents, which are considered reliable portrayals. By contrast, those of the older generations are imaginative works, often wearing equally imaginative clothing. Inscriptions are in gilded capitals on a dark background. The frame is in the [[Auricular style]] with [[putto|putti]] and angels. On the [[cornice]] below, there are small female figures representing the virtues. Both the upper sections are crowned with angels, one blowing a [[bassoon]], the other waving a palm branch. The German inscription at the top states (in summary):<ref name=natmus/>
:Sophie, Queen of Denmark, Frederik II's widow, has had this table drawn up and installed in the year 1627 in honour of her parents and for the memory of her descendants, after giving birth with the same lordly highness to seven children, Christian IV, King of Denmark, Ulrich and Johan, Dukes of Schleswig Holstein, and Elisabeth, Duchess of Braunschweig and Lüneburg, Anne, Queen of Great Britain, Augusta, Duchess of Schleswig Holstein and Hedvig, Electress of Saxony.
The table has been restored on several occasions, most recently in 1943 by N. H. Termansen. Cracks were repaired and the original base tone was revealed after being completely covered over during an earlier restoration, probably that of 1874. The table hangs on the church's north wall, on a U-shaped iron support.<ref name=natmus/>

'''Munīr al-Rayyis''' (1901–1992) was a prominent Syrian newspaper editor and writer.
Munir was born in Damascus. He studied literature at Damascus University and in 1919 began to work for the Ministry of Education. In the same year, be began writing for the newspapers ''al-Ayyam'' (Damascus) and ''al-Hayat'' (Beirut). Munir opposed the [[French Mandate for Syria and Lebanon]] imposed in 1920 and in 1925 left his job to join the revolt of [[Sultan al-Atrash]]. At the end of the revolt, in 1927, Rayyes returned to Damascus, where he was a regular writer for ''al-Hayyat''. In August 1933 Rayyes became a founder member of the [[League of Nationalist Action]], whose goal was to remove foreign political influence in the region. With the fading of the League in 1935, Rayyes moved to Palestine from 1936-38 to join [[Haj Amin al-Husseini]] in the [[1936–39 Arab revolt in Palestine]]. In 1938 he became the director of political affairs at the Damascus police department.
In 1945, Munir founded a newspaper, ''Barada'', working as its editor-in-chief, and another in support of [[Husni al-Za'im]]'s 1949 coup, called ''al-Inkilab'' (''The Coup d'Etat''). His journalism included campaigning for women's emancipation (including giving his wife, [[Thuraya Al-Hafez]], a platform; he also encouraged her to stand for election in 1953). On August 25, 1952, Barada merged with the Damascus daily paper ''al-Manar al-Jadid'' on the orders of [[Adib Shishakli]], becoming ''al-Liwaa''. The owner of ''al-Manar al-Jadid'', [[Bashir al-Ouff]], became editor-in-chief of the new paper, and Rayyes the director, until in 1954 the papers were split again. 1954 also saw a short-lived experiment with running a shareholding company to print Syria's four main papers, ''[[al-Qabas]]'', ''[[Al-Ayyam (Damascus)|al-Ayyam]]'', ''[[Alif Ba']]'', and ''[[al-Sham]]''. Rayyes supported Arab nationalist movements in the 1950s and [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] of Egypt both during and after the [[United Arab Republic]]. Rayyes supported the [[1963 Syrian coup d'état]] but once their power was established, the Baath party closed ''Barada''.
Rayyes is also noted for his book ''Al-Kitāb al-Dhahabī li'l-Thawrāt al-Waṭaniyya fī al-Mashriq al-ʿArabī: al-Thawra al-Sūriyya al-Kubrā'' (''The Golden Book of Nationalist Revolutions in the Arab East'').<ref>(Beirut: Dār al-Ṭalīʿa li'l-Ṭabāʿa wa'l-Nashr, 1966)</ref>
==Sources==
Sami M. Moubayed, ''Steel and Silk: Men and Women who Shaped Syria 1900-2000'' (Seattle: Cune Press, 2006), p. 496-98.
