{{Infobox person | name = Natsai Audrey Chieza | birth_place = [[Harare]], [[Zimbabwe]] | alma_mater = [[Central Saint Martins]]
[[University of Edinburgh]] | employer = Faber Futures | known_for = Biomaterials | website = https://www.faberfutures.com/ }} '''Natsai Audrey Chieza''' is a designer and the founder of Faber Futures,[https://www.faberfutures.com/ Faber Futures] a R&D studio that creates biologically inspired materials. She gave a 2017 [[TED talk]] on fashion's problem with pollution. She is Designer in Residence at [[Ginkgo Bioworks]]. == Early life and education == Chieza was born in Harare, [[Zimbabwe]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.designindaba.com/articles/creative-work/natsai-audrey-chieza-working-nature-help-solve-fashions-waste-problem|title=Natsai Audrey Chieza on working with nature to help solve fashion's waste problem {{!}} Design Indaba|work=Design Indaba|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en}} She moved to the [[United Kingdom]] when she was seventeen years old.{{Cite web|url=https://jonathanrjones.files.wordpress.com/2014/12/jonathan-r-jones-natsai-audrey-chieza-natural-curiosity-cover-magazine.pdf|title=Natural Curiosity|last=Jones|first=Jonathan|date=|website=Natural Curiosity|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-07}} She studied Architecture at the [[University of Edinburgh]]. She then joined [[Central Saint Martins]], where she completed a Master's in Materials Futures.{{Cite web|url=https://www.thriveglobal.com/stories/13682-designing-a-more-sustainable-future|title=Designing a More Sustainable Future|website=www.thriveglobal.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-06}} She worked with [[University College London]]'s John Ward, a Professor of Synthetic Biology, and became interested in the sustainability of [[synthetic biology]] and [[stem cell]] research.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/fashion/article/10160/1/central-st-martins-ma-textile-futures|title=Central St Martins MA / Textile Futures|last=Dazed|date=2011-04-12|work=Dazed|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.materialdriven.com/home/2016/10/4/how-to-co-cultivate-with-living-technology-in-conversation-with-natsai-audrey-chieza-faber-futures|title=How to co-cultivate with living technology: In conversation with Natsai Audrey Chieza, Faber Futures|work=MaterialDriven|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US}} During this time she was Designer in Residence at the Advanced Centre for Biochemical Engineering, [[University College London]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.craftscouncil.org.uk/content/files/Biosalon_Paper.pdf|title=Biosalon Paper|last=|first=|date=|website=Crafts Council|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-07}} == Research and career == Chieza joined the Textile Futures Research Centre.{{Cite news|url=http://rotarywasheclub.org/posts/newsletter/|title=Newsletter - Rotary WASH eClub|work=Rotary WASH eClub|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US}} She identified that [[streptomyces]] could be used as a fabric dye. [[Streptomyces]] produce [[actinorhodin]], which changes colour depending on the acidity of its environment.{{Cite news|url=http://www.designindaba.com/articles/creative-work/natsai-audrey-chieza-working-nature-help-solve-fashions-waste-problem|title=Natsai Audrey Chieza on working with nature to help solve fashion's waste problem {{!}} Design Indaba|work=Design Indaba|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en}} In ''Project Coelicolor'', these bacteria were used to dye silk scarves.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/01/stylish-silk-scarves-dyed-bacteria/|title=Stylish Silk Scarves, Dyed With Bacteria|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.faberfutures.com/projects/project-coelicolor/|title=Project Coelicolor - Faber Futures|work=Faber Futures|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en-GB}} She has exhibited at the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]], [[Science Gallery]], [[Bauhaus Dessau Foundation]], [[Harvard Art Museums]] and Audax Textile Museum.{{Cite news|url=https://www.juxtapoz.com/news/design/natsai-chieza-explains-her-process-of-using-colored-microbial-compounds-for-beautiful-textile-designs/|title=Interview: Natsai Chieza Explains Her Process of Using Colored Microbial Compounds for Beautiful Textile Designs|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en}} She was a resident designer at [[IDEO]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.ideo.com/blog/the-beautiful-future-of-living-technology|title=The Beautiful Future of Living Technology|website=www.ideo.com|access-date=2018-07-07}} She has taught at [[Central Saint Martins]] and [[The Bartlett]].{{Cite web|url=https://2018.synbiobeta.com/natsai-chieza/|title=Natsai Chieza - SynBioBeta 2018|website=2018.synbiobeta.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-07}} Chieza is concerned about pollution in the fashion industry.{{Cite web|url=http://www.zetteler.co.uk/clients/natsai-audrey-chieza|title=Zetteler - Natsai Audrey Chieza|website=Zetteler|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-07-06}} Chieza founded Faber Futures, a biomaterial research and development studio in London.{{Cite web|url=http://www.futureof.co/the-future-of-nature-by-natsai-audrey-chieza/|title=The Future of Nature by Natsai Audrey Chieza|website=The Future Of_|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-07}}{{Cite news|url=https://labiotech.eu/natsai-audrey-bacteria-clothes/|title=Color Patterns in the Clothes of the Future will be Made by Bacteria|date=2017-05-06|work=Labiotech.eu|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.promostyl.com/blog/en/faber-future-by-natsai-chieza/|title=Faber Future by Natsai Chieza {{!}} Promostyl Blog|date=2014-05-13|work=Promostyl Blog|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en-US}} She was chosen to give a [[TED talk]] in [[Tanzania]] on fashion's problem with pollution.{{Cite news|url=https://bulawayo24.com/index-id-news-sc-national-byo-114541.html|title=Zimbabwean born researcher selected to give TED Talk in Tanzania|last=eDuzeNet|work=Bulawayo24 News|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/06/21/africa/african-speakers-at-ted-global-2017/index.html|title=TED is coming to Africa, here are some of the speakers|last=CNN|first=Torera Idowu, for|work=CNN|access-date=2018-07-07}}{{Citation|last=Chieza|first=Natsai Audrey|title=Fashion has a pollution problem -- can biology fix it?|url=https://www.ted.com/talks/natsai_audrey_chieza_fashion_has_a_pollution_problem_can_biology_fix_it|language=en|access-date=2018-07-07}} In February 2018 she was named as one of [[OkayAfrica]]'s Top 100 Women.{{Cite news|url=https://100women.okayafrica.com/stem-articles/2018/2/28/natsai-audrey-chieza|title=Natsai Audrey Chieza|work=OKAYAFRICA's 100 WOMEN|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-US}} In 2018 she is launching the [[Ginkgo Bioworks]] Creative Residency in [[Boston]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.zetteler.co.uk/clients/natsai-audrey-chieza|title=Zetteler - Natsai Audrey Chieza|website=Zetteler|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-07-07}} She was a participant at the 2018 Sci Foo camp. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chieza, Natsai Audrey}} [[Category:Designers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] {{Infobox military person |name= '''Fu Lianzhang'''
'''Nelson Fu''' |birth_date=September 14, 1894 |death_date= {{death date and age|1968|3|29|1894|9|14}} |birth_place= [[Changting County|Changting]], [[Fujian]], [[Qing Dynasty|China]] |death_place= [[Beijing]], [[PRC]] |image=Fu Lianzhang.jpg |caption= |allegiance= {{PRC}} |nickname= |serviceyears=1933–1968 |rank= [[File:Lieutenant General rank insignia (PRC, 1955-1965).jpg|40px]] [[Lieutenant General]] |commands= |branch= [[File:People's Liberation Army Flag of the People's Republic of China.svg|22px]] [[People's Liberation Army]] |battles=[[Northern Expedition]], [[Long March]], [[Chinese Civil War]] |awards= [[File:中国人民解放军二级八一勋章的略章.png|45px]] [[Order of Bayi]]
(2nd Class Medal)
[[File:中国人民解放军一级解放勋章的略章.PNG|45px]] [[Order of Liberation (China)]]
(1st Class Medal) |laterwork= }} {{Chinese |pic= |s=傅连暲 |t=傅連暲 |p=Fù Liánzhāng }} [[File:Changting Zhongyang Hongse Yiyuan Jiuzhi 2013.10.06 09-38-26.jpg|thumb|Fu Lianzhang museum in [[Changting County|Changting]], Fujian]] '''Nelson Fu''' or '''Fu Lianzhang''' ({{zh|s=傅连暲}}; 1894–1968) was a Chinese doctor. He was one of the few Western-trained doctors to have made the [[Long March]] and later, in Beijing, a Vice-Minister of Public Health, to be responsible for the health of the Communist Party elite.[[Li Zhisui]], Anne F. Thurston, Hongchao Dai, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Vm9xAAAAMAAJ The private life of Chairman Mao: the memoirs of Mao's personal physician], {{ISBN|0-679-40035-4}}, 1994. In 1955, he was awarded the rank of [[lieutenant general]] of the [[People's Liberation Army]]. In the 1920s and 1930s, Fu lived and worked in the then-prefectural seat of [[Changting County|Changting]] (now [[Tingzhou, Longyan|Tingzhou town]]) in western [[Fujian]] Province. He was a senior doctor at its British Christian missionary ''Hospital of the Gospel''. During the [[Cultural Revolution]], Fu was severely persecuted and tortured by Vice Chairman [[Lin Biao]] and his subordinates, particularly [[Qiu Huizuo]]. He died in prison on March 29, 1968, at the age of 74.{{cite book|author1=[[Yan Jiaqi]] |author2=Gao Gao |title=Turbulent Decade: A History of the Cultural Revolution |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7bNooFMV12sC&pg=PA229 |date=January 1996 |publisher=University of Hawaii Press |isbn=978-0-8248-1695-7 |pages=229–231}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{First PLA lieutenant generals}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fu, Nelson}} [[Category:People persecuted to death during the Cultural Revolution]] [[Category:Communist Party of China politicians from Fujian]] [[Category:1894 births]] [[Category:1968 deaths]] [[Category:People's Republic of China politicians from Fujian]] [[Category:People from Longyan]] [[Category:Hakka people]] [[Category:People's Liberation Army generals from Fujian]] [[Category:Chinese public health doctors]] [[Category:20th-century Chinese physicians]]

'''Richard Rossi''' (born March 2, 1963) is an American [[Film director|filmmaker]], actor,<ref name="Pittsburgh Post-Gazette">{{cite news|last1=Vancheri|first1=Barbara|title=Film Notes: Strand to screen movie about Roberto Clemente|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/movies/2013/08/08/Film-Notes-Strand-to-screen-movie-about-Roberto-Clemente/stories/201308080400|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''|date=August 8, 2013}}</ref> writer, [[talk radio]] host,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rodgers-Melnick|first1=Ann|title=Revivalist accuses rivals of selling out for money, fame|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19911020&id=KN8cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GGQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1146,1418887&hl=en|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=Pittsburgh Press|date=October 20, 1991}}</ref><ref name="ppg1227">{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07361/844664-237.stm|title='Sopranos' lawsuit brings up question of idea ownership|date=December 27, 2007|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> and former [[evangelical]] minister.<ref name="Sporting News">{{cite news|last1=McMillen|first1=Gabrielle|title=Saint Roberto Clemente? Former pastor pushes canonization for Pirate|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/mlb-news/4632199-roberto-clemente-sainthood-pittsburgh-pirates-richard-rossi|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=Sporting News|date=January 12, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Rob |last=Biertempfel |title=Biertempfel: One man's cause to canonize Roberto Clemente |publisher=TribLive |date=July 19, 2014 |url=http://triblive.com/sports/pirates/6445006-74/clemente-rossi-biertempfel#axzz383KFD9lF |accessdate=September 13, 2014}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite news |first=Lawn |last=Griffiths |title=Finding Sister Aimee |publisher=GetOut |date=August 27, 2005 |url=http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/get_out/article_22e6445a-2158-54db-a716-d79178c7df9d.html |accessdate=September 13, 2014}}</ref> In 1995 Rossi went on trial for the [[attempted murder]] of his wife. She recanted her original identification of Rossi as her attacker and espoused his innocence. The case ended in a [[mistrial (law)|mistrial]] and was front-page news in Rossi's adopted hometown of Pittsburgh<ref name=Kane401/> and was widely covered by syndicated television news programs.<ref name="charisma"/><ref name="North Hills News Record">{{cite news|title=Rossi: Wife intends to sue officials|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/41688121/|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=North Hills News Record|date=January 11, 1995}}</ref> Rossi eventually was acquitted of attempted murder<ref name="Sporting News"/> but pleaded no contest to aggravated assault.<ref name="charisma"/><ref name="levin"/><ref name=kurutz/>
==Early years== Rossi's father was a professional jazz guitarist in [[West View, Pennsylvania]]; the son followed in his father's footsteps, playing the guitar on stage at age 7.<ref name="charisma"> {{cite news | last =Donnally | first =Ed | author2 = | title =Filmmaker Tells Story of 'Wounded Healer' | work = | pages = | language = | publisher =Charisma | date =October 2005 | url =https://www.charismamag.com/site-archives/154-peopleevents/people-and-events/1709-filmmaker-tells-story-of-wounded-healer | accessdate = 2017-08-23 }}</ref> [[File:Richard Rossi in 1980.jpg|thumb|right|Rossi (standing on right) age 17 with singing-songwriting partner John Walker in 1980.]] As a child, Rossi was fascinated with Pittsburgh-based faith healer [[Kathryn Kuhlman]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> After one of his father's hospitalizations for [[manic depression]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=ZumMallen|first1=Ryan|title=FEATURE: Roberto Clemente Biopic a Dream Come True|url=http://www.gazettes.com/sports/feature-roberto-clemente-biopic-a-dream-come-true/article_b4857726-2450-11e4-b669-0019bb2963f4.html|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=Gazettes|date=August 15, 2014}}</ref> Rossi landed in a surrogate family led by an evangelist who immersed him in Pentecostal preaching and outreach.<ref name="eastvalleytribune.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/story/46906 |title=Finding Sister Aimee |last=Griffiths |first=Lawn |date=August 27, 2005 |work=[[East Valley Tribune]] |accessdate=February 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090311002536/http://www.eastvalleytribune.com/story/46906 |archivedate=March 11, 2009 }}</ref> After a drug overdose,<ref name="charisma"/> he became a [[born-again]] Christian and toured as a [[rock and roll]] preacher, usually in tandem with songwriting partner Johnny Walker,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Guydon|first1=Lynda|title=Singing 'poets' spread gospel|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/89809886/|accessdate=August 16, 2016|publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''|date=October 29, 1981}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Marcia |last=Bennett |title=Their Faith Beats the Odds |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date=March 22, 1984 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ga8nAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oG0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4637,5012286&dq=john+walker+rich+rossi&hl=en |accessdate=September 25, 2014}}</ref> playing [[gospel rock]]. Rossi and his songwriting partner Walker were featured on ''[[The 700 Club]]''.<ref name="news.google.com">{{cite news |title=Their Singing and Writing Hits a High Note |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date=July 14, 1983 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19830714&id=Y55RAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pG0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=7130%2C2727599 |accessdate=September 25, 2014}}</ref>
==Pennsylvania ministries== [[File:RichardRossiHealingService.JPG|right|thumb|Richard Rossi prays for the sick at one of his [[faith healing]] services, September, 1990.]]
Rossi moved to [[Lynchburg, Virginia]] at age 18 to study at [[Liberty University]], where he earned a bachelor's and master's degree in biblical studies.<ref name="Backstage">{{cite news|last1=Horwitch|first1=Lauren|title=Actor Chad Allen's lead role in a $30 million|url=http://www.backstage.com/news/actor-chad-allens-lead-role-in-a-30-million/|accessdate=January 27, 2016|agency=Backstage, LLC|publisher=Backstage|date=February 7, 2006}}</ref>
His second church, created informally with ministry partner Jack Sims, was called "Matthew's Party," the name taken from the biblical story about Jesus eating with tax collectors and sinners at the home of [[Matthew the Apostle|Matthew]], the gospel writer.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Virginia|title=West View minister uses 'friendly' approach|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/41663235/|accessdate=January 11, 2016|agency=Gannett Publishing|issue=Front Page|publisher=North Hills News Record|date=September 5, 1986}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Buursma|first1=Bruce|title=Minister Caters To Yuppie Tastes|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-10-03/news/8603140547_1_baby-boomers-church-growth-evangelism|accessdate=January 11, 2016|publisher=''Chicago Tribune''|date=October 3, 1986}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Perman|first1=Stacy|title=In-N-Out Burger|date=2009|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=9780061872143|page=217|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PVLwhCRIjXoC&pg=PA191&lpg=PA191&dq=jack+sims++matthew%27s+party+richard+rossi&source=bl&ots=jredwtUudf&sig=F7OBwoYrn8ELx723Z4oP2UgPCQo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=RlkkUO3gMejA2gWs0ICIDg&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=jack%20sims%20%20matthew%27s%20party%20richard%20rossi&f=false|accessdate=December 25, 2015}}</ref> In 1986, Rossi started First Love, a [[charismatic (movement)|charismatic]] church. He rented movie theaters and showed films as an evangelistic outreach. Dramatic faith healings allegedly occurred. The healing services, called "Healing Clinics,"<ref>{{cite news|title=Having faith: Adams pastor holds fifth healing clinic|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/41729162/|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=North Hills News Record|date=December 12, 1992}}</ref> grew from 200 to 2000. Rossi filmed the healings and co-produced a Fox TV documentary on faith healing and exorcism in 1992 entitled ''Quest for Truth''. The program first aired during the fall season on [[WPGH-TV]] 53 and WPTT-TV 22.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="eastvalleytribune.com"/><ref name="christianitytoday.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/movies/reviews/2005/aimeesemplemcpherson.html|title=Aimee Semple McPherson|last=Armstrong|first=Chris|date=January 1, 2005|work=[[Christianity Today]]|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Allen|first1=Sue|title=Spirit Release|date=March 15, 2007|publisher=6th Books|isbn=978-1846940330|page=1|edition=First|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VSXtBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT15&lpg=PT15&dq=richard+rossi+actor&source=bl&ots=rCFqiyFUgU&sig=MXdYl6QinwOqII8m7gufaw0B5Q8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=FOLNVPvZNJCzoQSu0YHwBw&ved=0CEwQ6AEwCDg8#v=onepage&q=richard%20rossi%20actor&f=false|accessdate=December 24, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Miracles|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2002&dat=19930110&id=K6dUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gTsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2657,1803449&hl=en|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=Beaver County Times|date=January 10, 1993}}</ref>
In 1988, Rossi tried and failed to change both the name of the Church of the Three Rivers and its affiliation.<ref name="levin">{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08125/878975-85.stm|title=Rev. Rossi back in news as Hollywood success story|last=Levin|first=Steve|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|accessdate=February 19, 2010 | date=May 4, 2008}}</ref> He then joined the [[Assemblies of God]] the next year and led the [[Cranberry Township, Butler County, Pennsylvania|Cranberry]] church, but left in 1991, saying that his ministry was too radical for the Assemblies; church officials said he left owing several thousand dollars for the church building.<ref name="levin"/>
In September 1991, Rossi began broadcasting his nightly radio show ''Rich Rossi Live'' on Pittsburgh's [[WPIT|WPIT-FM]]. The program created controversy when Rossi called other evangelical churches "whores" who sell out the gospel for money.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rodgers-Melnick|first1=Ann|title=Revivalist accuses rivals of selling out for money, fame|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19911020&id=KN8cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GGQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1146,1418887|accessdate=December 25, 2015|publisher=The Pittsburgh Press|date=October 20, 1991}}</ref> Rossi appeared on the [[Jerry Springer Show]] in 1994 to discuss faith healing, exorcism, and ESP.<ref name="ppg60494">{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/89380661/|title=Museum Fetes Fred Rogers|date=June 4, 1994|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|accessdate=17 October 2017}}</ref>
==Attempted murder charge== On June 24, 1994, Rossi's wife, Sherrie Lynn, was found near death in a coma on the side of a Pennsylvania road. She had a crushed skull and was left covered in blood; her injuries were so severe that she needed to wear a helmet.<ref name=levin/><ref name=kurutz/><ref name=Kane>{{cite news| author=Karen Kane| publisher=''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''| date=October 13, 1994| title='My Husband Is Not To Blame'| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=h7cxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cW8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4910,9263794| page=A1}}</ref><ref name=Phillips>{{cite news| title=Pastor Wins By Default| author=Kim Phillips| publisher=[[Long Beach Press-Telegram]]| date=November 21, 1999| page=A2}}</ref> Her rescuers thought she had been in a traffic accident, and called for an ambulance.<ref name="kane121">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g64zAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nm4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6648,1492139&dq=richard-rossi+lawsuit&hl=en|title=Beating testimony ruled admissible|last=Kane|first=Karen|date=January 21, 1995|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|pages=B-6|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> Ninety minutes later, at 8:05 pm, Richard Rossi called police, and claimed that men killed his wife and shot at him twice.<ref name="kane121"/> But when police came to interview him, his story changed, first claiming that a man that looked like him got into the passenger side of the car, then that the man who looked like him attacked from the driver's side.<ref name="kane121"/> Rossi had a cellular phone available, but said he pursued the assailant instead of dialing for help because he was a "good runner."<ref name="kane121"/> Rossi also changed his story on where the assailants approached from, first saying they were in a white car, then that they "came out of the woods out of nowhere."<ref name=kane121/> Police testified that Rossi told them a "satanic cult" was trying to frame him; Rossi denies this.<ref name=kane121/><ref name="Gabbay">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RegyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vAcGAAAAIBAJ&pg=6848,2153509|title=Church troubles: Work of Satan?|last=Gabbay|first=Alyssa|date=January 14, 1995|publisher=[[Associated Press]]|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref><ref name=trauma/> Rossi was wearing only a pair of tan shorts when police interviewed him; Rossi claimed that he lost his shirt running through the woods, but did not explain why he was barefoot.<ref name=kane121/> Several witnesses reported seeing a man with long hair near the Rossi's cars, and State Police reports suggested the presence of two other cars, one blue and one white.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rossi's trial a whodunit with reluctant key witness|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2002&dat=19950326&id=ULsiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TLUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1442,6819844|accessdate=December 25, 2015|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Beaver County Times|date=March 26, 1995}}</ref>
Ms. Rossi twice testified that her husband attacked her and left her for dead.<ref name=levin/><ref name=Kane/> Sherrie Lynn received an order of protection from a court. But in October 1994, Sherrie withdrew her accusation; a state court judge refused her request to void the order of protection.<ref name=Kane/><ref name=Gabbay/> (Press accounts claimed that Ms. Rossi stated that her attacker might have been a demon in human form, but the Rossis deny she said this.)<ref name=Kane/><ref name=Gabbay/><ref name=trauma/> Sherrie's stepbrother, Mark Plaugher, accused the Rossi family of pressuring her to change her story; her father said she had been "brainwashed," and Sherrie's stepfather, Phil Plaugher, said that church members pressured Sherrie by telling her that it was a sin to testify against one's husband.<ref name=Kane95/><ref name="ppg1105">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_YoNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AnADAAAAIBAJ&pg=6147,2027691&dq=sherrie-rossi%27s-kin-doubt-her-husband&hl=en|title=Family advice shunned: Sherri Rossi's kin doubt her husband|last=Rodgers-Melnick|first=Ann|date=November 5, 1994|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|pages=C1, C7|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
Sherrie Rossi testified in the trial that her attacker was a different man with brown eyes and that Rossi's eyes are blue. She said her earlier testimony against Rossi was coerced by police when she was still recovering and did not have a complete recollection, and that her second testimony exonerating her husband came from "flashbacks" and a "fuller complete recollection" of what occurred.<ref name="North Hills News Record"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Trial, Wedding Renewal Set for Minister Accused of Wife Beating|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1995/Trial-Wedding-Renewal-Set-for-Minister-Accused-of-Wife-Beating/id-405f68635a377208e4a983fd26926e57|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=Associated Press}}</ref> Sherrie Rossi said: "We have eyewitnesses who saw a white car similar to ours following us and several family members several weeks before I was attacked. My husband also received a number of threats before I was attacked."<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite news|last1=Walsh|first1=Lawrence|title=Love and near-death: Sherrie Rossi announces book|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19951125&id=WCMxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uG8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4017,2579150|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''|date=November 25, 1995}}</ref> Over Rossi's wife's objections, prosecutors charged him with attempted murder and won a court ruling admitting her earlier testimony at trial.<ref name=kane121/> The parties argued whether the blood-soaked interior of Rossi's car was consistent with Sherrie's claim.<ref name=Kane401/> The secretary of Rossi's church testified that Rossi asked him shortly after the incident to forge an [[alibi]].<ref name="kane330">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=b-8NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bW4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6887,9342638&dq=richard-rossi+demons&hl=en|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130124144229/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=b-8NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bW4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6887,9342638&dq=richard-rossi+demons&hl=en|dead-url=yes|archive-date=January 24, 2013|title=Cover story by Rossi alleged|last=Kane|first=Karen|date=March 30, 1995|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|pages=A1, A3|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> The defense called two witnesses, a church member and Rossi's mother, for a total of a half-hour of testimony; Rossi himself did not testify.<ref name="kane331">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cO8NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bW4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4906,9760088&hl=en|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130124134312/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cO8NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bW4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4906,9760088&hl=en|dead-url=yes|archive-date=January 24, 2013|title=Rossi jury to begin deliberations|last=Kane|first=Karen|date=March 31, 1995|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|pages=A1, A11|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
[[File:RossiHungJury.JPG|right|thumb|After hearing of the hung jury, Rossi attorney Jim Ecker (foreground) faces the press with attorney Alexander H. Lindsay, Richard Rossi (3rd from left, behind Ecker), and Attorney Susan Jackson at the [[Butler County Courthouse (Pennsylvania)]] on March 31, 1995.]]A five-day trial ended in a [[hung jury]], with the vote 9–3 in favor of conviction after six and a half hours of deliberation.<ref name="Kane401">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ce8NAAAAIBAJ&sjid=j24DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2747,1885&dq=karen+kane+assault+rossi&hl=en|title=Rossi jurors can't decide|last=Kane|first=Karen|date=April 1, 1995|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|pages=A1|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref><ref name=Kane95>{{cite news| author=Karen Kane| date=May 19, 1995| publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''| title=No-contest plea entered for assault| page=A1}}</ref> Before retrial, Rossi [[plea bargain|pleaded]] [[nolo contendre|no contest]] to a count of second-degree aggravated assault while maintaining his innocence. Though his followers wanted him to fight what his wife called an "assault of justice," Rossi stated he pled nolo contendre to end the ordeal. "One of my many goals is to heal our family and become the best husband and father I can be," Rossi said to the judge.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dold|first1=R. Bruce|title=Pastor Sentenced To Jail In Wife's Beating|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-05-19/news/9505200061_1_no-contest-plea-jail-and-four-years-sentenced|accessdate=December 23, 2016|agency=Chicago Tribune|date=May 19, 1995}}</ref> He received a four-to-eight-month sentence in [[Butler County, Pennsylvania|Butler County]] Jail plus four years probation and required domestic violence counseling; he served 96 days.<ref name=Kane95/><ref name=PPG95>{{cite news| title=Rossi renewal blocked| publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''| date=June 26, 1995| page=C4}}</ref><ref name=Lucky>{{cite news| title='Lucky' man is out of jail| date=August 30, 1995| author=Karen Kane and Mark Belko| publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''| page=B1}}</ref> [[Domestic violence]] workers criticized the short sentence.<ref>{{cite news| title=Rev's 4-month jail term for beating wife ripped sends bad message, Victims Center says| date=May 20, 1995| publisher=[[Philadelphia Daily News]]| author=[[Associated Press]]| page=9}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title=Domestic violence workers score 'obscene' Rossi term| publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''| author=Cindi Lash| date=May 19, 1995| page=A9}}</ref> The Rossis renewed their wedding vows after his release.<ref name=PPG95/> Rossi wrote an apologetic letter to the ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' saying: "I repent of the sins I have committed and, with God's help, do not plan to repeat them."<ref name="eagle913">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=l2QlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=n6YFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6011,7432457&dq=sherrie-rossi&hl=en|title=Pastor seeks public forgiveness|date=September 13, 1996|work=[[Reading Eagle]]|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
Sherrie Rossi, who had campaigned for her husband's exoneration, sued state and county officials for abridging her civil rights when courts refused to lift a bond restriction forbidding her husband to contact her while he was out on bail; the suit was dismissed by a federal court.<ref name=Lucky/><ref>''Rossi v. Court of Butler, et al.'', No. 2:95-cv-01144-WLS-KJB (W.D. Pa.).</ref> In 1996, Sherrie self-published ''Assault of Justice: The Richard Rossi Mystery'', defending her husband and proclaiming his innocence, and claiming that charges were retaliation for exposing police corruption and a satanic cult on his [[talk radio]] show.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rodgers-Melnick|first1=Ann|title=Revivalist accuses rivals of selling out for money, fame|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19911020&id=KN8cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GGQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1146,1418887&hl=en|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=The Pittsburgh Press|date=October 20, 1991}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Walsh|first1=Lawrence|title=Love and near-death: Sherrie Rossi announces book|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19951125&id=WCMxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uG8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4017,2579150&hl=en|accessdate=December 25, 2015|publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''|date=November 25, 1995}}</ref> She said eyewitnesses confirmed her husband's innocence and that they had been receiving threats prior to the assault.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> An unsupported press release asserted Rossi was innocent (based on physical evidence and the testimony of eyewitnesses).<ref name=trauma>{{cite press release | title =The Trauma of Being Falsely Accused | date =July 14, 2007 | url =http://www.free-press-release.com/news/200707/1184439295.html | accessdate = 2007-07-31 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Trial, Wedding Renewal Set for Minister Accused of Wife Beating|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1995/Trial-Wedding-Renewal-Set-for-Minister-Accused-of-Wife-Beating/id-405f68635a377208e4a983fd26926e57|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=Associated Press|date=April 3, 1995}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last=Rossi|first=Sherrie Lynn|title=Assault of Justice: The Rev. Richard Rossi Mystery|publisher=Eternal Grace|year=1996|isbn=0-9652330-0-6}}</ref>
While charges were pending and Rossi served his sentence, membership in his church dropped from 300 to 12.<ref name=Lucky/> Media scrutiny of his trials and tribulations revealed Rossi suffered mental health, depression, and addiction issues similar to his father's. Rossi enrolled in a recovery program in jail that he continued after his release, including meetings four days a week, daily monitoring, and treatment in [[Atlanta]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Richard Rossi seeks the power of forgiveness|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19960912&id=fKBSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3X0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2519,1522358&hl=en|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''|date=September 12, 1996}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Rubin|first1=Marty|title=Famous Faces of Bipolar ~ YOU CAN BE ANYTHING YOU CHOOSE TO BE ~|url=http://www.marcyrubin.com/Famous_People_With_Bipolar.html|website=Marty Rubin: Professional Life Coach|publisher=Rubin Publishing|accessdate=September 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cohen|first1=Doctor Martin|title=Bipolar Celebrities|url=https://bipolardirectory.wordpress.com/bipolar-celebrities/|website=Bipolar Directory|publisher=Psychology Inc.|accessdate=September 7, 2016}}</ref>
After his release from jail, Rossi and his wife hosted a free Thanksgiving dinner for the homeless at the Ranch House in Pittsburgh's North Park. Rossi paid for buses to transport urban children out of high-crime areas to the park. Most of the buses got to those wanting to come, but one had difficulty getting to the arranged pick-up due to snow. [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]]s danced and helped Rossi serve dinners to disadvantaged children. Some of his fellow inmates Rossi befriended in jail attended to help serve the poor.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Walsh|first1=Lawrence|title=Troubles don't dampen Rossis' hospitality|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19951124&id=VyMxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uG8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3364,109383&hl=en|accessdate=March 31, 2016|publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''|date=November 24, 1995}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Walsh|first1=Lawrence|title=Rossis to host Thanksgiving festival|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/89634525/|accessdate=April 1, 2016|publisher=''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette''|date=November 16, 1995}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Rossis plan event for inner-city children|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/41851820/|accessdate=April 1, 2016|agency=TribLive|publisher=North Hills News Record|date=November 17, 1995}}</ref>
==California== After completing his probation,<ref name=levin/> Rossi relocated to [[Hollywood, Los Angeles|Hollywood]] with his wife and two children in 1997. He returned to preaching, serving as a pastor and church consultant, and moved into acting and filmmaking to explore his interest in creative and cutting-edge expressions of ministry.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
His tenure as pastor at Immanuel Baptist Church was interrupted when parishioners discovered his attempted murder charges and alleged that he had misused church money; litigation ensued, and the parties settled out of court.<ref name="levin"/><ref name=Phillips/><ref>{{cite news| publisher=Long Beach Press-Telegram| date=November 20, 1999| title=Pastor faces suit for revising bylaws of church}}</ref> Rossi's first Hollywood role was in the 1998 short film ''Jesus 2000''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Loeffler|first1=William|title=Minister Answers Call From Hollywood|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/41828874/|accessdate=24 August 2017|agency=North Hills News Record|issue=Front Page|date=December 6, 1997}}</ref> In 1998, he appeared on stage in his own adaptation of ''[[Elmer Gantry]]'', which he wrote, produced and starred. His stage performance resulted in an offer to Rossi to play the role in a new film version.<ref name="christianitytoday.com"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Chaudhri seeking investors to remake 'Elmer Gantry|url=http://www2.sharonherald.com/localnews/recentnews/9904/ln040699c.html|accessdate=December 25, 2015|publisher=Sharon Herald|date=April 6, 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PG&p_theme=pg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB48F8AEE4DE58D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | date=April 7, 1999|title=ROSSI IN REMAKE }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Local filmmaker to remake classic|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GElIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=64EMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2484,2996848&dq=richard+rossi+movie&hl=en|accessdate=December 25, 2015|publisher=The Vindicator|date=April 5, 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Controversial clergyman tapped for remake of film 'Elmer Gantry'|url=http://www2.sharonherald.com/localnews/recentnews/9904/ln040599a.html|accessdate=December 25, 2015|publisher=The Herald|date=April 5, 1999}}</ref>
He started "Eternal Grace", a movement of Hollywood [[house church]]es for actors and celebrities who had difficulty attending public services due to [[paparazzi]], and also for AIDS victims and others not welcome to attend other churches.<ref name="Backstage"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Wooding|first1=Dan|title=Maverick Minister Richard Rossi Goes Hollywood |url=http://www.sloppynoodle.com/wp/maverick-minister-richard-rossi-goes-hollywood/|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=Assist News|date=February 6, 2011 }}</ref><ref name="Charisma Magazine">{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Ken|title=God is Out of the Box|url=http://www.charismamag.com/site-archives/447-features/ministry-trends/1940-god-is-out-of-the-box|accessdate=September 22, 2016|publisher=Strang Publishing|date=May 31, 2006}}</ref> He was protested by followers of [[Fred Phelps]] from [[Westboro Baptist Church]] of [[Topeka, Kansas]], who decried his lenient attitude toward homosexuals.<ref name="levin"/> Rossi's wife Sherrie worked with puppets in their children's ministry.<ref name="levin"/>
In 2001, Rossi wrote and directed ''Saving Sister Aimee'', a short documentary film about 1920s evangelist [[Aimee McPherson]]. Though some considered it a sensationalized depiction, it won the Angel Award from the Southern California Motion Picture Council for best documentary.<ref name="charisma"/>
In 2005, Rossi revisited Sister Aimee's story in the low-budget feature biographical film ''[[Sister Aimee: The Aimee Semple McPherson Story]]'', (aka ''Aimee Semple McPherson''), featuring [[Mimi Michaels]] in the lead and [[Rance Howard]] as the preacher's father. It was voted one of the greatest guerrilla films of all time, and attracted a record crowd to Hollywood's [[New Beverly Cinema]], a revival house specializing in independent and cult films owned by [[Quentin Tarantino]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Donnally|first1=Ed|title=Filmmaker Tells Story of "Wounded Healer"|url=https://charismamag.com/component/content/article/154-j15/peopleevents/people-and-events/1709-filmmaker-tells-story-of-wounded-healer|accessdate=20 February 2018|agency=Charisma Magazine|publisher=Strang Publications|date=September 30, 2005}}</ref><ref name="levin"/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BCAB&p_theme=bcab&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FEEC61B9DD3BFDA&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work=Bakersfield Californian, The | date=November 19, 2003|title=Movie on founder of Four Square filmed here}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gilbert|first1=Ryan|title=Hallelujah! How Faith Healer Aimee Semple McPherson Inspired the Rip-Roaring New Musical Scandalous|url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/165228/hallelujah-how-faith-healer-aimee-semple-mcpherson-inspired-the-rip-roaring-new-musical-scandalous/|publisher=Broadway Buzz|date=November 5, 2012}}</ref> A group of [[Evangelicalism|Evangelicals]] offered to invest $2 million in the film, but with conditions that the movie did not depict McPherson's divorce or drug overdose and that the actor playing the lead be a [[Pentecostalism|Pentecostal]] Christian. Rossi turned them down. "By saying no to conditions that religious people put on me, I feel I'm actually of more service to God and people because I make an honest film," he said.<ref name="Backstage"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Wooding|first1=Dan|title=Maverick Minister Richard Rossi Goes Hollywood|url=http://www.sloppynoodle.com/wp/maverick-minister-richard-rossi-goes-hollywood/|accessdate=January 28, 2016|agency=Sloppy Noodle Inc.|publisher=Assist News Service|date=February 5, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Boyer|first1=David|title=Filmmaker Interviews|url=https://davidbboyerscreenwriter.weebly.com/interviews.html|accessdate=11 October 2017|date=April 3, 2010}}</ref> In addition to his film work, Rossi acted on stage in plays and musicals to positive reviews, remaining active in the Los Angeles theater community.<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Neal|first1=Dink|title=Modern Love|url=http://www.backstage.com/review/la-theater/modern-love/|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=Backstage|date=January 23, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Weaver|first1=Neal|title=Modern Love|url=http://www.laweekly.com/2009-02-05/calendar/modern-love/|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=L.A. Rossi's telling of Clemente's story of commitment, loyalty, and devotion attempts to provide a counterpoint to today's baseball culture of players suspected of steroid abuse.<ref name="levin"/><ref name="kurutz">{{cite news|url=http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/cityregion/s_581757.html|title=Minister jailed for beating wife in '94 plans return to Pittsburgh|last=Kurutz|first=Daveen Rae|date=August 8, 2008|work=[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Chantler|first1=Carrie|title=Capturing Clemente: Film about Pittsburgh Pirates legend makes NY premiere in Auburn|url=http://auburnpub.com/entertainment/capturing-clemente-film-about-baseball-legend-makes-ny-premiere-in/article_9ee3f3d4-66b2-5943-9f90-5981fc16fdc6.html|accessdate=December 25, 2015|agency=The Citizen|publisher=Auburn Pub|date=August 29, 2013}}</ref> The dramatic fulcrum of ''Baseball's Last Hero'' is a conversation Clemente has with a nun. "She talks to him about the cross. 'Greater love has no man than to lay down his life for his friends,' is what the nun quotes to him from Scripture, talking about sacrificial love and Christ's sacrificial love," Rossi said. "This is the theme I wanted to point out – an allegory of Christ on the cross." Rossi was pressured to delete the scene from the movie for being "too preachy and too Catholic."

SPORTS|publisher=Sporting News|date=August 17, 2017}}</ref>
==Recent news== === 2014–2015 === On November 28, 2014, Rossi was in the news again regarding the controversy over the [[shooting of Michael Brown]]. Rossi wrote and recorded a [[protest song]] expressing his feelings about a grand jury's decision not to charge a white police officer in the death of the unarmed black teen in [[Ferguson, Missouri]]. "I wrote the song in five minutes as a way to express my emotions about the danger of trigger-happy police," Rossi said. "I filmed it on my laptop at my kitchen table and uploaded it to YouTube." Rossi uploaded the video on November 26, and provided the song's lyrics in the video description. Here is a sample from the song's beginning, printed in the ''[[Los Angeles Daily News]]'': "Down at the courthouse on a Monday afternoon/Justice was thrown right out the window when a young white cop entered the room."<ref>{{cite news|title=Valley Village singer responds to Ferguson with YouTube protest song|url=http://www.dailynews.com/government-and-politics/20141128/valley-village-singer-responds-to-ferguson-with-youtube-protest-song|accessdate=December 24, 2015|publisher=Los Angeles Daily News|date=November 28, 2014}}</ref>
Rossi continues to host his radio talk-show "''Richard Rossi Live''" as a [[podcast]] on [[BlogTalkRadio]]. In 2015, the format of the program changed from its Christian roots on [[WPIT]], a [[Salem Radio Network]] station, by broadening its content for a general audience.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rodgers-Melnick|first1=Ann|title=Revivalist accuses rivals of selling out for money, fame|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=19911020&id=KN8cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GGQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1146,1418887&hl=en|accessdate=December 22, 2015|publisher=Pittsburgh Press|date=October 20, 1991}}</ref> Although Rossi still on occasion discusses religion, the program's focus is on known artists, writers, and celebrity guests.
Following the positive Pittsburgh reception to Rossi's Roberto Clemente project, Rossi said enough time had passed for him and his wife to forgive the media in his hometown for writing untruths about them. Rossi said they were finally coming home, living "bicoastal," maintaining homes in [[Hollywood]] and [[Pittsburgh]]. "We'd like to spend more time in our home, where most of our family and friends live, in the North Hills of Pittsburgh," Rossi said.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kurutz|first1=Daveen Rae|title=Minister Jailed for Beating Wife in '94 Plans Return to Pittsburgh|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-16989077.html|accessdate=January 8, 2016|agency=High Beam Research|publisher=Pittsburgh Tribune Review|date=August 8, 2008}}</ref>[[File:Richard Rossi playing guitar in scene from new film Canaan Land. Drummer D.J. Peligro from Dead Kennedys is on drums.jpeg|right|thumb|Richard Rossi playing guitar in scene from his new film ''Canaan Land'' with [[D.H. Peligro]] on drums. (April 17, 2017)]]
=== 2016–Present === In March, 2016, it was reported that Rossi is in [[pre-production]] on his new film ''Canaan Land''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hill|first1=Tim|title=Televangelists Threaten Controversial New Film ‘Canaan Land’ That Exposes Charismatic Movement’s ‘Frauds’|url=http://www.faithnews.cc/?p=22019|accessdate=August 5, 2016|publisher=Faith News Network|date=March 4, 2016}}</ref> On October 17, 2016, it was announced that [[Claudia Wells]], an actress who starred in the 1985 film ''[[Back to the Future]]'' was cast in the lead role of Sister Sara Sunday.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Friedlander|first1=Monique|title=Back to the Future’s Jennifer — AKA actress, Claudia Wells — reveals secrets from the film|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3848086/Back-Future-star-Claudia-Wells-says-kiss-Michael-J-Fox-says-share-connection.html|accessdate=October 18, 2016|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=October 18, 2016}}</ref> However, as controversy regarding the film grew, the following month the actress "no longer wants her name associated with the controversy," according to a casting associate.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marziale|first1=Father Mario|title=Pope Francis Praises Controversial Canaan Land Faith Film as Actresses Wrestle with Publicity Storm|url=http://christiannewswire.com/news/877478787.html|accessdate=March 29, 2017|publisher=Christian News Wire|date=November 30, 2016}}</ref>
On May 15, 2017, Rossi announced that [[Rebecca Holden]], known from [[Knight Rider (1982 TV series)|''Knight Rider'' (1982 TV series)]], was cast in the lead role of Sister Sara Sunday.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Heyman|first1=Macie|title=Knight Rider Star Rebecca Holden Lands Coveted Canaan Land Evangelist Role|url=http://www.military-technologies.net/2017/05/15/knight-rider-star-rebecca-holden-lands-coveted-canaan-land-evangelist-role/|accessdate=15 May 2017|agency=International Military Press|publisher=Military-Technologies|date=May 15, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Sarah|title=Film Director Richard Rossi Partners with Clapit in Nationwide Open Call Auditions for "Canaan Land"|url=http://dailytelescope.com/pr/film-director-richard-rossi-partners-with-clapit-in-nationwide-open-call-auditions-for-canaan-land/21564|accessdate=29 November 2017|agency=Daily Telescope|date=November 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Reyes|first1=Liz|title=Film Director Richard Rossi Partners with Clapit in Nationwide Open Call Auditions for "Canaan Land"|url=http://www.fox8live.com/story/36955346/film-director-richard-rossi-partners-with-clapit-in-nationwide-open-call-auditions-for-canaan-land|accessdate=30 November 2017|agency=Fox News|publisher=Channel 8|date=November 29, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Bernstein|first1=Jack|title=Edgy Faith-Based Film Already Stirring Controversy, Building SAG Buzz|url=https://www.charismanews.com/culture/68997-edgy-faith-based-film-already-stirring-controversy-building-sag-buzz|accessdate=17 January 2018|agency=Charisma Magazine|publisher=Charisma News, Strang Publications|date=January 8, 2018}}</ref>
On September 30, 2017, CBS KCAL9 news reported on Rossi's founding of the support group ''Families Fighting Fentanyl'' to combat the [[fentanyl]] epidemic, to help addicts, work with law enforcement to hold drug dealers accountable, and support grieving families who lost a loved one to fentanyl. Rossi discussed the 2017 death of his youngest brother due to an overdose of heroin laced with fentanyl.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Huggins|first1=Amy Johnson|title=Actor Richard Rossi Discusses Founding Of Group 'Families Fighting Fentanyl'|url=http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/video/3738840-actor-richard-rossi-discusses-founding-of-group-families-fighting-fentanyl/|accessdate=30 September 2017|agency=CBS|publisher=KCAL9, CBS Los Angeles|date=September 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Di Pietro|first1=Paula|title=Filmmaker Fights Fentanyl|url=http://www.huntingtonnews.net/151997|accessdate=3 October 2017|agency=Huntington News|publisher=AP, Huntington, W.V.|date=October 3, 2017}}</ref> On January 31, 2018, Rossi and his family, in tandem with [[Pittsburgh Police]], offered a cash reward for information leading to the arrest of the individual(s) who gave his brother the fatal fentanyl dose.<ref>{{cite news|title=ROSSIS OFFER REWARD TO SOLVE BROTHERS FENTANYL DEATH|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K7_yE8Ys9L8&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=1 February 2018|agency=CBS|publisher=KDKA News, Pittsburgh|date=January 31, 2018}}</ref>

Accessed 4 May 2014.</ref> | field = [[Mixed media]], [[Painting]] | training = MFA [[University of Saskatchewan]] (1985)<ref name=bio/> | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = [[German Expressionism]], [[Abstract Expressionism]], [[Art Povera]], [[Art Informel]]<ref name=bio/> | influenced = | awards = [[Eiteljorg Fellowship]] (1999)<ref name=e99/> | elected = | website = http://www.rickrivet.ca/ }} '''Rick Rivet''' (born 1949 in [[Aklavik]], [[Northwest Territories]]) is a [[Sahtu]]–[[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] [[painter]] living in [[Canada]].
==Background and education== Rivet's family lived both in the country and in town at Aklavik, which was a [[Métis]] trading center. Métis have a specific culture with [[First Nations]] and [[European ethnic groups|European]] roots. He began school in Aklavik at age seven.<ref name=bio>[http://www.rickrivet.ca/biography.php "About Rick Rivet."] ''Rick Rivet.''] 2014. Accessed 4 May 2014.</ref>
River earned four degrees: his Bachelor of Arts from the [[University of Alberta]] in 1972; his Bachelor of Fine Arts from the [[University of Victoria]] in 1980; his Master of Fine Arts from the [[University of Saskatchewan]] in 1985, and Bachelor of Education from the [[University of Saskatchewan]] in 1986.<ref name=bio/>
==Artwork== His art is deeply influenced by ideas of fusion and hybridity of cultures.<ref>{{cite book|title=Contemporary Masters: The Eiteljorg Fellowship for Native American Fine Art, Vol. I|date=1999|publisher=Eiteljorg Museum of American Indians and Western Art|location=Indianapolis, IN|isbn=0-9635492-2-7|page=32}}</ref> He works primarily in acrylic on canvas in a style he as referred to as "an expressionist/primitivist approach."<ref>{{cite book|last=Ostrowitz|first=Judith|title=Privileging the Past: Reconstructing History in Northwest Coast Art|date=1999|publisher=University of Washington Press|page=150}}</ref>

{{Redirect|Rudolf II| |Rudolph II (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Rudolf II & I | image = AACHEN, Hans von - Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II - WGA.jpg | full name = | caption = Portrait by [[Hans von Aachen]] | succession = {{longitem |col1style=padding-top:0.2em | {{Collapsible list |title=[[Holy Roman Emperor]]|titlestyle=background:transparent;text-align:center;padding-center:1.0em; | ---- {{Aligned table |fullwidth=on |cols=2 |class=nowrap |style=line-height:1.2em; |col1style=padding-right:0.5em; | '''[[Holy Roman Emperor]]''' | 1576–1612 | '''[[King of the Romans]]''' | 1575–1612 | '''[[List of Bohemian monarchs|King of Bohemia]]''' | 1575–1611 | '''[[List of Hungarian monarchs|King of Hungary]] [[List of rulers of Croatia|and Croatia]]''' | 1572–1608 | '''[[Archduke of Austria]]''' | 1576–1612 }} }} }} | reign = 12 October 1576 –
20 January 1612 | coronation = | predecessor = [[Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian II]] | successor = [[Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor|Matthias]] | house = [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] | father = [[Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian II]] | mother = [[Maria of Spain]] | birth_date = 18 July 1552 | birth_place = [[Vienna]], Austria | death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|1612|1|20|1552|07|18}} | death_place = [[Prague]], [[Kingdom of Bohemia|Bohemia]] | date of burial = | place of burial = [[St. Vitus Cathedral]], [[Prague]] | religion = [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]] |}} '''Rudolf II''' (18 July 1552 – 20 January 1612) was [[Holy Roman Emperor]] (1576–1612), [[King of Hungary]] and [[Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)|Croatia]] (as '''Rudolf I''', 1572–1608), [[King of Bohemia]] (1575–1608/1611) and [[Archduke of Austria]] (1576–1608). He was a member of the [[House of Habsburg]]. Rudolf's legacy has traditionally been viewed in three ways:Hotson, 1999. an ineffectual ruler whose mistakes led directly to the [[Thirty Years' War]]; a great and influential patron of [[Northern Mannerist]] art; and an intellectual devotee of occult arts and learning which helped seed what would be called the [[scientific revolution]]. ==Early life== [[Image:Archdukerudolf.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Archduke Rudolf, aged 15, painted by [[Alonso Sánchez Coello]]]] Rudolf was born in [[Vienna]] on 18 July 1552. He was the eldest son and successor of [[Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian II]], Holy Roman Emperor, King of [[Bohemia]], and King of Hungary and [[Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)|Croatia]]; his mother was [[Maria of Spain]], a daughter of [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]] and [[Isabella of Portugal]]. He was the elder brother of [[Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor|Matthias]] who was to succeed him as king of Bohemia and Holy Roman Emperor. Rudolf spent eight formative years, from age 11 to 19 (1563–1571), in Spain, at the court of his maternal uncle [[Philip II of Spain|Philip II]]. After his return to Vienna, his father was concerned about Rudolf's aloof and stiff manner, typical of the more conservative Spanish court, rather than the more relaxed and open Austrian court; but his Spanish mother saw in him courtliness and refinement.Marshall, 2006. Rudolf would remain for the rest of his life reserved, secretive, and largely a homebody who did not like to travel or even partake in the daily affairs of state. He was more intrigued by occult learning such as astrology and alchemy, which was mainstream in the [[Renaissance]] period, and had a wide variety of personal hobbies such as horses, clocks, collecting rarities, and being a patron of the arts. He suffered from periodic bouts of "[[Depression (mood)|melancholy]]" (depression), which was common in the Habsburg line. These became worse with age, and were manifested by a withdrawal from the world and its affairs into his private interests. ==Personal life== [[File:Portrait bust of Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor, Antwerp City Hall, Belgium - 20150629-03.jpg|thumb|upright|A portrait bust of Rudolf II in the collection of the [[Antwerp City Hall]], Belgium]] Like his near contemporary, [[Elizabeth I of England]] (who was born 19 years before he was), Rudolf dangled himself as a prize in a string of diplomatic negotiations for marriages, but never in fact married. During his periods of self-imposed isolation, Rudolf reportedly had affairs with his court chamberlain, Wolfgang von Rumpf, and a series of valets. One of these, Philip Lang, ruled him for years and was hated by those seeking favour with the emperor.Rowse, 1977. In addition, Rudolf was known to have had a succession of affairs with women, some of whom claimed to have been impregnated by him. He had several illegitimate children with his mistress [[Catherina Strada]]. Their eldest son, [[Don Julius Caesar d'Austria]], was likely born between 1584 and 1586 and received an education and opportunities for political and social prominence from his father.{{cite web|title=Don Julius D'Austria and his Fate|url=http://www.castle.ckrumlov.cz/docs/en/zamek_oinf_dojuda.xml|publisher=State Castle and Chateau Český Krumlov|accessdate=4 January 2013}} In 1607, Rudolf sent Julius to live at [[Český Krumlov]] in Bohemia (in the modern-day [[Czech Republic]]), a castle which Rudolf purchased from the last of the [[House of Rosenberg]] ([[Peter Vok of Rosenberg|Peter Vok/Wok von Rosenberg]]) after he fell into financial ruin. Julius lived at Český Krumlov when in 1608 he reportedly abused and murdered the daughter of a local barber, who had been living in the castle, and then disfigured her body. Rudolf condemned his son's act and suggested that he should be imprisoned for the rest of his life. However, Julius died in 1609 after showing signs of [[schizophrenia]], refusing to bathe, and living in squalor; his death was apparently caused by an ulcer that ruptured. Many artworks commissioned by Rudolf are unusually erotic.Trevor-Roper, 116-120 The emperor was the subject of a whispering campaign by his enemies in his family and the [[Catholic Church]] in the years before he was deposed. Sexual allegations may well have formed a part of the campaign against him.Trevor-Roper, 121-123. Trevor-Roper mentions many stories and rumours, but not those of Rudolf's homosexuality ==Reign== Historians have traditionally blamed Rudolf's preoccupation with the arts, occult sciences, and other personal interests as the reason for the political disasters of his reign. More recently historians have re-evaluated this view and see his patronage of the arts and occult sciences as a triumph and key part of the Renaissance, while his political failures are seen as a legitimate attempt to create a unified Christian empire, which was undermined by the realities of religious, political and intellectual disintegrations of the time. [[Image:Rudolf2c.jpg|thumb|left|[[Engraving]] by [[Aegidius Sadeler]] (1603)]] Although raised in his uncle's Catholic court in Spain, Rudolf was tolerant of [[Protestantism]] and other religions including [[Judaism]]. He largely withdrew from Catholic observances, even in death denying last sacramental rites. He had little attachment to Protestants either, except as counter-weight to papal policies. He put his primary support behind [[conciliarist]]s, [[irenicist]]s and [[humanists]]. When the papacy instigated the [[Counter-Reformation]], using agents sent to his court, Rudolf backed those who he thought were the most neutral in the debate, not taking a side or trying to effect restraint, thus leading to political chaos and threatening to provoke civil war. His conflict with the [[Ottoman Empire]] was the final cause of his undoing. Unwilling to compromise with the Turks, and stubbornly determined that he could unify all of Christendom with a new [[Crusade]], he started a long and indecisive war with the Turks in 1593.Craft, Kimberly L. (2011) ''The Private Letters of Countess Erzsébet Báthory'', pp. 73-74. This war lasted till 1606, and was known as "[[Long War (Ottoman wars)|The Long War]]". By 1604 his Hungarian subjects were exhausted by the war and revolted, led by [[Stephen Bocskay]] ([[Bocskai Uprising]]). In 1605 Rudolf was forced by his other family members to cede control of Hungarian affairs to his younger brother [[Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor|Archduke Matthias]]. Matthias by 1606 forged a difficult peace with the Hungarian rebels ([[Treaty of Vienna (1606)|Peace of Vienna]]) and the Turks ([[Peace of Zsitvatorok]]). Rudolf was angry with his brother's concessions, which he saw as giving away too much in order to further Matthias' hold on power. So Rudolf prepared to start a new war with the Turks. But Matthias rallied support from the disaffected Hungarians and forced Rudolf to cede the crowns of Hungary, Austria, and Moravia to him. At the same time, seeing a moment of royal weakness, Bohemian Protestants demanded greater religious liberty, which Rudolf granted in the ''[[Letter of Majesty]]'' in 1609. The Bohemians continued to press for further freedoms, and Rudolf used his army to repress them. The Bohemian Protestants then appealed to Matthias for help; Matthias' army then held Rudolf prisoner in his castle in Prague, until 1611, when Rudolf ceded the crown of Bohemia to his brother. ==Death== [[Image:Krone Kaiser Rudolf II Kaisertum Österreich.jpg|right|thumb|200px|The [[Imperial Crown of Austria|Crown of Rudolf II]] later became the imperial crown of the [[Austrian Empire]].]] Rudolf died in 1612, nine months after he had been stripped of all effective power by his younger brother, except the empty title of Holy Roman Emperor, to which Matthias was elected five months later. In May 1618 with the event known as the [[Defenestration of Prague]], the Protestant Bohemians, in defence of the rights granted them in the ''Letter of Majesty'', threw imperial officials out of the window and thus the [[Thirty Years' War]] (1618–1648) started. ==Patron of arts, collector of curiosities== Rudolf moved the Habsburg capital from Vienna to Prague in 1583. Rudolf loved collecting paintings, and was often reported to sit and stare in rapture at a new work for hours on end. He spared no expense in acquiring great past masterworks, such as those of [[Albrecht Dürer|Dürer]] and [[Pieter Brueghel the Elder|Brueghel]]. He was also patron to some of the best contemporary artists, who mainly produced new works in the [[Northern Mannerist]] style, such as [[Bartholomeus Spranger]], [[Hans von Aachen]], [[Giambologna]], [[Giuseppe Arcimboldo]], [[Aegidius Sadeler]], [[Roelant Savery]], and [[Adrian de Vries]], as well as commissioning works from Italians like [[Paolo Veronese|Veronese]]. Rudolf's collections were the most impressive in the Europe of his day, and the greatest collection of Northern Mannerist art ever assembled. The adjective '''Rudolfine''', as in "Rudolfine Mannerism" is often used in art history to describe the style of the art he patronized. Rudolf's love of collecting went far beyond paintings and sculptures. He commissioned decorative objects of all kinds and in particular mechanical moving devices. Ceremonial swords and musical instruments, clocks, water works, astrolabes, compasses, telescopes and other scientific instruments, were all produced for him by some of the best craftsmen in Europe. He patronized [[natural philosophy|natural philosophers]] such as the botanist [[Charles de l'Ecluse]], and the astronomers [[Tycho Brahe]] and [[Johannes Kepler]] both attended his court. Tycho Brahe developed the [[Rudolphine Tables]] (finished by Kepler, after Brahe's death), the first comprehensive table of data of the movements of the planets. As mentioned before, Rudolf also attracted some of the best scientific instrument makers of the time, such as [[Jost Bürgi]], [[Erasmus Habermel]] and [[Hans Christoph Schissler]]. They had direct contact with the court astronomers and, through the financial support of the court, they were economically independent to develop scientific instruments and manufacturing techniques.{{cite book|first=Ralf|last= Kern|title= Wissenschaftliche Instrumente in ihrer Zeit/Volume 1: Vom Astrolab zum mathematischen Besteck|location= Cologne|year= 2010|pages=366 and 370}} [[Image:Vertumnus årstidernas gud målad av Giuseppe Arcimboldo 1591 - Skoklosters slott - 91503.tiff|thumb|200px|right|Rudolf painted as [[Vertumnus]], Roman God of the seasons, by [[Giuseppe Arcimboldo]] (1590–1). Rudolf greatly appreciated the work.]] The poet [[Elizabeth Jane Weston]], a writer of [[Renaissance Latin]] poetry, was also part of his court and wrote numerous odes to him. Rudolf kept a menagerie of exotic animals, botanical gardens, and Europe's most extensive "[[cabinet of curiosities]]" (''Kunstkammer'') incorporating "the three kingdoms of nature and the works of man". It was housed at [[Prague Castle]], where between 1587 and 1605 he built the northern wing to house his growing collections.Wendell E. Wilson, Joel A. Bartsch & Mark Mauthner, Masterpieces of the Mineral World: Treasures from the Houston Museum of Natural Science, Houston Museum of Natural Science Harry N. Abrams/New York, 2004. {{ISBN|0-8109-6751-0}} A lion and a tiger were allowed to roam the castle, documented by the account books which record compensation paid to survivors of attacks, or to family members of victims.Simon Winder. Danubia. pp 129-130. Picador, Pan Macmillan. {{ISBN|978-0-330-52279-3}}. 2014. Rudolf was even alleged by one person to have owned the [[Voynich manuscript]], a codex whose author and purpose, as well as the language and script and posited cipher remain unidentified to this day. According to hearsay passed on in a letter written by [[Johannes Marcus Marci]] in 1665, Rudolf was said to have acquired the manuscript at some unspecified time for 600 gold [[ducat]]s. No evidence in support of this single piece of hearsay has ever been discovered. The [[Codex Gigas]] was also in his possessions. As was typical of the time, Rudolf II had a portrait painted in the studio of the renowned Alonso Sanchez Coello. Completed in 1567 by Alonso Sanchez Coello, the portrait depicted Rudolf II at the age of 15. This painting can be seen at the [[Lobkowicz Palace]] in the Rozmberk room. [[File:Celestial globe with clockwork MET DP237684.jpg|thumb|left|Richly ornamented [[celestial globe]] with clockwork, made for the Kunstkammer of Rudolf II, 1579]] By 1597, the collection occupied three rooms of the incomplete northern wing. When building was completed in 1605, the collection was moved to the dedicated ''Kunstkammer''. ''Naturalia'' ([[mineral]]s and [[gemstone]]s) were arranged in a 37 cabinet display that had three vaulted chambers in front, each about 5.5 metres wide by 3 metres high and 60 metres long, connected to a main chamber 33 metres long. Large uncut gemstones were held in strong boxes.{{cite book |title=The History of Mineral Collecting, 1530–1799 |last=Wilson |first=Wendell |editor=Wilson, Wendell |year=1994 |publisher=Mineralogical Record |url=http://www.minrec.org/bookdetail.asp?id=34 |access-date=2012-09-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130326044645/http://minrec.org/bookdetail.asp?id=34 |archive-date=2013-03-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Rudolf's ''Kunstkammer'' was not a typical "cabinet of curiosities" – a haphazard collection of unrelated specimens. Rather, the Rudolfine ''Kunstkammer'' was systematically arranged in an [[encyclopaedic]] fashion. In addition, Rudolf II employed his polyglot court physician, [[Anselmus de Boodt|Anselmus Boetius de Boodt]] (''c.'' 1550–1632), to [[curator|curate]] the collection. [[Anselmus de Boodt|De Boodt]] was an avid mineral collector. He travelled widely on collecting trips to the [[mining]] regions of Germany, [[Bohemia]] and [[Silesia]], often accompanied by his Bohemian [[naturalist]] friend, [[Thaddaeus Hagecius]]. Between 1607 and 1611, [[Anselmus de Boodt|De Boodt]] catalogued the ''Kunstkammer'', and in 1609 he published ''Gemmarum et Lapidum'', one of the finest mineralogical treatises of the 17th century. [[File:Praha Hoefnagel 1595 DSCN0730.JPG|thumb|240px|[[Prague Castle]] in 1595 by [[Joris Hoefnagel]]]] As was customary at the time, the collection was private, but friends of the [[Emperor]], artists, and professional scholars were allowed to study it. The collection became an invaluable research tool during the flowering of 17th-century European [[philosophy]], the "[[Age of Reason]]". Rudolf's successors did not appreciate the collection and the ''Kunstkammer'' gradually fell into disarray. Some 50 years after its establishment, most of the collection was packed into wooden crates and moved to [[Vienna]]. The collection remaining at [[Prague]] was looted during the last year of the [[Thirty Years War]], by Swedish troops who sacked Prague Castle on 26 July 1648, also taking the best of the paintings, many of which later passed to the [[Orléans Collection]] after the death of [[Christina of Sweden]]. In 1782, the remainder of the collection was sold piecemeal to private parties by [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]]. One of the surviving items from the ''Kunstkammer'' is a "fine chair" looted by the Swedes in 1648 and now owned by the [[Earl of Radnor]] at [[Longford Castle]] in England;Hayward, J. F., 1980. A Chair from the 'Kunstkammer' of the Emperor Rudolf II. The Burlington Magazine, 122(927), 428 to 432. [https://www.jstor.org/pss/880029] others survive in museums.http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/rupr/hd_rupr.htmhttp://collections.frick.org/view/objects/asitem/items$0040:277 ==Occult sciences== {{HRE Arms|rudolf2}} [[Astrology]] and [[alchemy]] were regarded as mainstream scientific fields in Renaissance [[Prague]], and Rudolf was a firm devotee of both. His lifelong quest was to find the [[Philosopher's Stone]] and Rudolf spared no expense in bringing Europe's best alchemists to court, such as [[Edward Kelley]] and [[John Dee (mathematician)|John Dee]]. Rudolf even performed his own experiments in a private alchemy laboratory. When Rudolf was a prince, [[Nostradamus]] prepared a horoscope which was dedicated to him as 'Prince and King'. In the 1590s [[Sendivogius]] was active at Rudolph's court.{{cite book|url=http://www.udu.cas.cz/en/archive/alchemy-and-rudolf-ii-searching-for-the-secrets-of-nature-in-central-europe-in-the-16th-and-17th-centuries|title=Alchemy and Rudolf II. Searching for the secrets of nature in Central Europe in the 16th and 17th centuries|year=2016|authors=Ivo Purš and Vladimír Karpenko|publisher=Artefactum|ISBN=978-80-86890-33-3}} Rudolf gave Prague a mystical reputation that persists in part to this day, with [[Alchemists' Alley]] on the grounds of Prague Castle a popular visiting place and [[tourist attraction]]. Rudolf is also the ruler in many of the legends of the [[Golem of Prague]], either because of, or simply adding to, his occult reputation. ==Ancestors== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1.
